questions.text: Which of the following is the most common delayed symptom of head and neck radiation therapy?
questions.solution:
The most common delayed symptom of head and neck radiation therapy is xerostomia.

Complications of Radiotherapy

  • Xerostomia- most common
  • Mucositis
  • Temporary or permanent dysgeusia (altered taste perception)
  • Osteoradionecrosis which is related to tooth caries and results from decreased production of saliva and damage to microvasculature of mandible and maxilla.

questions.text: A 70-year-old male patient presents with halitosis, dysphagia, and regurgitation of food. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis​?
questions.solution:
The clinical history of halitosis and regurgitation in an elderly man suggests a diagnosis of Zenker's diverticulum or Pulsion pseudodiverticulum. 

Zenker diverticulum, or cricopharyngeal achalasia/pharyngeal pouch, is a pulsion-pseudodiverticulum (false diverticula occurring due to motor disorder causing increased intraluminal pressure). It results from the herniation of mucosa and submucosa through Killian's triangle (dehiscence of Killian).

Killian's triangle is an area of muscular weakness between the cricopharyngeus's transverse fibers and the thyropharyngeus's oblique fibers (shown below).

 

It is usually seen in the seventh decade of life and is thought to occur due to loss of muscle tone and elasticity causing incomplete relaxation. The impaired relaxation and spasms of the cricopharyngeus muscle after swallowing results in increased pressure within the distal pharynx and the development of Zenker's diverticulum.

Patients complain of dysphagia, halitosis, recurrent regurgitation, and respiratory infections. The most serious complications are aspiration pneumonia and lung abscess.

Diagnosis is by barium swallow studies and video laryngoscopy. The gold standard of treatment is either endoscopic or open surgery. The transoral endoscopic approach is known as the Dohlman procedure in which the common wall between the diverticulum and the cervical esophagus is ablated using laser, electrocautery, or stapler devices. It can be used for diverticula between 2 and 5 cm in size. Lesions less than 2 cm are managed with myotomy. A sac more than 5 cm is usually excised.

Other options:

Option A: Cancer esophagus also presents with dysphagia and regurgitation of food, but halitosis is more classically seen with Zenker's diverticulum. The patient would also have weight loss, anorexia and other cancer related symptoms.

Option B: Achalasia is a type of esophageal motility disorder and a premalignant condition that occurs due to hypertension of the lower esophageal sphincter and thereby failure to relax. The classic triad of presentation is dysphagia, regurgitation, and weight loss. Esophagogram shows the classic bird beak appearance (dilated esophagus with distal narrowing). 

Option D: GERD also presents with dysphagia and regurgitation of food, but halitosis is not seen in GERD, it is more classic of Zenker's diverticulum.

questions.text: Identify the type of pelvis in the given image.
questions.solution:
A round-shaped pelvic inlet is associated with the gynecoid pelvis.

questions.text: A 30-year-old primigravida at 18 weeks of gestation presents for her antenatal check-up. Her random plasma glucose level was 243 mg/dL and thus she was asked to undergo further tests. The fasting blood glucose levels were 146mg/dL and HbA1c was 7.6%.  Which among the following is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?

choices.text: Maturity onset Diabetes of the young

questions.solution:
A fasting blood sugar > 126 mg/dL , random blood sugar > 200mg/dL and HbA1c> 6.5% is suggestive of overt diabetes or pregestational diabetes. 

The following are the lab results that would be suggestive of overt diabetes in a mother.

  • Fasting blood sugar at least 126 mg/dL
  • A random blood sugar of at least 200 mg/dL
  • HbA1c of at least 6.5%

Cardiac anomalies are most commonly seen in the fetuses of overt-diabetic mothers. Musculoskeletal, urogenital, and CNS anomalies are also seen,

Congenital malformations occur at a higher rate, in overt diabetes than in gestational diabetes mellitus (GDM). This is because GDM manifests in the second trimester and by then organogenesis would be complete.

Threshold values for gestational diabetes (75 g OGTT):

Plasma glucose Glucose concentration threshold
Fasting 92 mg/dl
1 hr OGTT 180 mg/dl
2 hr OGTT 153 mg/dl

 

According to WHO and ADA guidelines, the one-step approach omits the screening test and simplifies diagnostic testing for gestational diabetes mellitus by performing only a 75-gram, two-hour oral GTT.

Diagnostic criteria or cut-off values with a 75 g OGTT are as follows:

  • Fasting: 92 mg/dl 
  • 1 hour: 180 mg/dl  
  • 2 hours: 153 mg/dl

Two-step approach :

  • The first step (screening) is a 50-gram one-hour glucose challenge test (GCT) at 24-28 weeks of gestation who are not previously diagnosed with diabetes.
  • If the plasma glucose level measured 1 h after the load is ≥130, a 100-gram, three-hour oral glucose tolerance test (GTT) is done, which is the diagnostic test for gestational diabetes mellitus.

 At least 2 of the following 4 values should be raised for a diagnosis to be made:

  • Fasting: 95 mg/dL (5.3 mmol/L)
  • 1 h: 180 mg/dL (10.0 mmol/L)
  • 2 h: 155 mg/dL (8.6 mmol/L)
  • 3 h: 140 mg/dL (7.8 mmol/L)

Other options:

Option A: MODY or maturity-onset diabetes of the young is a monogenic form of diabetes that occurs < 25 years. There is impaired insulin secretion, but no antibodies.

Option D: LADA  is a form of diabetes mellitus affecting lean and thin adults less than 50 years with a positive family history. It is insulin-dependent and associated with autoantibodies.

Related Pearl: Types of Diabetes mellitus

I. Type 1 diabetes: Beta cell destruction, usually leading to absolute insulin deficiency

  • Immune-mediated
  • Idiopathic

II. Type 2 diabetes: Insulin resistance with relative insulin deficiency

III. Other specific types of diabetes

  • Genetic defects of beta cell development or function
    • MODY – Maturity Onset Diabetes of Young
  • Genetic defects in insulin action
    • Type A insulin resistance
    • Leprechaunism
    • Rabson-Mendenhall syndrome Lipodystrophy syndromes
  • Diseases of the exocrine pancreas
    • Pancreatitis
    • Neoplasia
    • Cystic fibrosis
    • Hemochromatosis
  • Endocrinopathies
    • Acromegaly
    • Cushing’s syndrome
    • Glucagonoma
    • Pheochromocytoma
    • Hyperthyroidism
  • Infections
    • Congenital rubella
    • Cytomegalovirus
    • Coxsackievirus
  • Uncommon forms of immune-mediated diabetes
    • “Stiff-person” syndrome
    • Anti-insulin receptor antibodies
  • Genetic syndromes sometimes associated with diabetes
    • Wolfram’s syndrome
    • Down’s syndrome, Klinefelter’s syndrome, Turner’s syndrome

IV. Gestational diabetes mellitus (GDM)

questions.text: In an elderly male experiencing recurrent fainting episodes, the electrocardiogram shows P waves at a rate of 75 beats per minute and qRS complexes at a rate of 35 bpm. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
In this clinical scenario, elderly male experiencing recurrent fainting episodes, with P waves at 75 bpm and qRS complexes at 35 bpm.

The presence of P waves at a rate of 75 bpm suggests normal atrial activity, while qRS complexes at a rate of 35 bpm indicate a significant bradycardia. This combination of findings is consistent with a severe AV block, suggesting a diagnosis of Stokes-Adams syndrome.

Stokes-Adams syndrome, also known as Adams-Stokes syndrome, refers to episodes of syncope (fainting) caused by sudden, temporary interruptions of the heart's electrical activity, leading to a lack of blood flow to the brain. This interruption often results from complete heart block (third-degree AV block) or other severe bradyarrhythmias.

Prompt recognition and management, including consideration of pacemaker therapy, are essential in such cases to prevent further syncopal episodes and potential complications.

Other options:

OPTION B: (Second-degree AV block: Second-degree AV block is characterized by intermittent failure of atrial impulses to conduct to the ventricles. This condition may present with a variety of patterns, such as Mobitz type I (Wenckebach) or Mobitz type II. While second-degree AV block can lead to symptomatic bradycardia and syncope, the specific ECG findings described in the question are more consistent with a complete heart block or severe bradycardia.

OPTION C: First-degree AV block: First-degree AV block is characterized by a prolonged PR interval on the ECG, indicating delayed conduction from the atria to the ventricles. It typically does not result in symptomatic bradycardia or syncope.

OPTION D: Electrical alternans: Electrical alternans refer to a phenomenon in which the amplitude of certain ECG waves, such as the QRS complex or T wave, alternates from beat to beat. It is often associated with pericardial effusion, cardiac tamponade, or severe left ventricular dysfunction, rather than bradyarrhythmias leading to syncope.

questions.text: A 50-year-old diabetic man presents with a progressive increase in pain in his calf, initially after walking a distance of 400m later 200m over the last 6 months. He now prefers to sleep in a seated position by hanging his leg to alleviate pain. Which of the following is the most likely cause?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario describes a case of peripheral arterial disease which has worsened over time. This patient who prefers to sleep in a seated position by hanging his leg to alleviate pain now has rest pain.

Peripheral arterial disease (PAD) presents as intermittent claudication (crampy pain in the muscles). As the disease progresses, claudication distance decreases, and pain occurs even at rest called ischemic rest pain. Rest pain is due to ischemia of the somatic nerves. The pain is exacerbated by lying down or elevation of the foot due to the loss of the gravitational effects on perfusion pressure. It may be lessened by hanging the foot down. 

Physical exam findings include atrophied skin, pallor on the raising leg (Buerger's test), nail changes, and decreased peripheral pulses.

The initial investigation done is an ABI. Further investigation is done with Doppler imaging, duplex scan, and digital subtraction angiography. Rest pain is seen when ABI becomes <0.5. 

Other options:

Option A: Sciatica - The patient complains of pain radiating down the back of the thigh and calf. Sciatica can either be because of inflammation of the sciatic nerve or because of compression of one of the roots constituting the sciatic nerve

Option B:  Neurogenic claudication occurs with changes in the position of the back such as bending forward and straightening. It takes more time to be relieved by rest (more than 5 minutes). In spinal stenosis, there is an abnormal narrowing of the central canal, the lateral recesses, or the intervertebral foramina to the point where the neural elements are compromised.

Option C: Patients with venous claudication have some form of venous diseases like varicose veins, edema and skin changes due to chronic venous diseases like pigmentation, eczema or ulcers.

 

Related Pearl: Ankle–brachial Pressure Index (ABPI)

The ankle-brachial Pressure Index (ABPI) is the ratio of systolic pressure at the ankle to that in the arm.

The numerator is the highest pressure in the dorsalis pedis, posterior tibial, or peroneal artery and the denominator is the highest brachial systolic pressure.

ABPI Reading Interpretation
>0.91 < 1.3 Normal
<0.9 Diagnostic of occlusive arterial disease in patients with symptoms of claudication or other signs of ischemia
0.5 to 0.9 Arterial obstruction often associated with claudication
<0.3 Critical limb ischemia (multilevel obstruction i.e any combination of iliac, femoral or tibial vessel disease and may be associated with non-healing ulcerations, ischemic rest pain, or pedal gangrene.
>1.4 Signifies poor compressibility of the arteries. Mostly due to calcification because of increased age, diabetes etc.

Note: A fall in the resting ABPI of more than 20% after exercise is indicative of arterial disease.

questions.text: A young male child was brought for psychiatric evaluation for intellectual disability. On examination, his IQ was 45. He has a long face, large ear, large testis and a cardiac murmur. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette along with the family history is suggestive of fragile X syndrome.

  • Fragile X syndrome is the second most common genetic cause of mental retardation (Down syndrome being the most common).
  • It is caused by a trinucleotide mutation in the familial mental retardation-1 (FMR1) gene.
  • When the cells were cultured in a folate-deficient medium, the cytogenetic alteration was discovered as a break in the staining in the long arm of the X chromosome. As it appeared that the chromosome was “broken” at this locale, it was named as a fragile site.
  • In fragile X syndrome, the affected males are mentally retarded, with an IQ in the range of 20 to 60.
  • The characteristic phenotypic features includes:
    • Long face with a large mandible
    • Large everted ears
    • Large testicles (macro-orchidism)
  • In some cases, hyperextensible joints, a high arched palate, and mitral valve prolapse may also be noted.

questions.text: An underweight adolescent girl is found to have the following finding on her ocular examination. What is the WHO grade for this finding?
questions.solution:
The given image shows a Bitot spot which is a feature seen in vitamin A deficiency. According to the WHO grading of xerophthalmia, Bitot spots are classified as 1B.

Bitos spots are triangular, pearly-white or yellowish, foamy spots on the bulbar conjunctiva on either side of the cornea.

Related Pearl: WHO grading of Vitamin A deficiency

The term xerophthalmia is reserved to cover all the ocular manifestations of vitamin A deficiency.

Stage Features Pathophysiology
XN Night blindness Lack of rhodopsin
X1A Conjunctival Xerosis Conjunctival epithelial alteration, loss of goblet cells
X1B Bitot’s spots Conjunctival keratinization and plaque formation
X2 Corneal xerosis Corneal epithelial alteration
X3A Corneal ulceration/ Keratomalacia affecting <1/3rd of the corneal surface Liquefaction of corneal stroma
X3B Corneal ulceration/ Keratomalacia affecting >1/3rd of the corneal surface              -
XS Corneal scar              -
XF Xerophthalmic fundus Degeneration of the retinal pigment epithelium

The first symptom of xerophthalmia is nyctalopia.

The first sign of xerophthalmia is conjunctival xerosis.

The pathognomonic feature of xerophthalmia is the appearance of Bitot's spots.

Note:

Up to the level of Stage 2, the manifestations are reversible if treated with vitamin A supplements.

However, active conjunctival xerosis and Bitot’s spots begin to resolve within 2—5 days after supplementation. Most will disappear within 2 weeks, although a significant proportion of temporal lesions may persist in shrunken form and may therefore not be completely reversible.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false regarding the given image?

choices.text: It is inserted by withdrawal technique
The copper in this device has a surface area of 380 square mm
It is used in emergency contraception
It has a life-span of 5 years

questions.solution:
The given image is CuT 380 A as it has copper in both the stem as well as the horizontal arms and it has the highest life span of 10 years.

Copper T-380A (Paragard):

It is named so for the 380 mm2 of copper surface area. A higher surface area of copper results in higher contraceptive efficacy. 

It has a plastic T-shaped core with copper placed around the vertical stem and horizontal arms. A silver core within the copper sheath is included to prevent fragmentation of the copper, extending the lifespan of the Copper T-380A.

The frame is connected to a monofilament thread that protrudes through the cervical canal into the upper vagina. This facilitates easy removal and allows the user to ensure that the IUD remains in the uterus.

If an IUCD is inserted within 5 days after coitus, it serves as an emergency contraceptive and is more effective than levonorgestrel/ulipristal acetate regimens.

questions.text: A 42-year old alcoholic and a chronic smoker presented with bouts of vomiting and stabbing pain in the epigastrium. He was binge drinking shortly before the symptoms started. He is febrile and tachycardic. The given findings were seen on bedside radiological imaging. Which among the following is a likely cause of this?
questions.solution:
In the given case scenario, the supine abdominal x-ray shows air beneath the diaphragm along with Rigler's double-wall sign indicating pneumoperitoneum. The likely cause for this would be peptic ulcer perforation. Consumption of alcohol and chronic tobacco smoking are high-risk factors for developing peptic ulcers. Fever and tachycardia suggest peritonitis from the perforated ulcer. 

Gastric ulcers are more prone to perforate than bleed. Thus, these perforations lead to pneumoperitoneum which is an emergency and warrants immediate surgical intervention.

 Other options: 

A. Tension pneumothorax - presents with a rapid hemodynamic compromise with absent breath sounds. Pneumoperitoneum rarely is caused by pneumothorax, and downward displacement of air is more likely seen in retroperitoneal spaces.

C. Boerhaave syndrome or spontaneous esophageal rupture - occurs in alcoholics after binge drinking, due to forced vomiting from the closed glottis.  Pneumomediastinum and subcutaneous emphysema are seen here. 

D. Mallory Weis tear - longitudinal mucosal tear resulting in upper GI bleeding. It is commonly seen in alcoholics.

questions.text: A 5-year-old girl was brought to the outpatient department by her mother saying she noted some abnormality in her genital area. On examination, there was presence of pubic and axillary hair. Which of the following is the least likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The presence of pubic and axillary hair in a five-year-old girl is suggestive of precocious puberty and 17-Hydroxylase deficiency is least likely to cause it. 

In 17-hydroxylase deficiency, patients are unable to synthesize sex hormones. Females are normal at birth and present with complaints of delayed puberty, primary amenorrhea, and a lack of secondary sexual characteristics in later life. The affected males are incompletely virilized and present as phenotypic females but undescended testes are usually palpable in the inguinal region.

In both 21-hydroxylase and 11β-hydroxylase deficiencies, the respective precursors to the hormones are shunted to the androgen synthesis pathway, resulting in all the signs and symptoms of androgen excess. Female babies are typically born with signs of virilization like ambiguous genitalia characterized by clitoral enlargement and labial fusion. Whereas, the males have normal-appearing genitalia at birth and present at 2 to 4 years with precocious puberty like early pubarche, a growth spurt, and adult body odour.

Since this child is having features of ambiguous genitalia and virilization, it is unlikely that she would have a 17-Hydroxylase deficiency.

Related Pearl: Variants of Congenital Adrenal Hyperplasia (CAH)

21-Hydroxylase 17-Hydroxylase 11β-Hydroxylase 3β-HSD

Deficiency of cortisol and aldosterone;

↑ in testosterone

 Deficiency of cortisol and sex hormones; ↑ in aldosterone Deficiency of cortisol; ↑ in deoxycorticosterone (mineralocorticoid) and testosterone Deficiency of cortisol, aldosterone and testosterone; ↑ in DHEA
Salt wasting crises Salt retention and  hypertension

Salt retention and  hypertension

 Salt-wasting crises
Virilization of females (ambiguous genitalia 46XX)     Failure of sexual development in females at puberty Virilization of females  (ambiguous genitalia 46XX) Females are mildly
virilized (DHEA is a weak androgen)
Precocious puberty in males Males are incompletely virilized (ambiguous genitalia 46XY) Precocious puberty in males Males are incompletely virilized (ambiguous genitalia 46XY)

Note: In 11β-Hydroxylase deficiency, Aldosterone synthetic capacity is normal and some corticosterone is synthesized from progesterone by intact aldosterone synthase enzyme. Thus, it is unusual for patients to manifest signs of adrenal insufficiency.

questions.text: An 18-year-old boy is brought to you by his concerned grandmother with a history of having experienced several episodes of jerking of the body the day before his final exam. There was no history post-ictal confusion or tongue bite and his investigations were normal. Which of the following conditions should be considered?
questions.solution:
In the given scenario, absence of muscle spasm, tongue thrusting, or post-ictal confusion, and normal investigations just before the final exam (personal gain), points towards malingering.

Intentional production of symptoms to achieve some practical gain (e.g. avoidance of work, financial compensation, avoidance of criminal responsibility, or military service) is suggestive of malingering.

Factitious disorder (Munchausen syndrome) is the intentional production of physical symptoms to obtain medical attention, not a practical gain.

questions.text: A newborn is seen to have an abnormal lump in the lower back. Identify the condition from the MRI given below.
questions.solution:
The MRI given represents meningocele. 

Meningocele involves the midline protrusion of the meninges. A fluctuant midline mass, that may transilluminate is present in the lower back along the vertebral column. Meningomyelocele involves the protrusion of the spinal cord with the meningeal covering. Neurological dysfunction is more common in these open defects.

Spina bifida occulta refers to fusion defects of the posterior part of the vertebral body. There is no associated protrusion of the spinal cord or meninges. These neonates are usually asymptomatic, without any neurological signs. They present only with a tuft of hair over the lower back. 

The image below shows (from left to right) spina bifida occulta, meningocele, and meningomyelocele-

questions.text: What is the stage of the breast cancer shown in the image?
questions.solution:
The image shows Peau d'orange appearance of breast which is T4b according to the TNM staging.

Tumour of any size with overlying skin involvement(Peau d'orange appearance) is T4b.

The peau d'orange appearance of the breast occurs due to blockade of sub-dermal lymphatics.The lymphatic blockade gives rise to edema in the breast and tries to swell up. Since the infiltrated skin is tethered to the ligaments of Cooper, the swelling is restricted. The resultant edema deepens the mouth of the sweat glands and hair follicles giving rise to the typical orange peel appearance.

questions.text: Koebner's phenomenon is seen in all of the following, except?
questions.solution:
Koebner's phenomenon is not seen in herpes.

Koebner’s phenomenon/ isomorphic response is the development of lesions in previously normal skin that has been subjected to trauma. If the same response is seen from the spread of an infective agent ( like molluscum contagiosum, viral warts), it's called pseudo-Koebner’s phenomenon.

Any of the following can elicit an isomorphic response: physical trauma, including friction, pressure, incision and laceration, skin grafting, bites, vaccination skin tests, burns, freezing, and ultraviolet (UV) and ionizing radiation.

It is seen commonly associated with psoriasis, lichen planus, and vitiligo. Other associated disorders include Darrier’s disease, pityriasis rubra pilaris, lichen nitidus, DLE, necrobiosis lipoidica, and Grzybowski syndrome.

questions.text: A 9-year-old boy is brought to the hospital with complaints of pain and limping. The symptoms started 6 months back and gradually worsened. The child appears to be healthy with normal height and weight. On examination, there is mild wasting on the right side, abduction ( especially in flexion ), and internal rotation is limited due to pain. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A young male patient with normal height and weight and complaints of pain and limping gradually progressing over 6 months and examination findings of limited abduction and internal rotation is likely to have Perthes's disease. The image shows a mushroom-shaped femoral head that is laterally displaced in a dysplastic acetabular socket. 

Between 4 and 7 years of age, the femoral head may depend on the lateral epiphyseal vessels for its blood supply and venous drainage almost entirely. These vessels situated in the retinacula make them susceptible to stretching and to pressure from an effusion.

The disease is characterized by the disruption of blood flow to the head of the femur. Due to which the bone goes for osteonecrosis and stops growing. Over time, healing occurs by new blood vessels infiltrating the dead bone and removing the necrotic bone which leads to a loss of bone mass and a weakening of the femoral head.

Clinical features include a boy of 4-8 years complaining of pain and limping. Symptoms continue for weeks on end or recur intermittently. The hip looks deceptively normal. Although initially, all movements are painful; with time, abduction with internal rotation is always limited.

Xray findings depend on the stages 

  • Necrotic phase: Radiographically dense areas which indicate new bone formation is soon followed by bone necrosis.
  • Fragmentation phase: Alternating patches of density and lucency. Sometimes a crescentic subarticular fracture is often seen in lateral view
  • Re-ossification phase: Epiphyseal density increases in this phase
  • Healing phase: Normal femoral head or mushroom-shaped femoral head which is laterally displaced in a dysplastic acetabular socket.

There are different 'head at risk signs' described by Catrell which include:

  • lateral subluxation of the femoral head
  • speckled calcification in the lateral epiphysis
  • Epiphysis being horizontal
  • Gage's sign: V-shaped osteoporotic segment in the lateral epiphysis and adjacent metaphysis.

Guidelines to treatment are derived from the review by Herring,

Children under 6 years - symptomatic treatment including activity modification is appropriate

Children aged 6-8 years - Bonge age and Catterall Staging determines the modality of treatment. Options include abduction brace or osteotomy.

For children aged 9 and above - operative containment is the choice.

Note:Salter's extrusion angle helps to assess the femoral head extrusion. Normal is 50 degrees or more.

questions.text: What type of deposition is typically observed in the cerebral cortex in patients with dialysis-dementia?
questions.solution:
Amyloid ß-2 is the amyloid protein associated with dialysis-associated amyloidosis.

Dialysis-related amyloidosis

  • It is seen in patients undergoing long-term hemodialysis or continuous ambulatory peritoneal dialysis (CAPD).
  • It causes destructive osteoarthropathies, such as carpal tunnel syndrome, flexor tenosynovitis, subchondral bone cysts, and pathologic fractures.
  • The most severe complication involves amyloid ß-2 amyloid deposits destroying paravertebral ligaments and intervertebral discs, which can result in paraplegia.
  • It can also cause visceral involvement, like the gastrointestinal (GI) tract, heart, and tongue.

Treatment

  • Symptomatic relief in patients with analgesic and anti-inflammatory medication, physical and occupational therapy, and surgical procedures.
  • Renal transplantation is the treatment of choice.

Other Options:

  • Cerebral Amyloid Angiopathy (CAA) is a condition characterized by the accumulation of Amyloid transthyretin protein in the walls of small and medium-sized blood vessels in the brain, specifically in the cerebral cortex and leptomeninges.
  • Amyloid beta deposition is a characteristic feature of Alzheimer's disease.

questions.text: A cancer patient undergoing radiotherapy is given a dose of 1.8 to 2 Gy once daily for 5 days per week for a duration of 6 to 8 weeks. What is this type of brachytherapy called?
questions.solution:
Since the patient is given a dose of 1.8-2.0 Gy per day for 5 days a week, for 6 to 8 weeks, it is called Regular/Conventional Fractionated Radiotherapy.

Radiotherapy:

The total dose of radiation needed for a tumor is usually given as fractions over the entire treatment period as it maximizes the effects of the radiation on the malignant cells and minimizes the damage to the healthy cells.

The reasons for this are due to :

1. Re-distribution: Cells are more resistant to damage in the late S2 phase while sensitive in the M and G2 phase. Only some tumor cells will be in the sensitive phase of the cell cycle when the radiation is given. Hence, giving another dose at a later time helps in killing the other cells that were in the resistant part of the cell cycle, thus increasing the success rate of the therapy.

2. Re-oxygenation: Hypoxic cells are less sensitive to the indirect effects of radiation. The tumor cells which are closer to oxygen sources are killed first and in the intervening time, the other relatively hypoxic cells can improve their oxygenation so that the next fraction of radiation is effective on them. 

3. Repair: The ability to repair DNA is more for healthy cells than malignant cells and thus when a radiation dose has been received, the healthy cells repair their DNA faster than the malignant cells. The malignant cells whose DNA is not fully repaired are highly susceptible to the next dose of radiation.

Types of fractionation:

Standard Fractionation: Radiotherapy(RT) is given once daily for 5 days/week, not more than 2 Gy/fraction.

Accelerated Fractionation:(Option C) Any fractionation schedule that gives >10 Gy/week. Subtypes include:

  • Pure accelerated fractionation (2 Gy/fraction, 6–7 fractions/week)
  • Accelerated hypofractionation (>3 Gy/fraction)
  • Accelerated hyperfractionation (>1 fraction/day)

Hypofractionation: Increased fraction size, with or without a decreased number of fractions/week.

  • Stereotactic Radiation (SRS/SBRT/SABR): RT delivered with stereotactic localization techniques in five fractions or less.
  • Fractionated Stereotactic RT (FSRT): RT delivered with stereotactic techniques and more than five fractions.

Hyperfractionation: Decreased fraction size with more than one fraction per day (BID or TID). (Option B)

Concomitant Boost (CB): Two fractions per day with one fraction to a large field and the other to a boost volume.

Simultaneous Integrated Boost (SIB): One fraction per day with a higher dose to a boost volume and a lower dose to the large field.

Note: Brachytherapy(Option D) is a method of treatment in which sealed radioactive sources are used to deliver radiation at a short distance by interstitial, intracavitary, or surface application.

questions.text: Which of these steps is followed first for the management of shoulder dystocia after McRoberts maneuver?

choices.text: Flex the legs over the abdomen

questions.solution:
Applying a gentle suprapubic pressure is the first step in the management of shoulder dystocia after the McRoberts maneuver.

Shoulder dystocia drill to better organize emergency management:

  • Call for help. Initially, a gentle attempt at traction is made. Drain the bladder if it is distended.
  • Episiotomy
  • McRoberts maneuver followed by application of suprapubic pressure. This maneuver requires the use of an assistant to apply pressure suprapubically with the palm or fist, directing the pressure on the anterior shoulder both downward (to below the pubic bone) and laterally (toward the baby's face or sternum).

These maneuvers will resolve most cases of shoulder dystocia. If not -

  • Delivery of the posterior arm is attempted. 
  • Woods screw maneuver is applied.
  • Rubin maneuver is attempted.

Other techniques generally should be reserved for cases in which all other maneuvers have failed. These include intentional fracture of the anterior clavicle and the Zavanelli maneuver.

questions.text: A 10-year-old child presents with brown-colored urine, flank pain, and fatigue for the last 3 days. He has 2+ proteinuria with >20 red cells/HPF and dysmorphic red blood cells. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A child presenting with acute onset (3 days) flank pain, cola-colored urine, and mild to moderate proteinuria is suggestive of a nephritic syndrome picture. The only disease which causes this out of the given options is post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis (PSGN).

PSGN is primarily caused by group A β-hemolytic streptococcal infections in children aged 5 to 12 years. It is caused by immune complexes containing streptococcal antigens (M protein of cell wall) and specific antibodies. PSGN typically manifests as an acute nephritic syndrome, appearing either 1 to 2 weeks after streptococcal pharyngitis or 3 to 6 weeks after streptococcal pyoderma. The severity of kidney involvement can vary, ranging from asymptomatic microscopic hematuria with normal renal function to gross hematuria with acute renal failure. Edema, hypertension, and oliguria may be present depending on the extent of renal involvement.

Laboratory findings commonly include a significant decrease in serum C3 levels during the acute phase, with values returning to normal within 6 to 8 weeks. To confirm the diagnosis, evidence of a preceding streptococcal infection is necessary. The antistreptolysin O (ASO) titer often increases following pharyngitis, while the anti-deoxyribonuclease B level is a reliable indicator of cutaneous streptococcal infection.

Light microscopic examination reveals enlarged, hypercellular glomeruli with diffuse mesangial and endothelial proliferation, as well as leukocyte infiltration. Immunofluorescence analysis demonstrates granular deposits of IgG and complement C3 along the glomerular basement membrane (GBM) and in the mesangium. Electron microscopy primarily shows subepithelial humps, with subendothelial deposits observed in early stages of the disease.

Managing the acute effects of renal insufficiency (sodium restriction and diuretics) and hypertension is the mainstay. Antibiotic therapy with a 10-day course of penicillin is recommended to limit the spread of nephritogenic pathogens. But antibiotics do not alter the natural course of PSGN. Complete resolution of the hematuria and proteinuria in the majority of children occurs within 3–6 weeks of the onset of nephritis but 3–10% of children may have persistent microscopic hematuria, non-nephrotic proteinuria, or hypertension.

Below is the image showing light microscopy findings of post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis:

questions.text: A child presents with Hb 6.3 with a history of repeated blood transfusions. Investigations show MCV- 70 fl and the peripheral smear showed a hypochromic microcytic picture. Which of the following investigations should be done next in this child?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of repeated transfusions, low Hb, low MCV, and a hypochromic microcytic picture in the smear is suggestive of thalassemia and Hb electrophoresis should be done in this for diagnosis.

Hb Electrophoresis is used for newborn screening. High-performance liquid chromatography (HPLC) is the investigation of choice but is not as definitive as globin gene sequencing. 

Alpha- and beta-thalassemia are inherited disorders in which there is reduced production of alpha-globin or beta-globin chains, respectively. This leads to the precipitation of the excess (unpaired) chains, interfering with red blood cell (RBC) production and survival. Disease severity is inversely correlated with the number of functioning globin chains.

Each individual carries 2 beta-chain genes and 4 alpha-chain genes.

Haemoglobin levels:

  • Normal hemoglobin pattern- HbA=95%, HbA2=3.5%, HbF =1.5%
  • Beta-thalassemia trait- HbA=90%, HbA2=5%, HbF=5%
  • Beta-thalassemia intermedia- HbA=45%, HbA2=5%, HbF=50%

Clinical features in thalassemia:

  • Anaemia
  • Jaundice and pigment gallstones
  • Skeletal deformities including facial deformities, changes in body habitus, osteopenia/osteoporosis
  • Iron overload
  • Growth impairment
  • Hepatosplenomegaly
  • Endocrine abnormalities including hypogonadism, hypothyroidism, diabetes mellitus
  • Heart failure and arrhythmias

Laboratory studies:

  • Peripheral smear is likely to show microcytic hypochromic anaemia with target cells, teardrop cells, and some coarse basophilic stippling in certain cases. These findings are non-specific. 
  • High RBC count 
  • Low reticulocyte count
  • High LDH, high indirect bilirubin, low haptoglobin, and negative Coomb's test
  • High transferrin saturation, normal serum iron levels, elevated ferritin levels

Other options:

Option A: Measurement of serum iron is necessary to monitor for iron overload in case of repeated blood transfusion. But in this case, the first step is to confirm the diagnosis by doing Hb electrophoresis.

Option B: Direct Coomb's test is used to test for AIHA- Autoimmune hemolytic anaemia. Given the history, AIHA seems unlikely and it usually occurs in adults and is unusual in a child.

Option C: Osmotic fragility test is a test done in the case of hereditary spherocytosis. It presents with splenomegaly, anemia, and hyperbilirubinemia. The MCV is decreased and MCHC is increased due to dehydration. It is unlikely to have a history of chronic blood transfusion.

Related Pearl: Thalassemia syndromes

Normally each individual carries 4 functional alpha chain genes and 2 functional beta chain genes. Alpha and beta-thalassemia are inherited disorders in which there is reduced production of alpha-globin or beta-globin chains, respectively.

  • Alpha thalassemia: Gene deletion is the most common cause of reduced α-chain synthesis.
  • Beta +- thalassemia: The most common cause is splicing mutation.
  • Beta 0- thalassemia: Chain terminator mutations are the most common cause.

questions.text: A 50-year-old male patient presents with difficulty in breathing and dizziness. He has been undergoing treatment for lung cancer. On examination, breath sounds were reduced over the left inferior-scapular region. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of dyspnea, dizziness, and reduced breath sounds over the left inferior-scapular region in a patient with lung cancer is suggestive of pleural effusion.

Pleural effusion refers to the pathological accumulation of fluid in the pleural space due to

  • Excess fluid formation from the interstitial spaces of the lung, parietal pleura, or peritoneal cavity.
  • Decreased fluid removal by the lymphatics.

Pleural effusion may present with dyspnea, pleuritic pain, dry cough, and associated symptoms like fever, weight loss, edema, and ascites depending on the etiology. On examination, there may be tachypnea, dullness on percussion and decreased/absent breath sounds at the base(s).

The etiology of pleural effusion can be of two types:

  • Exudative: disruption in pleural fluid formation and drainage because of local factors. Examples include malignancy, infections, and pulmonary embolism.
  • Transudative: disruption in pleural fluid formation and drainage due to systemic factors. Examples include congestive heart failure, hepatic cirrhosis, and nephrotic syndrome.

Light’s criteria can be used to differentiate between transudative and exudative pleural effusions. Exudative effusions will meet at least one of the following criteria:

  1. Pleural fluid protein/serum protein >0.5
  2. Pleural fluid LDH/serum LDH >0.6
  3. Pleural fluid LDH is more than two-thirds of the upper limit of normal for serum. 

Recommended tests for all diagnostic thoracocentesis include:

  • Lactate dehydrogenase (LDH) and protein
  • Microscopy and culture
  • Cytology and differential count
  • Glucose, pH, triglycerides, amylase, haematocrit, AFB culture and PCR can be done if a particular etiology is suspected.

Other options:

  1. Constrictive pericarditis: Symptoms may include swelling in the legs, fatigue, and discomfort, but it's not directly associated with reduced breath sounds or localized findings on lung examination.

  2. Cardiac tamponade is characterized by the accumulation of fluid in the pericardial space leading to impairment of diastolic relaxation of the cardiac chambers. This leads to a decline in cardiac output. The characteristic signs of cardiac tamponade are Beck's triad, which consists of hypotension, muffled heart sounds, and elevated jugular venous pressure.

  3. Pneumothorax: It can cause sudden, sharp chest pain and difficulty breathing, but it often presents with hyper-resonant percussion (tapping on the chest) and decreased breath sounds on the affected side.

questions.text: A 45-year-old chronic alcoholic is brought to the hospital due to fever and abdominal pain. He was diagnosed to have a cirrhotic liver 2 years back. The ascitic fluid shows a neutrophil count of 360 cell/ microliter. Which of the following is the drug of choice in this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient’s clinical features are suggestive of spontaneous bacterial peritonitis (SBP). The drug of choice in this patient is cefotaxime.

SBP is characterized by spontaneous infection of the ascitic fluid without an intraabdominal source. It is commonly seen in adults in association with liver cirrhosis. The pathogens involved are Escherichia coli, streptococci, enterococci, and pneumococci. 

In a patient with ascites, SBP presents with fever and acute abdominal pain. On examination, tachycardia, tachypnea, and signs of peritonitis are seen. Hepatic encephalopathy and gastrointestinal bleeding may also occur. 

Diagnosis is by paracentesis and an ascitic fluid neutrophil count of >250/mm3 is suggestive of spontaneous bacterial peritonitis. Ascitic fluid culture may reveal pathogenic organisms.

Management is mainly by third-generation cephalosporins such as cefotaxime. Albumin infusion can be given as it decreases the risk of renal failure and improves patient survival. Early diagnosis and treatment improve the prognosis. In patients who have had an episode of SBP and recovered, once-weekly administration of antibiotics is used as prophylaxis for recurrent SBP.

questions.text:
An elderly man underwent Roux-en-Y gastric bypass surgery for obesity. He now presents to his physician with complaints of dizziness, fatigue, and tremors 2 hours after the ingestion of a carbohydrate-rich meal. His symptoms occur mainly due to
  1. Hypoglycemia
  2. Small volume of food intake
  3. High osmotic load of food
  4. Increased release of insulin
  5. Increased release of glucagon
questions.solution:
The patient is presenting with features of late dumping syndrome following Roux-en-Y gastric bypass surgery. This occurs due to an increased release of insulin and hypoglycemia.

Dumping syndrome occurs due to rapid gastric emptying. It is commonly seen following gastric surgeries. It can be divided into

  • Early dumping syndrome- Occurs after ingestions of foods with a high osmotic load. Increased osmotic load in the intestine leads to the sequestration of fluid from the circulation into the gastrointestinal tract. Patients will develop hypovolemia and hypotension.
  • Late dumping syndrome- Occurs after ingestion of a large volume of meals and meals which are rich in carbohydrates. A large amount of glucose is absorbed from the intestine which leads to a rapid increase in blood sugar levels. This in turns results in increased release of insulin which causes hypoglycemia. 

The mainstay in the management of dumping syndrome is dietary manipulation. The patient is advised to have small volume, regular meals that are rich in protein, fat, and low in carbohydrates. Somatostatin analogue like octreotide is used in the management of intractable syndromes.

questions.text: A female patient presents with ambiguous genitalia and rapid virilization. She also complains of excessive facial hair growth, voice deepening, and an enlarged clitoris over the past few months. CT scan is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The presented clinical scenario, along with the CT scan findings of bilaterally enlarged adrenal glands with nodules in the adrenal cortex, suggests a likely diagnosis of Congenital Adrenal Hyperplasia (CAH).

Congenital adrenal hyperplasia (CAH) is a disorder of cortisol synthesis. It has an autosomal recessive pattern of inheritance. Cortisol deficiency increases the secretion of the adrenocorticotropic hormone (ACTH), causing adrenal hyperplasia with the overproduction of intermediate metabolites. This child has clitoromegaly due to increased androgen synthesis. The enzyme 21-hydroxylase helps in the downstream synthesis of cortisol and aldosterone. A deficiency of aldosterone causes salt wasting that presents as low blood pressure.

The presentation depends on the enzyme that is deficient, which could result in mineralocorticoid deficiency or excess, incomplete virilization or precocious puberty in affected males, and virilization or sexual infantilism in affected females.

Given below is the pathway and enzymes involved in adrenal steroid synthesis:

Other options:

Adrenocortical carcinoma might appear as a large, irregular mass within the adrenal gland. The mass could have areas of necrosis or hemorrhage, contributing to its irregular appearance. 

A pheochromocytoma typically presents as a well-defined, solid mass within the adrenal gland. It might be associated with areas of hemorrhage, leading to a heterogeneous appearance. 

The adrenal glands may appear normal in size or slightly enlarged on a CT scan in case of primary hyperaldosteronism. There might not be distinct masses or nodules in the adrenal glands.

Related Pearl: Variants of Congenital Adrenal Hyperplasia (CAH)

virilized (DHEA is a weak androgen)

Note: In 11β-Hydroxylase deficiency, Aldosterone synthetic capacity is normal and some corticosterone is synthesized from progesterone by intact aldosterone synthase enzyme. Thus, it is unusual for patients to manifest signs of adrenal insufficiency.

questions.text: In the sagittal section of the brain given below the colored area represents the paracentral lobule. Which of the following structures are affected in a lesion to this area?
questions.solution:
The area marked in the picture is the paracentral lobule. The structures affected in a lesion to this area are the perineum and leg.

The paracentral lobule is supplied by the A2 segment of the anterior cerebral artery. Lesions in the paracentral lobule lead to :

  • Weakness and loss of sensation in the contralateral lower limb (paraplegia).
  • Urinary incontinence
  • Fecal incontinence

questions.text: The best way to plot trends in the incidence of diarrheal disease in a given area is by?
questions.solution:
Line graphs or line diagrams are the best way to plot trends in the incidence of a disease in a given area.

Related Pearl: Graphical Representation of Data

1. Histogram

  • A histogram, by definition, is a graphical representation of frequency distribution that contains rectangles and shows the underlying frequency of a set of continuous, quantitative data.
  • The X or horizontal axis is called the abscissa which usually has the group scores or class intervals of the variables/data and the Y or vertical axis is called the ordinate which usually shows the frequencies at which these variables appear.
  • The following is a histogram of cholesterol levels from the Framingham Heart Study.

2. Bar Chart

  • It is also called a bar graph.
  • It is used mainly for nominal or ordinal scale data as they are not quantitative and usually qualitative.
  • The difference between a bar graph and a histogram is that the rectangles are separated by spaces representing data that forms discrete categories instead of continuous groups.
  • Bar graphs can be simple, multiple or component bar graphs.

3. Pie Charts

  • Pie charts are also used for nominal or ordinal data.
  • The categorical data are represented as segments of a circle.

4. Frequency polygons

  • Frequency polygons are used for mainly ratio and interval scale data.
  • In a frequency polygon, the mid-points of each class interval are joined together by straight lines.

5. Ogive

  • A frequency polygon which is drawn to represent cumulative frequency distributions form a typical S-shaped curve which is called an ogive. It referred to as a cumulative frequency diagram.

6. Line chart

  • It is also called a line diagram or line graph.
  • Its best use is to show the trend of events or change over passage of time.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman presents with complaints of greenish frothy vaginal discharge for 1 month and a burning sensation in her vaginal area for the past 5 days. There is no history of fever. Vitals are within normal limits. On speculum examination, you are able to see the below finding. Which of the following kits would you prescribe to this patient?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the image showing  strawberry cervix is suggestive of Trichomoniasis and the green kit containing Tablet Secnidazole 2 gm, to be taken orally as a single dose is recommended in its treatment.

Trichomoniasis: Infection of the female genital tract with the Trichomonas vaginalis protozoan

Trichomoniasis characteristically causes a copious, frothy, offensive yellow-green discharge with vaginal soreness or irritation and urinary frequency. 

The vagina looks red and inflamed. The inflamed cervix looks like a strawberry with punctate hemorrhagic spots.

Management: The CDC recommends one of the following treatment regimens.

  • Metronidazole 2 g orally in a single dose (Standard treatment) or Secnidazole/Tinidazole 2 g orally in a single dose
  • The alternative regimen includes Metronidazole 500 mg orally twice a day for 7 days
  • Metronidazole gel does not reach therapeutic levels in the urethra and perivaginal glands. Because it is less efficacious than oral metronidazole, it is not recommended.

Related Pearl: Vaginal infections

questions.text: A 60-year-old woman who recently received a kidney transplant 2 months ago develops a high fever and severe dyspnea with a dry hacking cough. Chest x-ray reveals bilateral interstitial infiltrates that are diffuse and urine examination shows 'owl-eye' appearance of cells. Which of the following agents is most likely responsible for her condition?
questions.solution:
Cytomegalovirus (CMV) infection is an important cause of morbidity and mortality after allogeneic transplant. Interstitial pneumonia (IP) is the most common manifestation of CMV, in transplant recipients.

The predominant pathogen to infect the renal transplant recipients in the period around 1 to 4 months following the transplantation is cytomegalovirus (CMV).The most common CMV presentation in kidney transplant patients is fever (most common), leukopenia, hepatosplenomegaly, myalgia, and arthralgia. 

CMV infection in immunocompromised hosts:

The infection is contained by host immune response where virus remains latent in leukocytes. Then reactivates when host becomes immunocompromised, and may cause:

  • Retinitis (especially in AIDS patients)
  • Pneumonia (especially in transplant patients)
  • Esophagitis

Diagnosis:

  • Giant cells with “owl’s eye” intranuclear inclusionbodies found in tissues/urine
  • Serology (negative monospot test as compared to EBV mononucleosis)
  • Detection in buffy coat culture (CMV infects WBCs)

Other options:

  • Option a: Adenovirus is associated with conjunctivitis and acute respiratory disease in military recruits, among other diseases.
  • Option c: Although influenza can cause pneumonia, there is no mention of season, and CMV is still the most common cause in transplant patients.
  • Option d: Respiratory syncytial virus is usually seen in children (especially premature infants).

questions.text:
A 60-year-old man presents with fatigue, pallor, weight loss, and heaviness in the left hypochondrium, for the past 2 months. Abdominal palpation reveals splenomegaly. His hemogram and peripheral smear results are given below. What is the most likely diagnosis?

Hemogram:

Hb - 10 gm/dL

WBC count - 1,65,000/cu.mm (Leukocytosis)

Platelet count - 3 lakhs/mm3

Peripheral smear: 

Metamyelocytes - 15%

Promyeloblasts - 30%

Myeloblasts - 45%
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of chronic myelogenous leukemia (CML). 

In this condition, the peripheral smear contains neutrophils and their precursors of various sizes and configurations like band cells, myelocytes, metamyelocytes, and blasts. Hence, the histological picture is described to have garden party or college girl appearance. 

The image given below shows the peripheral smear in CML showing a garden party or college girl appearance.

CML is a myeloproliferative disorder with a peak incidence in the 5th to 6th decades of life. It occurs due to the chimeric BCR-ABL gene.

Clinical features of CML:

  • Hypermetabolism
  • Fatigability
  • Weakness
  • Weight loss and anorexia
  • Extensive extramedullary hematopoiesis causing -
    • Splenomegaly
    • Mild hepatomegaly
    • Lymphadenopathy

Hematological findings include:

  • Mild-to-moderate anemia 
  • Leukocytosis
  • Platelets - usually increased
  • DLC shows predominantly neutrophils, band forms, metamyelocytes, myelocytes, eosinophils, and basophils and blasts (>10%)

questions.text: Hypokalemia is seen in all of the following conditions, except?
questions.solution:
RTA 4 (hyperkalemic renal tubular acidosis) is associated with aldosterone deficiency or resistance, leading to impaired potassium excretion, leading to hyperkalemia and metabolic acidosis.

RTA refers to a group of disorders in which there is impaired tubular transport of H+ and/or HCO3- despite relatively well-preserved renal function. There are 4 types:

  • Type I - impaired H+ secretion (distal), leading to decreased HCO3- production
  • Type II - impaired HCO3- reabsorption (proximal)
  • Type III - carbonic anhydrase deficiency causing defects in the transport of both H+ and HCO3- (mixed)
  • Type IV - hypoaldosteronism (hyperkalemic)

The overall deficiency of HCO3- in all the types is compensated by Cl- secretion. Hence, the serum anion gap remains normal.

Other options:

  • RTA 1 (Distal Renal Tubular Acidosis): This condition is characterized by impaired acid secretion in the distal renal tubules, leading to metabolic acidosis. Hypokalemia can occur due to the compensatory secretion of potassium to maintain electroneutrality. 

  • RTA 2 (Proximal Renal Tubular Acidosis): This condition involves impaired bicarbonate reabsorption in the proximal tubules, leading to metabolic acidosis. Hypokalemia can occur due to urinary losses of potassium.

  • Ureterosigmoidostomy: Ureterosigmoidostomy is a surgical procedure that involves connecting one or both ureters to the sigmoid colon. This procedure can lead to significant potassium and bicarbonate loss in the colon, which may result in hypokalemia and metabolic acidosis.

questions.text: In controlled tipping, the amount of land required for the trench method to be practiced for a population of 10,000 is:
questions.solution:
In controlled tipping, one acre of land is required by trench method to be practiced for a population of 10,000.

It is also known as sanitary landfill. It is the most satisfactory method of refuse disposal where suitable land is available. In this method waste material is placed in a trench or other prepared area. Then it is adequately compacted and covered with earth at the end of the day.

Methods used in this are:

  • Trench method: Done in places where level ground is available
  • Ramp method: Well suited where the terrain is moderately sloping
  • Area method: Used for filling land depressions, disused quarries and clay pits

questions.text: A 5-year-old child is brought to you with complaints of 18 episodes of loose stools in the last 24 hours and vomiting twice in the last 4 hours. The child is irritable but drinking fluids. The optimal therapy for this child is______

choices.text: Intravenous fluid initially for 4 hours followed by oral fluids

questions.solution:
Oral rehydration therapy is the first line of treatment used in treating acute diarrheas due to all aetiologies, in all age groups, and in all countries and the recommended fluid is ORS.

Recommended formulation: Reduced osmolarity ORS solution, which has a reduced concentration of sodium (75 mmol/liter) and glucose (75 mmol/liter) helps in reducing the adverse effect of hypertonicity on net fluid absorption.

Related Pearl: Symptoms associated with different levels of dehydration

Symptoms No or minimal dehydration Mild to moderate dehydration Severe dehydration
Loss of body weight <3% 3–9% >9%
Mental status Well; alert Fatigued or irritable Lethargic or unconscious
Thirst Drinks normally Thirsty; eager to drink Drinks poorly
Heart rate Normal Normal to increased Tachycardia
Quality of pulse Normal Normal to decreased Weak, thready or impalpable
Skin turgor test Instant recoil Recoil in <2 sec Recoil in >2 sec
Capillary refill Normal Prolonged Prolonged

Related Pearl: Treatment of dehydration based on severity

Plan A: For no dehydration or minimal dehydration. ORS is administered after each loose stool.

Age Amount 
<2 years 50–100 mL
2-10 years 100–200 mL
>10 years As much fluid as they want

Plan B: For moderate dehydration.

The amount of oral rehydration solution (ORS) to be given is 75 mL/kg body weight (wt × 75).

Plan C: Severe dehydration

Age First, give 30 mL/kg in Followed by 70 mL/kg in Total 100 mL/kg in
Infants (under 12 months) 1 hr 5 hrs  6 hrs
Older 30 min 2½ hrs  3 hrs

Note: Ringer lactate (ideal) or normal saline is used as intravenous fluids.

questions.text: A 30-year-old lactating mother presents with pain in her left breast and fever. On examination of the affected side, there is localized erythema, warmth, point tenderness, fluctuation test is positive. There is mild axillary lymphadenopathy on the affected side and contralateral breast is normal. What is the management plan for this patient?

choices.text: Aspiration under USG guidance and antibiotics and repeated aspiration as necessary
Punch biopsy under ultrasound guidance followed by a course of IV antibiotics

questions.solution:
The given case scenario points towards a diagnosis of breast abscess. The latest guidelines for the management of breast abscess specify that multiple aspirations under antibiotic cover should be attempted before an incision and drainage is done. This often allows resolution without the need for an incision scar and also allows the patient to continue breastfeeding.

Breast abscess is a sequelae of untreated bacterial mastitis which occurs due to the growth of staphylococcus or streptococcus due to breast milk stasis.

Signs and symptoms: 

  • Fever and malaise
  • Localized pain and tenderness 
  • Redness and swelling of the affected breast
  • Fluctuation test positive due to pus in the abscess. It is a late sign.

The initial treatment should involve providing pain relief with analgesics. The abscess should then be localized preferably under USG guidance and percutaneous aspiration carried out. The pus should be sent for microbiological examination to find the organism and antibiotic sensitivity. Repeated aspirations may be carried out under antibiotics cover if needed.

In some conditions mentioned below, the breast abscess may be unresponsive to repeated aspirations and antibiotic cover. In such cases, incision and drainage is performed. The conditions include:

  • Presence of thick pus
  • Bacteria resistant to antibiotics
  • If just superficial part has been aspirated in the presence of a multiloculated abscess
  • A non-healing breast abscess due to tuberculosis of breast or Inflammatory carcinoma of the breast, or an immunocompromised host.

The below table summarises likely features to differentiate Bacterial mastitis from a Breast abscess

  Bacterial mastitis Breast abscess
Condition Localized inflammation
due to ascending infection 
or infection due to milk stasis 		 Occurs as a complication of mastitis
Pus formation
Symptoms Dull pain Throbbing pain
Signs (if any) Tenderness
Erythema		 Point tenderness
Erythema
Induration of skin(if chronic)
Lymphadenopathy
Fluctuation test +ve
Management Analgesics
Antibiotics		 Analgesic
Aspiration of Pus
Antibiotics

 

Image (above) shows mastitis of the breast

questions.text: Tetralogy of Fallot is most commonly associated with which of the following:
questions.solution:
Tetralogy of Fallot is most commonly associated with Downs syndrome among the given options.

Children with tetralogy of Fallot are more likely to have chromosome disorders, such as Down syndrome, Alagille syndrome, and DiGeorge syndrome (a condition that causes heart defects, low calcium levels, and poor immune function).

Tetralogy of Fallot: It is the most common cyanotic congenital heart disease.

  • The primary defect is an anterior deviation of the infundibular septum (the muscular septum that separates the aortic and pulmonary outflows).
  • The primary defect gives rise to the 4 anatomical components of TOF which are:
  • Ventricular septal defect (VSD) ( NOT ASD)
  • Obstruction to right ventricular outflow - Pulmonic stenosis (PS)
  • Right ventricular hypertrophy (RVH)
  • Overriding (or dextroposition) of the aorta
  • Obstruction to pulmonary arterial blood flow is usually at both the right ventricular infundibulum (subpulmonic area) and the pulmonary valve.
  • The degree of pulmonary outflow obstruction determines the degree of the patient’s cyanosis and the age of first presentation.

The heart is typically enlarged and is classically “boot-shaped” due to marked right ventricular hypertrophy.

questions.text:
Elective splenectomy is preferred in which of the following conditions?

G6PD deficiency- Glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase deficiency
questions.solution:
Elective splenectomy is done in case of hereditary spherocytosis.

Hereditary spherocytosis is a type of hereditary hemolytic anemia that is passed down in an autosomal dominant pattern. Mutations of the red blood cell surface proteins spectrin and ankyrin can result in unstable cell membranes, leading to hemolysis.

This disorder can present at a young age with severe jaundice and fatigue. The unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia predisposes the patient to develop gallstones.

Laboratory findings include normocytic anemia with unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia. The peripheral smear will show large spherical red blood cells without central pallor. The diagnosis can be confirmed by the acid glycerol lysis test and the eosin-5′-maleimide (EMA)–binding test. 

There is no specific treatment available besides splenectomy. However, due to the possible adverse effects, it is only indicated in severe cases and after the child attains puberty in moderate cases. It should be followed up with the appropriate antibiotic and vaccine prophylaxis.

Other options:

Option (A): Glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase deficiency is a type of inherited hemolytic anemia. It is associated with exacerbations after consuming anti-malarial drugs and in periods of oxidative stress. The peripheral smear shows characteristic "bite cells". In G6PD deficiency, uncontrolled oxidative stress causes hemoglobin to denature and form Heinz bodies. G6PD deficiency is largely preventable by avoiding exposure to triggering factors.

Option (B): Paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria is a hemolytic disorder that also presents with pancytopenia and a tendency to form venous thrombi. It occurs due to defective GPI anchors on the red blood cell surface which are normally used to anchor CD 59 (cell-protective proteins) to the surface. These patients can present with episodes of dark brown urine in the morning, anemia, pancytopenia, and recurrent abdominal pain due to thrombosis of abdominal veins. 

Bone marrow transplantation is done for the treatment. Recently humanized monoclonal antibody eculizumab is used.

Option (D): Hairy cell leukemia is a distinctive B cell neoplasm, that predominantly affects middle-aged males. Tartrate-resistant acid phosphatase is the cytochemical stain characteristically shown by leukemic hairy cells. Patients commonly present with massive splenomegaly due to infiltration of the leukemic cells. Pancytopenia due to marrow involvement can also be seen. These tumors respond well to chemotherapy and BRAF (B-type Raf proto-oncogene) inhibitors, and they have an excellent prognosis.

questions.text: What is the needle shown in the picture ?
questions.solution:
This is the image of a Tuohy needle that is used to provide epidural anesthesia. It can be recognized by its curved (Huber) tip and the markings made at 1 cm intervals along its length.

Other options: 

Options A and B: The image below shows spinal needles are long thin needles that are classified based on their tip into: 

  • Cutting needles: Quincke-Babcock, Pitkin
  • Pencil tip needles: Whitacre and Sprotte

Option D: The instrument below is the Quincke Needle used in spinal anesthesia.

questions.text: An elderly male with a history of chronic smoking is diagnosed with squamous cell carcinoma of the lower lip stage. Further investigations revealed that the lymph nodes are not involved. What is the treatment of choice in this patient?

choices.text: Wide local excision with negative margins
Wide local excision with frozen borders

questions.solution:
This pateint has an early stage squamous cell carcinoma. Wide local excision with negative margins is the preferred treatment for this type of cancer.

Lip cancer most commonly occurs in men from 50 to 70 years but can be seen in younger patients. Risk factors include sunlight exposure, smoking, and tobacco use. Squamous cell carcinoma is the most common type of lip cancer. But commonly occurring cancer in the upper lip is basal cell carcinoma.

Surgical resection (wide local excision with negative margins) is the preferred treatment modality. The typical lip length is 6 to 7 cm. For defects of <1/3rd of the lip, resection with primary closure is the preferred treatment.

For defects of more than 1/3rd of the lip, require local flaps for reconstruction after resection:

  • Johansen step technique- local flap for large central defects 
  • Lip-switch (Abbe-Estlander) flap- based on the sublabial or superior labial artery. When the defect involves only the commissure, the Estlander flap is used, and the Abbé flap is used for midline defects. Abbe-Estlander Flap is used for mixed defects. The markings of the Abbe-Estlander flap are shown below.
  • Karapandzic flap - circumoral advancement flap. It is a neuromuscular flap that includes the remaining orbicularis oris muscle with its innervation.

In the presence of neck metastasis, neck dissection is indicated. Postoperative radiation is administered to patients with positive margins, lymph node metastases, tumor thickness >4mm, or perineural invasion. If the mandible is involved, mandibulectomy and free flap reconstruction is required.

questions.text: In the anteroposterior diameters of the pelvic inlet, the true conjugate is___

choices.text: the distance from midpoint of sacral promontory to the upper most margin of the symphysis pubis.
the shortest distance between the sacral promontory and the symphysis pubis.
the distance from the lowest margin of the symphysis to the sacral promontory.
the distance from the posterior margin of the sacral promontory to the symphysis pubis.

questions.solution:
The true conjugate is the distance between the midpoint of the sacral promontory to the inner margin of the upper border of the symphysis pubis. 

Anteroposterior diameters of the pelvic inlet:

  • Diagonal conjugate:
    • It is the distance between the lower border of the symphysis pubis to the midpoint on the sacral promontory. 
    • It measures 12 cm (4 ¾")
  • Obstetric conjugate:
    • It is the distance between the midpoint of the sacral promontory to prominent bony projection in the midline on the inner surface of the symphysis pubis.
    • It measures 10 cm (4")
  • Anatomical/true conjugate/conjugate vera:
    • It is the distance between the midpoint of the sacral promontory to the inner margin of the upper border of the symphysis pubis. 
    • It measures 11 cm

questions.text: A 60-year-old female patient presents with complaints of pain and swelling in the left wrist following a fall on an outstretched hand. On examination, dinner fork deformity can be noticed. What is the most likely displacement seen in this patient?

choices.text: Proximal and  ventral displacement of radius
Proximal and dorsal displacement of radius
Proximal and dorsal displacement of ulna
Proximal and ventral displacement of ulna

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of Colles’ fracture in which proximal and dorsal displacement of the radius is most likely seen.

Colle's fracture is common in postmenopausal after a fall on an outstretched hand.

Clinical presentation -
The patient presents with pain, swelling, and deformity of the wrist. Tenderness may be present. The 'dinner fork deformity ' is the prominence on the back of the wrist and depression in the front. It is due to the dorsal angulation of the distal fracture fragment. The radial styloid process comes to lie at the same level or a little higher than the ulnar styloid process.  

 

Displacements(radius) that may be seen in Colles' fracture:

  • Dorsal tilt
  • Dorsal shift
  • Lateral tilt (Radial tilt)
  • Lateral shift (Radial shift)
  • Supination
  • Impaction of fragment
  • Proximal shift

Diagnosis -
Diagnosis is by X-ray.  X-rays show there is a transverse fracture of the radius at the cortico-cancellous junction. A dorsal tilt is the most common.

Management -

  • Undisplaced fracture - immobilization in a below-elbow plaster cast for six weeks
  • Displaced fractures - manipulative reduction followed by immobilization in Colles' cast in palmar flexion, pronation, and ulnar deviation.
  • Comminuted fractures -  transfixed percutaneously using two K-wires

Related Pearl: Named fractures of the upper limb

Colle's fracture: Extra-articular fracture of the distal radius with dorsal angulation of the distal bone fragment.

 

Galeazzi fracture-dislocation: Fracture of the lower third of the radius and subluxation of the distal radio-ulnar joint.

 

Monteggia fracture-dislocation: Fracture of the shaft of the ulna with dislocation of a proximal radio-ulnar joint.

 

Barton’s fracture: Intra-articular fracture of the distal radius.

 

Rolando's fracture: Intra-articular comminuted fracture of the base of the first metacarpal with a T or Y configuration.

 

Smith's fracture: Reverse Colles' fracture. Extra-articular fracture of the distal one-third of the radius with palmar or ventral displacement (Image below).

 

Chauffeur's fracture or the Hutchinson fracture: Fracture of the radial styloid.

Essex–Lopresti lesion: Fracture of the radial head with disruption of the interosseous membrane and distal radial ulnar joint ligaments.

Nightstick fracture: Isolated fracture of radial or ulnar bone.

questions.text: A 25-year-old female patient presented with painless, fleshy, exophytic lesions on the surface of the genitalia. She is 14-weeks pregnant. It is found to be caused by low-risk strains of HPV. Which of the following is the safest and can be used to manage this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of painless exophytic lesions on the genitalia and caused by low-risk HPV strains is suggestive of Anogenital warts. Cryotherapy is the safest management that can be used in pregnant women for treating warts.

Anogenital warts is a genital infection caused by the human papillomavirus(HPV) commonly HPV‐6 and HPV‐11. Transmission of HPV commonly occurs sexually or through the genital lesions of the mother during delivery. Giant warts are called Condyloma acuminata.

The lesions present as soft, pink and flesy warts. These growths may be pedunculated discrete or verrucous and coalesce to form large cauliflower-like growths. It commonly occurs on the glans, corona, and frenulum in men and the posterior fourchette in women. Diagnosis is done by HPV DNA PCR (polymerase chain reaction). 

Management (non-pregnant):

The first-line drugs used in the treatment are podophyllin and imiquimod. Podophyllin is the most commonly used drug for anogenital warts and is used as a local application of podophyllin 25% in alcohol or podophyllin 20% in tincture benzoin or podophyllin cream. Imiquimod is also used as a first-line drug next to podophyllin and is used as a 5% cream applied 3 times per week.

Second-line management includes Cryotherapy, Surgical removal of warts, laser and 80-90% trichloroacetic acid. Fluorouracil 5% and 25% trichloroacetic acid combination causes small warts to fall off by 3-4 days and is also used as a second-line management. Cryotherapy is the safest management that can be used in pregnant women for treating warts.

As imiquimod, podophyllin, and podofilox should not be used during pregnancy, cryotherapy is considered relatively safer.

Interferon therapy can be used for severe extensive warts.

Cryotherapy:

This treatment is physician administered. Dimethyl ether spray, carbon dioxide snow and liquid nitrogen all produce cold thermal damage to the skin.

Liquid nitrogen produces the coldest freeze and is commonly used in practice. It is applied using a cotton wool bud or a cryospray until a rim of iced tissue (seen as a white discoloration) develops around the wart. The freeze is maintained for 5–30 sec depending on the size and site of the wart. Scarring is unlikely with freezing times under 30 secs.

questions.text: Komal, a 2-year-old girl is brought to the clinic with a high fever, cough, red eyes, and rash. Parents say that the rash started on the forehead and behind the ears, then subsequently spread to the neck and body. On examination, a confluent maculopapular rash is noted as shown below. Which of the following is false regarding this child's condition?

choices.text: The period of infectivity is 3 days before and 5 days after the appearance of rash
The most common cause of death is subacute sclerosing panencephalitis

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of measles. The most common cause of death is pneumonia (Hecht's giant cell pneumonia).

Measles (rubeola) is caused by RNA paramyxovirus. The infection is spread via droplets, with a secondary attack rate ≥of 90%. The patients are infectious from 3 days before to 5 days after the appearance of the rash. The rash appears on the 4th day of the fever. It starts from the retro auricular region. Koplik spots and Warthin–Finkeldey giant cells are pathognomonic.

Measles can lead to subacute sclerosing panencephalitis (SSPE) as a late complication.

Measles can be prevented by administering live attenuated, Edmonston–Zagreb strain or combined MMR given at 9 months of age.

Related Pearl: Viral infections associated with rash

Viral infection  Rash characteristics 
Chickenpox Appears 1st day of fever, centripetal, pleomorphic, dewdrops on rose petal appearance
Measles Appears on the 4th day over the face and retroauricular origin
Rubella Rash on day 1 over the face

Erythema infectiosum

 Rash on cheeks (slapped cheek appearance), moves to trunk and extremities
Exanthem subitum Macules or maculopapular rash
Infectious mononucleosis Associated with maculopapular rash

Related Pearl: Skin rashes: 1st to 6th diseases

1st disease

Measles

2nd disease

Scarlet fever

3rd disease

Rubella

4th disease

Duke’s disease

5th disease

Erythema infectiosum

6th disease
