questions.text: There are 30 people at a small camping site. How will they best manage their refuse disposal?
questions.solution:
Burial is suitable for refuse (municipal, nonhazardous solid waste) in small camps.

Other methods of refuse disposal:

  • Dumping: Refuse is dumped into low lying areas by throwing it in open space.
  • Incineration: It is the method of choice of disposal by burning when suitable land is not available.
  • Composting:
    • This is a method of combined disposal of refuse and sludge.
    • Compost has manorial value for soil.
    • It includes 2 methods:
      • Bangalore method - Anaerobic composting
      • Indore method - Aerobic mechanical composting
  • Controlled tipping (sanitary landfill): It is the most satisfactory method of refuse disposal where suitable land is available. The material is placed in a trench or other prepared area, adequately compacted, and covered with earth at the end of the working day. There are three methods under controlled tipping:
    1. The trench method
    2. The ramp method
    3. The area method
  • Manure pits: Commonly used in rural areas in India.

questions.text: Which of the following is used in the management of tumor lysis syndrome?
questions.solution:
Rasburicase - recombinant urate oxidase is used in the management of tumor lysis syndrome(TLS). TLS is associated with hyperuricemia and rasburicase helps in decreasing the levels of uric acid in the blood.

Management of TLS includes:

  • Aggressive hydration
  • Allopurinol
  • Urinary alkalinization with sodium bicarbonate (controversial)
  • Rasburicase - recombinant urate oxidase.

However, rituximab, gemtuzumab, and alemtuzumab are monoclonal antibodies that cause a rapid fall in circulating tumor cells upon infusion and may lead to TLS.

questions.text: A 20-year-old male presented with a 1-week history of yellow skin and sclerae but is otherwise asymptomatic. He gives a history of viral infection 10 days ago which resolved 2 days back. There is a history of a similar episode of icterus 2 years back when the patient had long hours of basketball practice. The current serum bilirubin is 2.4 mg/dL, unconjugated bilirubin is 2.1mg/dl, and conjugated bilirubin is 0.3mg/dl. Serum AST and ALT levels are normal. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Gilbert syndrome is the most likely diagnosis in this patient.

This patient's mild jaundice seen only during a period of stress along with an increase in unconjugated bilirubin and normal AST, and ALT levels strongly point towards a diagnosis of Gilbert syndrome.

Gilbert syndrome is a benign, familial disorder inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern characterized by mild intermittent jaundice usually seen during stress, illnesses, or any other precipitating factors. There is no hemolysis or underlying liver disease. The condition is recognized to arise from a mutation in the promoter region of the UGT1A1 gene, which results in mildly decreased UDP-Glucoronyltransferase production. UDP-Glucoronyltransferase is required for the conjugation of bilirubin.

Precipitating factors in Gilbert syndrome:

  • Dehydration
  • Fasting
  • Menstrual periods
  • Illness
  • Vigorous exercise.

Other options:

Option A: Dubin-Johnson syndrome is a benign autosomal recessive disease that is characterized by chronic conjugated hyperbilirubinemia and conspicuous brown-black melanin-like pigment deposition in the liver. The disease is caused due to mutation in multidrug resistance protein 2 (MRP-2) in hepatocytes, which is required for the transport of non-bile salt organic anions at the canalicular membranes. Liver biopsy shows characteristic deposition of black-colored pigment.

Option B: Crigler-Najjar syndrome is of two types with type 1 having absent/trace UDP-Glucoronyltransferase production and type 2 having <10% of the normal enzyme activity. Hence, type 1 is far more severe and leads to kernicterus and neurological damage in babies. Type 2 may also lead to kernicterus occasionally. Unconjugated bilirubin is elevated. Isolated unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia in a 25-year-old male is less likely to be due to Criggler Najar type 1 syndrome. It is because patients usually die in infancy or early childhood despite the best treatment.

Option D: Rotor syndrome: similar to Dubin-Johnson syndrome but with a milder presentation. Increased conjugated bilirubin levels. Liver biopsy does not show black colored liver

questions.text: Following gastrectomy, the patient is most likely to have which of the following?
questions.solution:
After gastrectomy, the patient is likely to have vitamin B12 deficiency.

Vitamin B12 is absorbed in the ileum. Vitamin B12 binds to intrinsic factor, a protein secreted by the parietal cells of the stomach, and the complex is absorbed across the ileal mucosa. Hence after gastrectomy IF-B12 complex is not formed and there is impaired absorption of vitamin B12.

Folic acid is absorbed mainly in Jejunum.

Gastric ulcer does not occur following gastrectomy.

Constipation is not common after gastrectomy. 

Related Pearl: Major Sites of Absorption of Hematopoietic Factors

  • Duodenum + upper jejunum: Iron
  • Jejunum: Folate
  • Terminal Ileum: Vitamin B12

Mnemonic - Dude Is Just Feeling Ill Bro

Related Pearl: Causes of Megaloblastic Anemia

Vitamin B12 Deficiency causes:

  • Decreased Intake
    • Inadequate diet
    • Vegetarianism
  • Impaired Absorption
    • Intrinsic factor deficiency
    • Pernicious anemia
    • Gastrectomy
    • Malabsorption states
    • Diffuse intestinal disease (e.g., lymphoma, systemic sclerosis)
    • Ileal resection
    • Ileitis
  • Competitive parasitic uptake
    • Fish tapeworm infestation
    • Bacterial overgrowth in blind loops and diverticula of bowel

Folic Acid Deficiency causes:

  • Decreased Intake
    • Inadequate diet
    • Alcoholism
    • Infancy
  • Impaired Absorption
    • Malabsorption states
    • Intrinsic intestinal disease
    • Anticonvulsants
    • Oral contraceptives
  • Increased Loss
    • Hemodialysis
  • Increased Requirement
    • Pregnancy, infancy
    • Disseminated cancer
    • Markedly increased hematopoiesis
  • Impaired Utilization
    • Folic acid antagonists
    • Unresponsive to vitamin B12 or folic acid therapy
    • Metabolic inhibitors of DNA synthesis and/or folate metabolism

questions.text: A  male patient presented with a sudden onset tearing type of chest pain radiating to the back, shortness of breath, and nausea. CT chest image is given.What is the most appropriate next step in the management of this patient?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario of a male patient with tearing chest pain is suggestive of aortic dissection. Beta-blockers such as Labetalol should be given to all patients with aortic dissection and surgical repair is done after stabilizing the patient. So, option A is the correct answer.

Aortic dissection occurs when a tear or flap occurs in the intima or inner media of the aorta resulting in progressive separation of the layers of the aorta.

Risk factors for aortic dissection are:

  • Smoking
  • Hypertension
  • Atherosclerosis 
  • Hypercholesterolemia
  • Aortopathy, aortitis, bicuspid aortic valve, or preexisting medial degenerative disease.
  • Aortic injury during cardiac catheterization, surgery, endovascular aortic repair (Iatrogenic) 
  • Cocaine or amphetamine abuse 
 

The most typical presentation of aortic dissection is tearing chest pain. Other clinical features include dyspnea, nausea, vomiting, murmurs due to aortic valvular insufficiency, and shock. A discrepancy between the extremities in pulse, blood pressure, or both is the classic physical finding in patients with aortic dissection.

The dissection can extend distally down the aorta to involve the:

  • Renal arteries (renal pain and renal failure)
  • Mesenteric arteries (abdominal pain and bowel ischemia)
  • Spinal arteries (paraplegia, incontinence)
  • Iliofemoral arteries (leg pain, pallor, loss or reduced pulses, and limb ischemia).

The dissection may track proximally to involve the:

  • Head and neck vessels (syncope and focal neurological deficits)
  • Coronary vessels (cardiac ischemia, cardiac tamponade)
  • Aortic root (aortic regurgitation)

Delays in diagnosis and treatment of aortic dissection can have disastrous consequences.

Investigations in aortic dissection:

  • Transesophageal echocardiography can be done at the bedside in patients who are hemodynamically unstable; it can give information about flow in the true and false lumen and shows very high sensitivity for confirmation of the aortic dissection.
  • Currently, a CT scan is the initial best investigation for the diagnosis of aortic dissection in the hemodynamically stable patent. Additionally, it tells about the segments involved and the acuity, and complications of the dissection. The classic feature seen in the CT scan is a double-lumen aorta.

Treatment:

The initial management of patients diagnosed with aortic dissection is beta-blocker medication to control hypertension, along with pain management. The preferred beta-blocker drug is esmolol, a cardio-selective beta blocker. These reduce cardiac contractility and blood pressure. It can be used in patients with bronchospastic disorders. Labetalol, a non-selective beta blocker decreases systemic vascular resistance without impairing the cardiac output. Enalapril and other angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitors can be used if there is decreased renal perfusion.

 Calcium channel blockers like diltiazem may be used IV if beta-blockers cannot be employed.

Once hypertension is controlled, definitive surgical repair of aortic dissection is done. Nitroprusside, a direct vasodilator is given after adequate beta-blockade is achieved. Definitive management is by surgical repair.

Types: 

  • Stanford type A (DeBakey types I and II) requires surgical intervention once the patient's blood pressure is stabilized.
  • Stanford type B (DeBakey type III) is best managed by antihypertensive drugs. Surgical intervention is indicated in complicated cases if the pain increases (signaling impending rupture) or when there is evidence of malperfusion of organs or neurological symptoms.

questions.text: What is the probable diagnosis of the ECG given below?
questions.solution:
The hallmark of this patient's ECG is the Osborn J wave.

Hypothermia is defined as core body temperature being less than 95°F.

In the initial stages of hypothermia, as a reaction to the general stress, there is sinus tachycardia. As the temperature drops below 90°F, there is sinus bradycardia associated with prolongation of the PR interval, QRS complex, and QT interval progressively.

With temperature approaching 86°F, atrial ectopic activity is often noted and can progress to atrial fibrillation. It is at this level of hypothermia that many patients have Osborn waves that consist of an extra deflection at the end of the QRS complex. J waves occur when a heterogeneous distribution of potassium current enhances the activity of a transient outward potassium current in the heart, caused by low temperatures.

Osborn waves, also known as J waves, camel-hump waves, or hypothermic waves, are best seen in the inferior and lateral precordial leads. They become more prominent as the body temperature drops, and they regress gradually with rewarming.

A progressive widening of the QRS complex occurs when the temperature falls below 86°F, which is associated with an increased risk of ventricular fibrillation and asystole occurs when the temperature drops to about 60°F.

Other options:

  • Hyperkalemia: Tall, tented T waves are seen in hyperkalemia.
  • Hypokalemia: U waves are seen in hypokalemia.
  • Hypocalcemia: Prolonged QTc interval, occasional T wave inversion.

questions.text: Identify the investigation shown below which is the investigation of choice in distal small bowel tumours.
questions.solution:
Enteroclysis, which is the investigation of choice in patients with small bowel tumors.

Enteroclysis is a barium study in which the contrast agent is put directly into the duodenum through a nasogastric tube.

Continued infusion of 500 to 1000 mL of thin barium sulfate and methylcellulose suspension is done and then viewed continuously with the use of either fluoroscopy or radiographs taken at frequent intervals. This technique is a double-contrast procedure that allows detailed imaging of the entire small intestine.

Enteroclysis has a sensitivity of over 90% in the detection of small bowel tumors and is the investigation of choice, particularly for tumors located in the distal small bowel.

Advantages of enteroclysis:

  • The contrast is administered at a controlled rate directly in the small bowel, bypassing the regulatory action of the pylorus.
  • The entire small bowel is demonstrated in a distended state, allowing better diagnosis. As a result of the dilatation, the following can be visualized:
    • Mild strictures
    • Small sinus tracts and fistulas
    • Minimal extrinsic compressions
    • Skip lesions
    • Proximal and distal extent of diffuse diseases.
  • The examination can be completed in 15–30 minutes, thus reducing patient waiting time.

Related Pearl: Barium Studies

Barium swallow: Used to assess the pharynx, esophagus, and stomach.

The image below is a barium swallow showing eosinophilic esophagitis and associated stricture:

Barium meal: Used to assess stomach and duodenum.

Barium meal followthrough: Used to assess the small intestine

Barium enema: Used to assess the large intestine

questions.text: A patient presented with lesions as shown in the image below and later developed arthritis also.  What is the treatment of choice for a patient who presented with the following findings?
questions.solution:
The patient has right knee effusion, dactylitis of multiple digits, sharply demarcated red papulosquamous lesions on both knees all of which point towards a diagnosis of psoriatic arthritis. 

Methotrexate and apremilast are the first-line drugs for the treatment of moderate to severe psoriasis associated with psoriatic arthritis.

Features of psoriatic arthritis are :

  • Asymmetrical oligoarthritis
  • associated with nail pitting/ onycholysis, or
  • dactylitis, enthesitis 
  • Inflammation is prominent in the distal interphalangeal joints 
  • There is dactylitis with pronounced telescoping.
  • Nail dystrophy (hyperkeratosis and onycholysis) affects each of the finger
  • Axial involvement may occur

Radiological features:

  • Pencil-in-cup deformity of DIP joint
  • marginal erosions with adjacent bony proliferation "whiskering"
  • small joint ankylosis
  • Ray distribution of lesions

Note :

Indications for methotrexate (inflammatory conditions) include:

  • Rheumatoid arthritis
  • Psoriasis 
  • Psoriatic arthritis
  • Ankylosing spondylitis
  • Polymyositis
  • Dermatomyositis
  • Wegener’s granulomatosis
  • Giant cell arteritis 
  • Systemic lupus erythematosus
  • Other systemic vasculitis
  • Graft versus host disease associated with organ transplantation.

Related Pearl: Drug of choice for different types of psoriasis

Type Drug of choice
Chronic Plaque Psoriasis Methotrexate
Erythrodermic Psoriasis Methotrexate 
Psoriatic Arthritis Methotrexate / Apremilast
Pustular Psoriasis Acitretin
Psoriasis in HIV patients Acitretin
Impetigo Herpetiformis

1. Systemic Corticosteroids

2. Cyclosporine
Erythrodermic Psoriasis in Pregnancy Systemic Corticosteroids

questions.text: A 49-year-old man presented to the OPD with complaints of a gradually progressive swelling over his abdomen for 1.5 years. He has a history of penetrating stab injury at the same site. On examination, the swelling was >12 cm and was partially reducible with a palpable cough impulse. Which of the following is the best way to manage this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
Incisional hernias are repaired by fascial closure augmented with a mesh. 
 
Incisional hernia refers to an abdominal wall hernia at the site of a previous surgical incision. It is a type of ventral hernia. Incisional hernias are usually asymptomatic, but can occasionally present with pain. Strangulation and bowel obstruction is rare due to the large neck of the defect. In general, incisional hernias are repaired by fascial closure augmented with a mesh. There are different options for mesh placement:
  • Onlay (above the anterior fascia, over the defect)
  • Inlay (between the fascial edges without overlap)
  • Sublay (below the fascial components) - this includes retrorectus, preperitoneal, and intraperitoneal (IPOM) mesh placements 

Primary suture repair using Mayo’s technique is reserved only for very small hernias with < 2cm defect. This involves closing the fascial edges with a 2 cm overlap using an interrupted suture and then reinforcing it with a continuous running suture (double-breasting).

questions.text: A mother brought her 16-year-old daughter to the hospital with the complaints of primary amenorrhea. On evaluation axillary and pubic hair were present and other secondary sexual characteristics normal.LH and FSH levels are normal and USG showed absence of uterus.What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The child does not have any uterus but has normal sex hormones and normal secondary sexual characteristics suggesting it is a case of MRKH( Mayer-Rokitansky-Kuster-Hauser).

A similar presentation is seen in Androgen insensitivity but LH and FSH levels would be abnormal in that case.

 

Presentation Mullarian agenesis  Androgen insensitivity /Testicular feminization syndrome 
Inheritance pattren Sporaidic  X-linked recessive
Karyotype  46, XX 46, XY
Breast development  Yes  Yes
Axillary and pubic hair Yes No
Uterus Absent Absent
Gonad Ovary Testis (Intraabdominal)
Testosterone  Female levels Male levels
Associated anomoly Yes  No

 

Turner's syndrome is a chromosomal abnormality with partial or complete monosomy of the X chromosome (45+XO). In Turner's syndrome, gonadal dysgenesis causes primary ovarian failure that is hypogonadism. The clinical picture of amenorrhea, short stature, webbed neck, low hairline at the back of the neck, widely spaced nipples, and lack of secondary sexual characteristics is seen in Turner's syndrome.

Sweyer syndrome or pure gonadal dysgenesis occurs as a result of a mutation in the SRY gene. This leads to underdeveloped, dysgenetic gonads that fail to produce androgens or anti-Mullerian hormone (AMH). The following features are seen: 

  • Normal prepubertal female phenotype- Absent or poorly developed secondary sexual characteristics.
  • Normal Müllerian system development due to the absence of AMH. (Uterus and cervix present)
  • Female external genitalia
  • Presence of dysgenetic testes that cannot produce AMH or sex hormones. They have a risk of malignant transformation.

As there is gonadal dysgenesis in a patient with 46 XY karyotype, they are actually determined to be males and are a type of male pseudohermaphrodite. They present with primary amenorrhoea, absence of secondary sex characters, and female external genitalia.

Related Pearl: Disorders of Sexual Development

Note: 

Turner's syndrome have different chromosomal anomalies:

  • 45 XO which is seen in 40-50% patients 
  • 45 X mosaicism (eg, 45,X/46,XX or 45,X/47,XXX, or 45,X mosaics with the X chromosome anomalies)

questions.text: A 60-year-old bedridden patient develops acute onset dyspnea and chest pain. A CT pulmonary angiography was done. Which of the following investigations is considered the investigation of choice in this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
In a bedridden patient presenting with sudden onset dyspnea and chest pain, there is a concern for possible pulmonary embolism (PE). Deep vein thrombosis (DVT) can be suspected in this patient because of his bedridden status. Duplex ultrasound is the investigation of choice for diagnosis of DVT (Filling defects in flow and lack of compressibility indicate the presence of a thrombosis)

DVT of the leg is complicated by the immediate risk of pulmonary embolus and sudden death. Patients are at risk of developing a post-thrombotic limb and venous ulceration. 

Virchow's Triad: three factors important in the development of venous thrombosis. 

  • Endothelial injury (vascular Injury)
  • Hypercoagulability of blood
  • Stasia or turbulence of blood flow

The most important predisposing factor is hospital admissions for the treatment of a medical or surgical condition

Diagnosis:

  • D-dimer measurement: If normal, no indication for further investigation but if raised, a duplex ultrasound examination of the deep veins should be performed.
  • Duplex ultrasound is the investigation of choice for diagnosis of DVT (Filling defects in flow and lack of compressibility indicate the presence of a thrombosis)
  • Ascending venography shows thrombus as a filling defect, which is now rarely required

Treatment

  • Rest, elevation of the limb, and bandaging the entire limb with a crepe bandage.
  • Anticoagulants: Heparin/low molecular weight heparin, warfarin, phenindione.
  • Palma operation
  • May-Husni operation

questions.text: An elderly obese man was brought to casualty with complaints of severe chest pain for the last two hours. He has also had profuse sweating, pain in the left arm, nausea, and one episode of vomiting.  On examination, his pulse rate is 58 per minute and blood pressure is 90/60 mm of Hg. ECG was done and it shows the following finding. Cardiac biomarker showed elevated troponin levels. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given presentation of chest pain, and elevated biomarkers depict that the patient has a myocardial infarction. In the ECG, there is elevation of ST-segments in leads II, III, aVF, with reciprocal change in lead aVL. This depicts inferior wall MI. It mainly occurs due to blockage of the posterior descending branch of the right coronary artery.

The table below gives localization of MI and probable vessel involved based on ECG findings.

Location of MI Leads Affected Vessel Involved ECG Changes
Anterior wall V2 to V4 Left Anterior Descending artery (LAD)
– Diagonal branch
  • Poor R-wave progression
  • ST-segment elevation
  • T-wave inversion
Septal wall V1 and V2 Left Anterior Descending artery (LAD)
– Septal branch
  • R-wave disappears
  • ST-segment rises
  • T-wave inverts
Lateral wall I, aVL, V5, V6 Left Coronary Artery (LCA)
– Circumflex branch
  • ST-segment elevation
Inferior wall II, III, aVF Right Coronary Artery (RCA)
– Posterior descending branch
  • T-wave inversion
  • ST-segment elevation
Posterior wall V7 to V9 Left Coronary Artery (LCA)
– Circumflex branch

 

Right Coronary Artery (RCA)
– Posterior descending branch
  • Tall R waves
  • ST-segment depression
  • Upright T waves

Patients with pericarditis also present with severe chest pain and ST-segment elevations. However, this ST-segment elevation has upward concavity with depression of PR segment.

Below image- ECG in pericarditis

Related Pearl: Localisation of MI based on ST elevations in different leads

Extensive anterior - I, aVL, V1-V6

Lateral - I, aVL

Inferior - II, III, aVF

Anteroseptal - V1-V4

Anterolateral - I, aVL, V3-V6

Posterior - ST depression and tall R in V1-V4

questions.text: A patient diagnosed with renal cell carcinoma is found to have a tumor that is 10 cm in size, situated at the lower pole of the kidney with negative regional lymph nodes. Which of the following is the preferred management for this patient?
questions.solution:
A tumor that is 10 cm in size, confined to the kidney with negative metastasis is classified as T2bN0M0. A tumor greater than 7 cm is managed by radical nephrectomy. RCC is a radio and chemoresistant tumor.

Radical Nephrectomy :

  • Classic radical nephrectomy consists of the removal of the kidney, perirenal fat, adrenal gland, and regional lymph nodes.
  • In patients with a tumor <5 cm in size, located at the inferior pole, the adrenal gland can be spared. 
  • Regional lymph node dissection is done for patients with clinically positive nodes detected by CT or during surgery.

Partial nephrectomy :

  • For tumors less than or equal to 4 cm in size and limited to the kidney (T1a), partial nephrectomy is performed.
  • Partial nephrectomy is also increasingly being performed in tumors >4cm in size but less than or equal to 7 cm, and limited to the kidney (T1b). If partial nephrectomy is not feasible in T1b tumors, then a radical nephrectomy is done.
  • Other indications for partial nephrectomy are bilateral renal cell carcinoma and carcinoma affecting a solitary functioning kidney.

Radical nephrectomy is performed in patients with large tumors and for patients in whom a partial nephrectomy is not technically feasible.

 

TNM staging for renal cell carcinoma:

T: Primary tumor

T1: Limited to the kidney, <7 cm

T1a: Tumor confined to the kidney,<4 cm

T1b: Tumor confined to the kidney, >4 cm, but <7 cm

T2: Limited to the kidney, >7 cm

T2a: Tumor confined to the kidney, >7 cm but < 10 cm

T2b: Tumor confined to the kidney, >10 cm

T3: Tumor extension into major veins or perinephric tissues, but not into the ipsilateral adrenal gland or beyond Gerota's fascia

T3a: Tumor grossly extends into the renal vein or its segmental (muscle-containing) branches, or tumor invades perirenal and/or renal sinus fat but not beyond Gerota's fascia

T3b: Spread to infra-diaphragmatic IVC

T3c: Spread to supra-diaphragmatic IVC or invades the wall of the IVC
T4: Involves ipsilateral adrenal gland or invades beyond Gerota's fascia

 

 

 

N: Regional Lymph Nodes
N0: No nodal involvementN1: Metastatic involvement of regional lymph node(s)
M: Metastasis
M0: No distant metastasesM1: Distant metastases
Stage groupings
Stage I: T1 N0 M0Stage II: T2 N0 M0Stage III: T3 or N1 with M0Stage IV: T4 or M1

questions.text: A 55 year old man with a history of uncontrolled diabetes mellitus came to OPD with following wound . What is the diagnosis based on the image below?
questions.solution:
The image below shows a case of a carbuncle on the back of the head which is a common location.

Carbuncle:

  • A carbuncle is a deep infection of a group of contiguous follicles with S. aureus.
  • Intense inflammatory changes in the surrounding and underlying connective tissues, including the subcutaneous fat.
  • Larger than abscesses/boils as they represent a cluster of coalescing boils connected under the skin surface.
  • Risk factors include diabetes, malnutrition, cardiac failure, drug addiction, obesity and prolonged steroid therapy.
  • Smooth painful hard red lump, dome‐shaped and increases in size to reach a diameter of 3–10 cm or more.
  • Suppuration begins after some 5–7 days, and pus is discharged from the multiple follicular orifices.
  • Necrosis of the intervening skin leaves a yellow slough surmounting a crateriform nodule and can even develop into a deep ulcer with a purulent floor.
  • Most commonly on the back of the neck, the shoulders or the hips and thighs.
  • Constitutional symptoms like fever, malaise and prostration can be present if severe.
  • In the frail and ill, death may occur from toxaemia or from metastatic infection while in favourable cases lesions they usually heal with scarring.
  • Treatment includes antibiotics, incision and drainage or saucerization under local anaesthetic to help remove pus and necrotic tissue and expedite healing.

Option A: Botryomycosis presents as multiple indurated draining sinuses mimicking actinomycosis.

Option B: Ecthyma is a pyogenic infection of the skin characterized by the formation of adherent crusts, beneath which ulceration occurs. It most commonly results from mixed infection of group A streptococci > staphylococci and causes a deeper infection than impetigo. The buttocks, thighs, and legs are most commonly affected.

Option C: In erysipelas, well-defined raised margin erythematous lesions are seen.

questions.text: A 40-year-old patient comes to the OPD with a history significant for a mood disorder. Her moods can be charted as done in the image given below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given image showing 4 episodes of depression and 2 episodes of mania within 1 year, points towards a diagnosis of rapid cycling bipolar disorder. 

It is diagnosed when the patient has 4 or more episodes of depression and/or mania or hypomania within one year. There must be less than 2 weeks of normalcy between the episodes or an immediate shift between the symptoms with no intervening normal mood.

Risk factors:

  • Female patients
  • Hypothyroidism
  • Alcoholism or substance abuse
  • Antidepressants (if used without mood stabilizers)
  • Cyclothymia
  • Bipolar II disorder

The drug of choice for rapid cycling disorder is valproate. 

Note: If the phases of mania and depression alternate very rapidly in a matter of hours or days then the condition is known as ultra-rapid cycling disorder.

questions.text: A woman with a history of infertility is on treatment with HMG. She presented with the following finding in the USG. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the USG findings are suggestive of ovarian hyperstimulation syndrome.

Ovarian hyperstimulation syndrome is characterized by mul­tiple ovarian follicular cysts accompanied by increased capillary permeability. It most often is a complication of ovulation­ induction therapy for infertility, although it may rarely develop in an otherwise normal pregnancy. It has also been reported with a partial molar pregnancy. Its etiopatho­genesis is thought to involve the stimulation of vascular endo­thelial growth factor (VEGF) expression in granulosa-lutein cells by hCG.

Human menopausal gonadotropin (HMG) is a medication that is composed of FSH and LH. It is used to stimulate the release of ova in women who do not ovulate spontaneously. It can lead to ovarian hyperstimulation syndrome.

Related Pearl: Management of female infertility for different causes are as follows

Etiology Investigations Management  
Tubal cause
  • Hysterosalpingography or sonosalpingography
  • Falloscopy
  • Salpingography
  • Laparoscopic chemotubation
  • Laparoscopic adhesiolysis
  • Tuboplasty
  • Hysteroscopic cannulation and balloonplasty
  • If all the above procedures fail or not feasible go for IVF/GIFT 
Ovulation related           
  • Ovulation monitoring by ultrasound (BBT, BBI) And  Endometrial Biopsy for tuberculosis done    
  • If the above steps are abnormal, do a hormonal study
  • FSH, LH, Prolactin
  • E2, P level
  • Thyroid and diabetes
  • Clomiphene and letrozole
  • If it fails, give FSH, LH, GnRH
  • Check for a response; if there is no response do IVF Donor egg.
  • If all the above measures fail, the final option is to adopt  
Other causes   Ultrasound, MRI, SSG, hysteroscopy   Treat the cause

questions.text: Which of the following represents type III choledochal cyst from the given image?
questions.solution:
The figure marked C in the given image represents choledochal cyst type III, a cystic dilation of the intramural common bile duct, within the wall of the duodenum, known as choledochoceles.

Choledochal cysts:

Choledochal cysts are congenital cystic dilations of the intrahepatic and/or extrahepatic biliary tree. They present with a triad of jaundice, a palpable upper quadrant mass, and abdominal pain. They are commonly seen in females.

Choledochal cyst is classified into five types:

The original classification for choledochal cysts by Alonso–Lej, and colleagues has been modified by Todani and associates to include intrahepatic cystic disease.

  • Type I: is a simple cyst that can involve any portion of the CBD.
  • Type II: It is described as an isolated diverticulum arising from the wall of the CBD
  • Type III: They arise from the intraduodenal portion of the common bile duct and are also known as choledochocele.
  • Type IVA: The cysts consist of multiple dilatations of the intrahepatic and extrahepatic bile ducts.
  • Type IVB: These choledochal cysts are multiple dilatations involving only the extrahepatic bile ducts.
  • Type V (Caroli’s disease): It consists of multiple dilatations limited to the intrahepatic bile ducts.

Caroli's disease:

Caroli’s Disease is an autosomal recessive condition of multifocal cystic dilatation of segmental intrahepatic bile ducts. According to Todani's classification, it is classified as a type V choledochal cyst.  

USG may show dilated intrahepatic bile ducts in these individuals. The beaded appearance of intrahepatic bile ducts on the HIDA scan and the central dot sign on CT are characteristic findings associated with Caroli's disease. MRCP is the investigation of choice.

Treatment options:

  • Type I—excision of the cyst with its mucosa and reconstruction by Roux-en-Y hepaticojejunostomy.
  • In type II—excision of the diverticulum and suturing of the CBD wall can be done
  • Type III cysts represent Choledochoceles, consisting of cystic dilation of the intramural common bile duct, within the wall of the duodenum. As type III cysts are associated with the lowest malignancy risk of any choledochal cyst, endoscopic sphincterotomy followed by surveillance is generally recommended over cyst excision with pancreaticoduodenectomy.
  • Type IV, if the cyst is adherent to the portal vein posteriorly, that part of the cyst wall over the portal vein is left behind. But mucosa of the part should be removed. This is named Lily’s operation.
  • Excision of all cystic tissues and reconstruction of the biliary tree is recommended for extrahepatic biliary involvement as in Type 4B and in case of intrahepatic involvement, an additional segmental resection of the liver may be required which can be removed by hepatectomy.
  • Liver transplantation is the preferred treatment of choice in type IV and type V.

Related Pearl: Classification of Choledochal Cysts

Type

Feature

Type I

The most common choledochal cyst type; it involves only the extrahepatic biliary tree and is generally a fusiform dilation.

Type II

Saccular diverticulum off the common bile duct and may be mistaken for an accessory gallbladder.

Type III

A cystic dilation of the intramural common bile duct, within the wall of the duodenum, known as choledochoceles.

Type IV

Type IVa: Cysts involving the intrahepatic and extrahepatic biliary tree

Type IVb: Multiple cysts limited to the extrahepatic biliary tree.

Type V

Also known as Caroli disease, involve the intrahepatic ducts only.

questions.text: A 28-year-old primigravida with a low-risk pregnancy presents at 39 weeks for a normal health check. Her vitals are stable. On PV, her cervix is 4 cm dilated. A repeat PV  after 4 hours shows that her cervix is 6 cm dilated. The fetal head is at +2 station and membranes are absent. Liquor is clear and uterine contractions are good. Fetal heart rate is 150 BPM and reassuring. What is the appropriate course of management?

choices.text: Rupture of membranes and confirm cord prolapse

questions.solution:
The appropriate course of management for this 28-year-old primigravida with the given clinical scenario is to wait and watch.

The patient is low-risk, stable, and in active labor with progressive cervical dilation from 4 cm to 6 cm in 4 hours. This indicates that labor is progressing adequately.

The fetal head is at +2 station, indicating descent into the birth canal, which is a positive sign of labor progression. The absence of membranes suggests that the patient has experienced spontaneous rupture of membranes (SROM), which is a normal occurrence during labor. Clear liquor and reassuring fetal heart rate (150 BPM) indicate fetal well-being.

If there are any signs of labor dystocia or fetal distress during monitoring, appropriate interventions can be considered at that time.

Other options:

  • Oxytocin augmentation or rupture of membranes without clear indications may lead to unnecessary interventions and potential complications.
  • Emergency Caesarean section is not warranted in the absence of fetal distress or other complications.

questions.text: A 40-year-old man presents with the given rash after he had taken NSAIDs for his knee pain. He reported that he developed the same rash in the same location 6 months ago when he took the same drugs for back pain. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The recurrence of hyperpigmentation occurring at the same site with the use of the same drug is characteristic of fixed drug eruption.

Fixed drug eruption is one of the most common drug-induced exanthems. The acute erythematous and bullous stages of fixed eruption characteristically settle leaving residual slate-brown hyperpigmentation, especially in those with darker skin types. The genitalia and perianal area are often affected.

Option A: Drug hypersensitivity is an immune-mediated reaction to a drug of which symptoms ranging from mild to severe include rash, anaphylaxis, and serum sickness.

Option B: Postinflammatory hyperpigmentation (PIH) is an acquired hypermelanosis occurring after cutaneous inflammation or injury e.g., acne vulgaris, atopic dermatitis, and impetigo.

Option D: Drug-induced hypermelanosis is localized or generalized hyperpigmentation that can be caused by a wide range of medications and chemicals. eg. busulphan.  It doesn't necessarily occur at the same site with the reintroduction of drugs.

questions.text: Which of the following should be used for pre-operative management in a patient with pheochromocytoma?
questions.solution:
Alpha-blockers like phenoxybenzamine are given pre-operatively to manage hypertension in pheochromocytoma. Beta-blockers such as propranolol are given only after adequate alpha blockade is achieved.

The drug of choice to control blood pressure prior to surgery is oral phenoxybenzamine at 0.5–4 mg/kg of body weight. It is a non-specific α-blocker and is preferred due to its long action (3-4 days).

Pheochromocytoma:

Pheochromocytoma is a catecholamine secreting tumor derived from the chromaffin cells of the adrenal medulla.

It can be sporadical or hereditary. Hereditary pheochromocytoma occurs in association with syndromes such as MEN 2 (Multiple endocrine neoplasia type 2), familial paraganglioma syndrome, Von Hippel Lindau (VHL) syndrome, and neurofibromatosis (NF) type 1.

Clinical features:

It most commonly presents as a classic triad of intermittent headache, palpitation, and profuse sweating along with hypertension. The patient can also present with anxiety, panic attacks, nausea, abdominal pain, weight loss, and weakness.

Symptoms may be precipitated by surgery, pregnancy, position changes, exercise, and medications such as metoclopramide and tricyclic antidepressants.

Investigations:

  1. Biochemical screening test - measurement of urinary and plasma levels of catecholamines and metanephrines. 
  2. MRI is the investigation of choice for localizing the tumor. It is preferred over a CT scan as the contrast used in CT scans can precipitate paroxysms.
  3. Other imaging modalities like MIBG scintigraphy, DOPA- or FDG- PET scan are used in identifying the primary tumor as well as the extra-adrenal tumors and metastases.

Treatment:

Surgical resection of the tumor is the definitive treatment for pheochromocytoma.

Preoperatively, hypertension is managed initially with alpha-blockers followed by beta-blockers.

Postoperatively, lifelong yearly follow-up should be done.

questions.text: An elderly diabetic female patient presented as shown in the image. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of Mucormycosis.

Diabetic patients with local tissue destruction with blackish nasal discharge typically resemble the presentation of invasive mucormycosis. The blackish discoloration is due to direct fungal invasion causing arterial and venous thrombosis leading to gangrene. Mucormycosis is an opportunistic infection caused principally by species of Rhizopus, Mucor, and Lichtheimia. The most prevalent species is Rhizopus Oryza. 

The rhino-orbital-cerebral is the most common form of mucormycosis. Patients present with rhinitis, eye or facial pain, and facial numbness, followed by the onset of conjunctival suffusion and swelling along with blurry vision.

Diagnosis is made by biopsy with histopathologic examination. The biopsy shows characteristic wide, ribbon-like aseptate hyphal elements that branch at right angles.

The image below shows biopsy findings seen in mucormycosis:

Risk factors:

  • Diabetes (diabetic ketoacidosis).
  • Immunocompromised individuals

Treatment of the infection includes 4 steps:

  1. Initiation of therapy (amphotericin B) as early as possible. Posaconazole can also be used in the management of this condition.
  2. Surgical debridement
  3. Reversal of underlying conditions and risk factors
  4. Treatment of underlying malignancy if present.

The image below shows biopsy findings seen in mucormycosis:

 

Other options:

Option A: Invasive aspergillosis leads to the formation of a black or greyish membranes in the nasal mucosa. The maxillary sinus may contain a fungus ball containing semisolid cheesy-white or blackish material.

Option C: Foreign body nose presents with foul-smelling unilateral discharge.

Option D: Rhinosporidiosis is a granulomatous condition caused by Rhinosporidium seeberi and presents with nasal discharge, epistaxis, and nasal obstruction by a polypoidal mass.

Related Pearl: Classification of fungus based on morphology

Fungi are classified into 4 types based on their morphology:

  • Yeast
  • Yeast-like
  • Molds
  • Dimorphic fungi

Yeast:

  • Unicellular fungi
  • Reproduces by budding
  • Oval to round forms
  • Example: Cryptococcus, Saccharomyces.

 

Yeast like:

  • Unicellular fungi
  • Reproduces by budding or binary fission
  • Spherical or oval forms
  • Pseudohyphae may be seen.
  • Example: Candida, Malassezia furfur.

 

Molds/filamentous fungi:

  • Have hyphae which may be septate or aseptate
  • Aseptate or coenocytic hyphae – Rhizopus, mucor, Lichtheimia.
  • Septate hyphae – Penicillium, Dermatophytes, Aspergillus, fusarium.

 

Dimorphic fungi

  • Filamentous forms in the culture at 220C – 250C and in the environment.
  • Yeast form in the culture at 370C and in tissues.
  • Examples – Histoplasma capsulatum, Blastomyces dermatitidis, Coccidioides immitis, Paracoccidioides brasiliensis, Talaromyces marneffei, Sporothrix schenckii.

questions.text: Steroid-resistant nephrotic syndrome is defined as failure to achieve remission after _____ weeks when on a daily corticosteroid therapy regimen.
questions.solution:
Steroid-resistant nephrotic syndrome(SRNS) is defined as failure to achieve remission after 4-6 weeks of daily dose corticosteroid therapy.

Note:

The IAP guidelines mention SRNS as, remission not achieved even after 4-6 weeks of daily dose therapy with steroids. 

Uptodate guidelines mention SRNS as remission not achieved even after 4 weeks of therapy at a dose of 60 mg/m2 per day.

According to Nelson and Ghai, it is defined as the absence of remission despite therapy with daily prednisolone at a dose of 2 mg/kg per day for 4 weeks and on alternate days for the next 4 weeks (meaning a total of 8 weeks).

questions.text: A 13 year old boy was brought to the child psychiatrist by the parents. The parents reported that child lies frequently at home and in school, misbehaves with the teacher, often bullies the younger kids and has been caught stealing money on multiple occasions. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
History of misbehaving with people , bullying and theft for the last couple of years points towards a diagnosis of conduct disorder.

If it persists beyond 18 years of age it is referred to as anti-social personality disorder.

Conduct disorder is diagnosed when at least 3 behaviors have been present within the previous 12 months, with at least 1 present in the past 6 months.

Onset of Conduct Disorder:

  • Childhood-onset type: Individuals show at least one symptom characteristic of conduct disorder before the age of 10 years.
  • Adolescent-onset type: Individuals show no symptom characteristic of conduct disorder before the age of 10 years.
  • Unspecified onset: Criteria for a diagnosis of conduct disorder are met, but there is not enough information available to determine whether the onset of the first symptom was before or after the age of 10 years.
DSM-5 criteria for Conduct Disorder  
Aggression towards people and animals

Initiating physical fights, bullying, threatening, or intimidating others

Using a weapon to cause serious harm to others

Being physically cruel to people

Being physically cruel to animals

Stealing while confronting a victim

Forcing someone into sexual activity
Destruction of property

Setting fires

Intentionally destroying the property of others
Serious violation of rules

Running away overnight at least twice or once without returning for a lengthy period.

Being truant from school often starting before age 13.

Frequently staying out at night despite parental prohibitions starting before age 13
Deceitfulness or theft

Frequently lying to obtain goods or favors

Breaking into a car or building

Stealing items of nontrivial value without confronting a victim

Oppositional defiant disorder(ODD):

  • Persistent pattern, lasting at least 6 months, of negativistic, hostile, and defiant attitude/behavior towards adults, including arguments, temper outbursts, vindictiveness, and deliberate annoyance.
  • Seen in children less than 10 years of age.
  • The symptoms must be present for 6 months, during which 4 or more of the following have to be present:
    • Argues with others
    • Loses temper
    • Blames others
    • Easily annoyed
    • Refuses and defies to listening to adults
    • Annoys other people quite often

NOTE: Unlike conduct disorder, children with ODD do not indulge in destructive and physically harmful activities.

Disruptive mood dysregulation disorder: Onset before age 10. Severe, recurrent temper outbursts out of proportion to the situation. The child is constantly angry and irritable between outbreaks.

questions.text: Which of the following is the correct sequence of vaginal discharge during puerperium?
questions.solution:
The correct sequence of vaginal discharge during puerperium- Lochia rubra>Lochia serosa>Lochia alba.

Lochia is the vaginal discharge for the first fortnight during puerperium that originates from the uterine body, cervix, and vagina.

Depending upon the variation of the color of the discharge, it is named:

(1) Lochia rubra- Seen in 1–4 days after delivery. The color of the discharge is red. It consists of blood, shreds of fetal membranes and decidua, vernix caseosa, lanugo, and meconium.

(2) Lochia serosa- Seen during 5-9 days. The color is yellowish or pink or pale brownish. It consists mainly of leukocytes, wound exudate, mucus from the cervix, and micro-organisms (anaerobic streptococci and staphylococci). The presence of bacteria is not pathognomonic unless associated with clinical signs of sepsis.

(3) Lochia alba- Seen during 10–15 days. The color of the discharge is pale white. Lochia alba contains plenty of decidual cells, leukocytes, mucus, cholesterin crystals, fatty and granular epithelial cells, and microorganisms.

questions.text: A female patient presents with a hard and irregular lump in the upper outer quadrant of the breast.  The histopathological slide of the mass sample is given below. What is the most likely condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and histopathological findings are suggestive of lobular carcinoma of the breast. Single line of cells are seen lining the normal duct (bottom right of the image) which is the characteristic Indian file/ Single file appearance.

The histopathological image shows discohesive infiltrating tumor cells, signet-ring cells containing intracytoplasmic mucin droplets, and the Indian file appearance which is suggestive of lobular carcinoma of the breast. Tubule formation is absent in this subtype.

Lobular Carcinoma:

  • Usually bilateral
  • Multicentric and presents as hard irregular masses
  • It can have a diffuse infiltrative pattern with minimal desmoplasia
  • It is the most common type of breast carcinoma to present as an occult primary
  • Pathogenesis: Mutation in CDH-1 gene which encodes for cadherin. Loss of E-cadherin leads to small, monomorphic discohesive cells arranged one after another. This arrangement is called an Indian file/ Single file appearance.
  • Desmoplasia is minimal or absent
  • They are Luminal-A type
  • Excellent prognosis

Note: Mutation in CDH-1 also pose a high risk for gastric signet ring cell carcinoma.

Other options:

Option B: Papillary carcinoma consists of true papillae with a leaf-like arrangement of fibrovascular tissue, lined by the tumor cells.

 

Option C: Medullary carcinoma of the breast shows sheets of highly pleomorphic cells with mitotic figures, lymphoplasmacytic infiltrates and pushing border.

 

Option D: Colloidal carcinoma is an invasive breast carcinoma, which shows intra and extracellular mucin deposition. Extracellular type shows tumor cells with faint nuclei arranged in clusters floating in pools/lakes of mucin on histopathological examination. In intracellular type, nuclei are pushed to the peripherally to form signet ring appearance.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common cause of mortality in diabetic ketoacidosis?
questions.solution:
Cerebral edema is the leading cause of mortality in diabetic ketoacidosis.

The osmolar gradient generated due to the high blood glucose level results in water shift from the intracellular fluid (ICF) to the extracellular fluid (ECF) space and leads to the contraction of cell volume. Correction with insulin and intravenous fluids can result in a rapid reduction in effective osmolarity, reversal of the fluid shift, and result in cerebral edema.

Complications of diabetic ketoacidosis include:

  • Cerebral edema – especially in children
  • Cardiac arrhythmia - due to electrolyte imbalance
  • Acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS)
  • Venous thrombosis
  • Acute gastric dilation
  • Acute kidney injury 
  • Intestinal necrosis
  • Acute pancreatitis
  • Mucormycosis

questions.text: Serial monitoring of serum beta hCG is required for which of the following conditions?

choices.text: Pregnancy associated with Neural tube defects

questions.solution:
Serial monitoring of serum Beta hCG testing is done for a molar pregnancy.

Follow-up after the termination of molar pregnancy is done with serum β hCG levels. During the follow-up period, pregnancy must be avoided as it might interfere with the β hCG levels. The initial β-hCG level is obtained 48 hours after evacuation and used as a baseline. It is measured weekly till it becomes negative, and three consecutive normal values are obtained.

All patients should be followed-up for 2 years because choriocarcinoma if it occurs, develops within this period of the evacuation of the mole. Commonly, the circulating levels of βhCG decrease or becomes negative within 4 to 8 weeks post-evacuation. Once negative, the patient is usually followed up monthly for 6 months, then 3 monthly in the first year, and 6 monthly in the second year.

After beta HCG levels have become normal, subsequent conception must be avoided for one year(preferably 2 years). Pregnancy should also be avoided for 1 year after the stoppage of chemotherapy because of the teratogenic effect of drugs.

Other options:

Options A and B: Downs syndrome and Pregnancy associated with Neural tube defects require Maternal serum AFP testing.

Option D: Rh-negative pregnancy requires Coombs antibody testing.

questions.text: Obliteration of right cardiac border on chest X-Ray indicates pathology involving which of the following structures?
questions.solution:
Right middle lobe pathology causes obliteration of right cardiac border.

The silhouette sign is the loss of clear demarcation between normal lung and soft tissue (e.g., heart, diaphragm). This occurs when the lung parenchyma is no longer filled with air and the contrast between air and soft tissue is lost.

A silhouette in a chest radiograph is the outline of a particular structure that is formed at the interface of two tissues with different tissue densities eg. cardiac silhouette between the heart and the lung. Blurring/obliteration of these normal silhouettes due to disease pathologies is known as the silhouette sign.

The silhouette can be obscured only by a pathology that is in direct anatomical contact, eg. right cardiac border will be obscured when there is right middle lobe pneumonia. Hence, the silhouette sign helps us in localizing the site of pathology.

Given below is a list of normal silhouettes on chest radiographs as seen on the PA view. Loss of these silhouettes are indicative of the site of pathology:

Obliterated silhouette Site of pathology
Right para-tracheal stripe Right upper lobe
Right heart border Right middle lobe or
medial right lower lobe
Right hemidiaphragm Right lower lobe
Aortic knuckle Left upper lobe
(posterior segment)
Left heart border Lingula segments of 
left upper lobe
Left hemidiaphragm 
or descending aorta		 Left lower lobe

The left image is a normal chest radiograph with the red line indicating the silhouette of the right heart border and right middle lobe.

The right image shows the same red line delineating where the silhouette should be, but is lost due to consolidation in the right middle lobe.

questions.text: A patient was diagnosed with supraspinatus tendinitis. What degree of movement of the shoulder would be painful for this patient?
questions.solution:
Supraspinatus tendinitis seen in shoulder impingement syndrome is due to repeated rubbing of the tendon (mainly supraspinatus) under the coraco-acromial arc. The patient complaints of increased pain when the arm traverses an arc between 60 and 120 degrees when greater tuberosity negotiates the subacromial space.

Shoulder impingement syndrome:

It is also called supraspinatus syndrome, painful arc syndrome, and swimmer's shoulder and occurs when the tendons of the rotator cuff muscles become irritated and inflamed as they pass through the subacromial space. This can result in pain, weakness, and loss of movement at the shoulder.

Causes of impingement syndrome:

  • Supraspinatus tendinitis (Common)
  • Complete or partial rupture of the rotator cuff
  • Osteoarthritis of the acromioclavicular joint

Clinical features:

  • Subacute tendinitis or painful arc syndrome: Anterior shoulder pain after vigorous activity. Treatment is with avoidance of initiating activity, NSAIDs, and physiotherapy.
  • Chronic tendinitis: Recurrent attacks of subacute tendinitis and pain is worse at night. 
  • Cuff disruption: There is progressive fibrosis and disruption of the cuff leading to a partial or full-thickness tear. Treatment includes acromioplasty and repair of rotator cuff.

A schematic diagram showing the pain in rotator cuff disorder:

questions.text: The usage of the given device in the picture is?

choices.text: Measure the length of the uterus

questions.solution:
The instrument given in the image is Karman’s cannula which is used for menstrual regulation or aspiration.

Menstrual regulation or aspiration is the aspiration of the endometrial cavity 1-3 weeks after a missed period in a woman with a previous normal cycle and a positive urine pregnancy test. It is performed using Karman's cannula.

Procedure -

  • Under aseptic precautions, the cervix may be gently dilated using 4-5 mm size dilators.
  • Then 5-6mm Karman’s cannula is inserted and attached to a 50ml syringe for suction.
  • The cannula is rotated, and pushed in and out with gentle strokes.

This procedure is contraindicated in advanced pregnancy and in the presence of local pelvic inflammation.

The drawback of the procedure - an implanted zygote , and an ectopic pregnancy can be missed.

Other options:

Option A:  Hysterosalpingography is done using a Rubins cannula.

 

Option B:  The length of the uterus is measured using Simpson's uterine sound.

Option C: Retraction is done using Doyen's retractor

Related Pearl: Instruments in OBG

questions.text: Identify the segment marked in the image below.
questions.solution:
The liver segment highlighted in green in this CT section is segment V. The section of the CT given is taken below the portal vein as the cross-section of the portal vein before its bifurcation can be viewed.

A horizontal plane known as the portal plane divides the liver where the portal vein bifurcates and becomes horizontal. This divides each section of the liver into superior and inferior segments: 

  • Left lateral section: segment II above and segment III below the portal plane
  • Left medial section: segment IVa above and segment IVb below the portal plane
  • Right anterior (or medial) section: segment VIII above and segment V below the portal plane
  • Right posterior (or lateral) section: segment VII above and segment VI below the portal plane

 Shown below is a section from below the portal plane.

Couinaud classification is the commonly used classification of the liver. It divides the liver is divided into eight segments. It is based on the distribution of portal venous branches in the liver parenchyma. Each segment has its own vascular supply, biliary drainage, and lymphatic drainage.

The Couinaud's liver segments are as follows:

Related Pearl: Couinaud's Liver Segments

The Couinaud classification is currently the most widely used system to describe functional liver anatomy.

  • Based on the distribution of hepatic portal venous branches in the parenchyma
  • Each segment has its own dual vascular inflow, biliary drainage and lymphatic drainage

Segment I corresponds to the gross anatomical caudate lobe and is considered as posterior segment.

Other segments:

Liver sections

Couinaud's Segments

Right anterior sections

Segments V,VIII

Right Posterior sections

Segments VI, VII

Left medial sections

Segment IV (quadrate lobe)

Left lateral sections

Segment II, III

questions.text: McCall culdoplasty is done in which of the following?
questions.solution:
McCall's culdoplasty is used in enterocele repair.

An enterocele is herniation of the pouch of Douglas and small bowel loops into the rectovaginal septum. Enteroceles are most commonly associated with uterine prolapse. Patients present with the following clinical features:

  • Fecal incontinence
  • Sexual dysfunction
  • Constipation/diarrhea
  • Mass descending PV
  • Pelvic pain or pelvic discomfort
  • A bulge in the posterior vaginal wall:
    • Upper 1/3rd - enterocele
    • Lower 2/3rd - rectocele
  • Peristalsis may be observed in the bulge 

Enterocele repair is done via the following methods:

  • Vaginal approach - it is usually preferred over an abdominal approach. In McCall's culdoplasty, the uterosacral ligaments are used to suspend the vaginal vault. The posterior peritoneum and uterosacral ligaments are approximated. 
  • Abdominal approach - it is preferred in cases where there is associated fecal incontinence. It includes:
    • Moschcowitz repair - the pouch of Douglas is obliterated by several purse-string sutures.
    • Halban's procedure - the peritoneal sac is obliterated using vertical sutures. This can also be done transvaginally.

questions.text: A male patient was brought to the ER after a road traffic accident. On examination, left-sided hydropneumothorax was noted. Thoracostomy was done and around 1800 ml of blood was drained in 1 hour. What is the most appropriate management for this patient?

choices.text: Continue resuscitation for the next 6 Hours
Administer a hemostatic agent through the chest tube

questions.solution:
Given the significant blood loss (1800 ml) and the patient's critical condition, the most appropriate management in this scenario would be an emergency thoracotomy.

A thoracotomy is a surgical procedure in which an incision is made into the chest to access the thoracic cavity. It is performed in critical situations to control bleeding and repair injuries to the chest structures, including the lung and blood vessels.

In this case, the patient's condition is serious due to the combination of pneumothorax, hydrothorax, and a rapid blood loss of 1800 ml in just 1 hour. This level of bleeding suggests a severe injury to blood vessels or vital structures within the chest. Emergency thoracotomy would provide direct access to the bleeding source, allowing for immediate control of bleeding, repair of injuries, and restoration of stable conditions.

Indications for thoracotomy:

  • Initial tube thoracostomy drainage of >1000 ml (penetrating injury) or >1500 ml (blunt injury) of frank blood
  • Ongoing tube thoracostomy drainage of >200 ml/ hr for 3 consecutive hours in non-coagulopathic patients with hemothorax
  • Caked hemothorax despite the placement of two chest tubes
  • Massive air leak from chest tube with inadequate ventilation
  • Open pneumothorax
  • Great vessel injury
  • Pericardial tamponade
  • Cardiac herniation
  • Tracheobronchial injury
  • Esophageal perforation

Other Options:

Option A: Thoracentesis involves the removal of fluid or air from the pleural space using a needle or catheter. However, given the severity of the situation with rapid blood loss, this procedure alone would not adequately address the underlying issues or stop the significant bleeding.

Option B: Continued resuscitation for the next 6 hours is not appropriate in this scenario due to the patient's critical condition and substantial blood loss. Immediate intervention is required to stabilize the patient's condition and address the underlying causes of the blood loss.

Option C: While hemostatic agents can be useful in certain bleeding situations, the rapid blood loss and critical nature of the presented case call for a more immediate and direct approach, such as an emergency thoracotomy, to achieve rapid control of bleeding and prevent further complications.

questions.text: A child presents with the findings shown in the image below. What is the true statement regarding this condition?
questions.solution:
This malnourished child with a distended abdomen has kwashiorkor due to protein malnutrition.

Kwashiorkor is a form of severe acute malnutrition (SAM) characterized by edema and apathy. It usually affects infants and children, most often around the age of weaning till the age of 5. 

It is due to an overall deficiency in protein and calories, with a much more severe protein deficit. It is due to a deficiency of proteins, such as albumin that exerts oncotic pressure in the blood that there is such extensive pitting edema which starts in the legs, and feet and then spreads to hands, face and later becomes generalized.

Skin changes occur over the swollen limbs and include dark, crackled peeling patches with pale skin underneath forming patches of hyper and hypopigmentation called flaky paint dermatosis or crazy paving. The skin gets easily infected.

The hair is dull, brittle, sparse, and can easily be pulled out. It may lose its curl. In dark-haired children, the hair may turn pale or reddish. Alternating bands of light and normal color hair may be seen, known as the flag sign. Children are miserable, apathetic, and often refuse to eat. There is marked muscle atrophy and growth retardation.

Marasmus is another form of SAM that occurs as a result of a calorie deficiency primarily. It is characterized by severe wasting that occurs due to the consumption of fat and muscle to release energy. The child has monkey facies and baggy pants appearance due to the loss of fat pad in the face and buttocks without edema.

Clinical features seen in marasmus are:

  • Head that appears large relative to the body, with staring eyes
  • Emaciated and weak appearance
  • Bradycardia, hypotension, and hypothermia
  • Thin, dry skin
  • Shrunken arms, thighs, and buttocks, with redundant skin folds caused by loss of subcutaneous fat
  • Thin, sparse hair that is easily plucked

Related Pearl: Differences between Marasmus and Kwashiorkar

Marasmus Kwashiorkor
Seen in infants less than 1 year of age

Seen in older children

(6 months to 3 years of age)
Total calorie deficit Protein deficit
No edema Edema is prominent

Voracious appetite

No apathy

Loss of appetite

Apathy
Severe muscle wasting Muscle wasting mild or absent
Prominent ribs Protuberant abdomen

No Fatty liver

No subcutaneous fat

Fatty liver

Subcutaneous fat preserved

Special features:

  1. Alert
  2. Loose wrinkled skin 
  3. Baggy pant appearance

Special features:

  1. Moon face
  2. Flaky paint dermatosis
  3. Flag sign

The image below shows Flag sign characterised by alternating bands of hypopigmented and normal pigmented areas on the hair strand.

 

The image below shows a child with an old wrinkled old man appearance.

 

The image highlights the differentiating clinical features between marasmus and kwashiorkor

questions.text: A 20-year-old survivor of a terrorist attack that happened 2 weeks ago comes to the psychiatry OPD with complaints of persistent flashbacks about the incident. She has been unable to sleep properly and is avoiding going to crowded places. She is no longer interested in doing activities with her friends. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The likely diagnosis in this patient is acute stress disorder, because the symptoms have been present for less than one month.

Post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD) and acute stress disorder both present with the same set of symptoms:

  • Intrusive symptoms such as recurrent nightmares and flashbacks of the event, psychological distress due to stimuli that are reminders of prior trauma
  • Avoidance of external reminders of trauma
  • Negative mood or cognition related to the trauma, such as diminished interest in activities and withdrawal
  • Altered level of arousal, such as sleep disturbances and hypervigilance

A diagnosis of PTSD is made if these symptoms present ≥1 month following the traumatic event. If these symptoms are present prior to 1 month, then a diagnosis of acute stress disorder is made.

The treatment modalities for PTSD and acute stress disorder include trauma-focused cognitive behavioral therapy, eye movement desensitization and reprocessing therapy (EMDR), and SSRIs. 

Adjustment disorder (option B) is diagnosed when the patient has emotional or behavioral changes following a stressor in his life. However, the distress is out of proportion to the stressor itself — that is, the feeling of distress is subjective.

Major depressive disorder (option C) presents with low mood, loss of interest in pleasurable activities, and decreased energy. Although this patient has a loss of interest in activities, the presence of hypervigilance symptoms and flashbacks following a traumatic event points towards a diagnosis of a stress-trauma related disorder.

questions.text: A female presented a few weeks ago to the OPD  with an itchy skin rash. She was prescribed a topical ointment that relieved the itching. However, after a few days of stopping the ointment application, she presented to the OPD again with the same complaints. The lesions are shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
In this case, the patient presented with an itchy skin rash and was most likely given topical corticosteroids. The image shows atypical lesions of tinea, which is a fungal infection. Although steroids could have provided initial relief, it is not the appropriate treatment for this condition. Therefore, the skin rash reappeared when the patient stopped using the ointment. This scenario is suggestive of tinea incognito.

  • Steroids suppress inflammation without eliminating the fungus; so the typical raised margin is diminished, scaling is lost and inflammation reduces. Hence, diagnosis becomes difficult. Once steroid dosage is decreased or stopped, scaling reappears and shows fungal mycelium.
  • Treatment: Oral terbinafine or itraconazole

Tinea corporis/ ringworm infection is caused by the dermatophyte Trichophyton rubrum. It results from the invasion and proliferation of the causal fungi in the stratum corneum with lesions on the trunk and limbs. 

Characteristic lesions are circular, usually sharply marginated with a raised edge with central resolution. Scaling is a common but not a constant finding. The diagnosis is mostly clinical. In case of doubt, skin scrapings from site of lesion examined under a microscope may show fungal mycelium.

Pharmacological treatment of fungal Tinea infection is :

Localized disease, recent onset

  • Topical terbinafine twice daily for 2 weeks
  • Topical azole once or twice daily for 2–4 weeks

Widespread disease

  • First-line:
    Oral terbinafine 250 mg/day 2–3 weeks
    Oral Itraconazole 100 mg/day 2–4 weeks
  • Second line:
    Oral Griseofulvin 1 g/day for 4 weeks

questions.text:
Which of the following are storage symptoms of benign prostatic hyperplasia?
  1. Urgency
  2. Enuresis
  3. Hesitancy
  4. Frequency
  5. Dribbling
questions.solution:
Urgency, enuresis and frequency are storage symptoms.

Lower urinary tract symptoms (LUTS) can be classified as:

Storage Voiding
  • Frequency (earliest symptom in BPH)
  • Nocturia
  • Urgency
  • Urge incontinence
  • Nocturnal incontinence (enuresis)
  • Hesitancy
  • Poor flow
  • Intermittent stream
  • Dribbling
  • Sensation of poor bladder emptying
  • Episodes of near retention

BPH is characterized by symptoms of urinary frequency, urgency, nocturia, incontinence, slow urinary stream, straining to void, urinary intermittency (stream starting and stopping during micturition), or hesitancy, splitting of the voiding stream, and terminal dribbling. Physical examination reveals a smooth enlarged and non-tender prostate. Lab investigations reveal a normal PSA (prostate-specific antigen). Diagnosis is made based on clinical presentation and a lack of lab findings suggestive of malignancy (elevated PSA). A biopsy is rarely indicated.

Conservative treatment is recommended for men with mild symptoms, flow rate >10ml/s, and good bladder emptying with residual urine <100ml. 

Medical management includes alpha-adrenergic blocking agents that inhibit the contraction of smooth muscle that is found in the prostate. Tamsulosin is an adrenoreceptor antagonist with receptor selectivity at α1A. It is used in the treatment of benign prostatic hyperplasia.

The other class of drugs is the 5α-reductase inhibitors, which inhibit the conversion of testosterone to DHT, the most active form of androgen. Finasteride is a 5α-reductase enzyme inhibitor. It is effective in the treatment of palpable enlarged prostate. These drugs result in a 25% shrinkage of the prostate gland.

Indications for surgical management:

  • Lower urinary tract symptoms that are refractory to medical therapy
  • Refractory urinary retention
  • Recurrent urinary tract infection (UTI)
  • Hematuria
  • Stone formation
  • Hydronephrosis, hydroureter with renal functional impairment

Surgical management involves the use of the transurethral resection of the prostate (TURP). Laser ablative techniques using holmium YAG can also be done. 

Storage symptoms are seen in conditions where the bladder is irritated. Voiding symptoms are common in conditions causing bladder outlet obstruction. In benign prostatic hyperplasia, both storage and voiding symptoms are present.

questions.text: A young male patient was given regional block with 0.25% bupivacaine for a minor surgical procedure. Shortly after the injection, the patient suddenly became unresponsive and the pulse was not recordable. Which of the following would be the best course of management for this patient?
questions.solution:
The clinical picture of an unresponsive patient with an absent pulse following bupivacaine administration is most likely due to bupivacaine-induced cardiotoxicity resulting from accidental intravascular injection of local anesthetic. The best course of management in this scenario would be administering CPR (cardiopulmonary resuscitation), along with a 20% intralipid injection.

Bupivacaine is a long-acting local anesthetic that is the most cardiotoxic among the local anesthetics. It depresses the rapid phase of depolarization in Purkinje fibers and ventricular muscle due to a decreased availability of fast sodium channels in cardiac membranes. This reduced rate of depolarization depresses myocardial contractility. Hence, bupivacaine is a potent cardio depressant.

Cardio-vascular effects of bupivacaine-induced toxicity are as follows:

  • Left ventricular depression
  • Atrioventricular heart block
  • Ventricular arrhythmias and ventricular fibrillation
  • Sinus bradycardia can lead to cardiac arrest

Initial management includes immediate initiation of cardiopulmonary resuscitation (CPR) and defibrillation as per the advanced cardiac life support (ACLS) algorithm.

Following CPR, intralipid therapy is initiated. Its mechanism is explained by the lipid sink theory which states lipophilic drugs (bupivacaine) are absorbed into the lipid emulsion of the plasma, hence, removed from tissues affected by toxicity.

A rapid bolus of intralipid 20% IV (1.5 mL/kg) is administered without delay, followed by an infusion of 0.25 mL/kg/min. The infusion should be given continuously for at least 10 minutes after hemodynamic stability is achieved. 

Local anesthesia systemic toxicity (LAST) can also affect the central nervous system (CNS), which is more susceptible to local anesthetic action as compared to the cardiovascular system. Dizziness, tinnitus, and disorientation are the initial symptoms. Shivering, muscular twitching, and tremors follow. Tonic-clonic seizures occur. Finally, respiratory depression can lead to respiratory arrest.

questions.text: If a wide range of values are present in a community, what is the best measure of central tendency?
questions.solution:
The best measure of central tendency if there are a wide range of values is median.

If we take an example of a dataset of (1, 1, 1, 2, 4, 5, 5, 5, 6, 11, 41), we can see that 41 seems to be well away from the mean of 7.45 of the dataset.  If we eliminate this outlier, we can get a new dataset of (1, 1, 1, 2, 4, 5, 5, 5, 6, 11) with a median of 4.5 and a mean of 4.1. We see that the median only changed by 10% (went down to 4.5 from 5), while the mean decreased by 45%. Therefore, the median is less affected by outliers or extreme values.

 The median is not sensitive to extreme values or outliers and thus it is the preferred measure of central tendency in a distribution with a wide range of values.

  • The median is the central element in a distribution when all the elements are arranged in order.
  • In a distribution that has an odd number of elements, the median is the middle value.
  • In a distribution that has an even number of elements, the median is the average of the middle values, i.e., the arithmetic mean of the two middle values.
  • The drawback of the median is that it doesn’t respond to the actual values of the elements but only to the number of values above or below it.
  • The median is the same as the 50th centile.
  • It is sometimes symbolized by Mdn.
  • The median can be arrived at in ordinal, interval and ratio data scales.

questions.text: A 10-year-old male child presents with a history of spontaneous excessive bruising and haemarthrosis. On investigation, he has a normal platelet count, prolonged PTT, and a normal PT. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis is Haemophilia A. Bleeding into joints (hemarthrosis) following minor trauma is particularly characteristic of hemophilia.

  • Hemophilia A, the most common hereditary disease associated with life-threatening bleeding, is caused by mutations in factor VIII, an essential cofactor for factor IX in the coagulation cascade.
  • Hemophilia A is inherited as an X-linked recessive trait and thus affects mainly males and homozygous females.
  • About 30% of patients have no family history; their disease is caused by new mutations.
  • Hemophilia A -  clinical severity correlates well with the level of factor VIII activity.
  • Those with less than 1% of normal levels have a severe disease; those with 2% to 5% of normal levels have moderately severe disease, and those with 6% to 50% of normal levels have mild disease.
  • A tendency toward easy bruising and massive hemorrhage after trauma or operative procedures.
  • Spontaneous hemorrhages frequently occur in regions of the body that are susceptible to trauma, particularly the joints, where they are known as hemarthroses.
  • Recurrent bleeding into the joints leads to progressive deformities that can be crippling.
  • Petechiae are characteristically absent.
  • Patients with hemophilia A have a prolonged PTT and a normal PT results that point to an abnormality of the intrinsic coagulation pathway.
  • Factor VIII-specific assays are required for diagnosis.

questions.text: A  female patient was provisionally diagnosed with intestinal obstruction. An emergency laparotomy was done, and the following specimen was removed. Identify the following specimen.
questions.solution:
The given specimen is that of a trichobezoar. This is a type of bezoar that forms in the stomach due to the accumulation of hair.

Trichophagia is the compulsive eating of hair associated with trichotillomania. Trichotillomania is a form of obsessive-compulsive disorder that is associated with hair pulling. In trichophagia, people also ingest the hair that they pull. 

Complications of trichotillomania include

  • Trichobezoars
  • Malnutrition
  • Intestinal obstruction

The modalities currently used in the management of trichotillomania are cognitive behavioral therapy and habit reversal training.

Other options:

  • A phytobezoar forms when undigested plant material, such as fibers from fruits and vegetables, clump together in the stomach and create a mass that can lead to gastrointestinal symptoms. 
  • Lactatobezoar is a rare type of bezoar that forms in newborns' stomachs due to the accumulation of undigested milk or formula.
  • Gangrene of the stomach can occur as a complication of conditions like gastric volvulus (twisting of the stomach), which leads to compromised blood flow to the stomach tissues.

questions.text: Split thickness skin graft for wound closure on thigh includes:

choices.text: Epidermis and variable parts of dermis

questions.solution:
Split thickness skin graft for wound closure on thigh includes epidermis and variable parts of the dermis.

Split thickness skin graft (Thiersch graft ): Partial-thickness skin grafts consisting of the epidermis and a portion of the dermis are called split-thickness skin grafts.

Full-thickness skin grafts (Wolfe graft): include the epidermis and entire dermis, with portions of the sweat glands, sebaceous glands, and hair follicles. 

Advantages of split skin graft over full-thickness skin graft:

  • Large grafts can be harvested.
  • In the case of thinner split-thickness grafts, the donor site heals more rapidly and can be reused in severe cases such as burns.
  • Uptake is good. Meshing can be done i.e. small splits are made in graft and any exudates collected can come out through this and this improves graft take up. 
  • Meshing also allows the graft to expand.

Advantages of full-thickness skin graft over split skin graft:
