  • It has a lesser degree of post graft contraction
  • Best cosmetic appearance as they include the highest number of skin appendage elements.

The most preferable donor site is buttock in cosmetically sensitive individuals and children. The most commonly used donor site is the thigh.

  • The graft is taken from the donor site with a handheld Humby knife or electric dermatome.
  • Grafts are perforated to allow exudates to escape and improve ‘take’. It can further be meshed to allow expansion.
  • Grafts will take up only on the beds which are vascularized, hence preparation of wound bed is an essential step.
  • Skin grafts are completely dependent on nutrition on the tissue over which they are placed and can heal well over muscle, perichondrium, and periosteum. They do not take well over bone or cartilage or on tissue that has been irradiated or infected or is hypovascular.
  • A clean healthy wound bed with a meshed graft tied in place to stop movement will encourage take.
  • The presence of group A beta-hemolytic streptococci is a contraindication in grafting as it can destroy split grafts completely and also convert donors to full-thickness defects.
  • The donor area is dressed appropriately and the dressing is opened after 10 days and not earlier. 

The given image shows Humby's knife. The average thickness of the graft obtained from a Humbys knife is 0.3 mm.

Related Pearl: Skin graft : phases of uptake of the graft

The take of skin graft occurs in three phases:

  1. Imbibition (Plasmatic circulation): during the first 48 hours, the graft is nourished with plasma exudate from host bed capillaries.
  2. Inosculation, in which cut vessels from the host bed line up with the cut ends of the vessels of the graft to form anastomoses
  3. Neovascularization, in which blood vessels grow from the recipient bed into the graft

Sensibility returns to the graft over time, with reinnervation beginning at approximately 4 to 5 weeks and being completed by 12 to 24 months. Pain returns first, with light touch and temperature returning later.

Note: some books give that the 3 phases are imbibition,revascularisation (inosculation+neovascularisation) and organisation (fibrin layer holds the graft in place and this is replaced by postgraft day 7 with fibroblasts)

questions.text: A primigravida woman gives birth to a baby with the following defect. Identify the anomaly.
questions.solution:
The above image showing anencephaly and a contiguous bony defect of the spine, is suggestive of craniorachischisis. It occurs due to failure of complete closure of the neural tube.

Rachischisis is the most severe type of neural tube defect, where the entire neural tube fails to close. Rachischisis can occur in the spinal cord or brain regions of the neural tube. The exposed neural tissues often become necrotic. 

The image given below shows craniorachischisis.

Spina bifida is a general term used for neural tube defects affecting the spinal region and associated with splitting of the vertebral arches. It is characterized by gaps in the vertebral arches and may or may not involve the underlying neural tissue.

The illustration shown below shows spina bifida.

The 3 main types of spina bifida:

  • Spina bifida occulta - This is the mildest form of spina bifida. The defect in the vertebral arches is covered by the skin. The splits in the vertebrae are so small that the spinal cord does not protrude. The skin at the site of the lesion may be normal, or it may have some hair growing from it.
  • Meningocele - The defect in the vertebra allows the meninges to protrude through the defect.
  • Myelomeningocele (meningomyelocele) - Defect in the vertebral column allows the spinal cord with the meningeal coverings to protrude. 

The image given below shows the different types of spina bifida.

questions.text: Interpret the finding of the ECG given below.
questions.solution:
The given ECG shows a regular rhythm, narrow QRS complex tachycardia and absent P waves is suggestive of supraventricular tachycardia. 

Supraventricular tachycardias (SVTs) originate above the ventricles

  • Tachycardias originating from the atrium:
    • Sinus tachycardia- from the SA node
    • Focal atrial tachycardia
    • Multifocal atrial tachycardia
    • Atrial flutter 
    • Atrial fibrillation
  • Tachycardias originating from the AV node:
    • Junctional tachycardia- automaticity within AV Node
    • AV nodal reentry tachycardia (AVNRT)
  • Tachycardia associated with accessory atrioventricular pathways: Atrioventricular reentry tachycardia(AVRT).

The management of paroxysmal supraventricular tachycardia is given below.

ECG in Atrial fibrillation also shows absent p waves, narrow QRS complex, and irregularly irregular RR interval with a heart rate ranging between 110-160 beats/minute

Related Pearl: Supraventricular tachycardias

 

Supraventricular tachycardias with narrow QRS complex:

  • Narrow QRS with regular RR interval
   Tachycardia                ECG features
Sinus tachycardia Normal P wave, normal ECG features except for the rate
Focal atrial tachycardia A single type of abnormal p wave morphology is seen
Junctional tachycardia No p waves. Heart rate is 100- 200/ min
AV nodal reentry tachycardia No p waves. Pseudo R' waves may be seen. Heart rate is 150-250/ min
Atrioventricular reentry tachycardia P wave always follows QRS. RP interval< PR interval
Atrial flutter Sawtooth shaped flutter waves are seen

 

  • Narrow QRS with irregular RR interval
     Tachycardia        ECG features
Atrial fibrillation No distinct p waves seen
Multifocal atrial tachycardia More than 3 different abnormal p wave morphologies are seen
Atrial flutter/tachycardia with variable block ECG features of heart block are seen.

 

Supraventricular tachycardias with wide QRS complex:

  • Antidromic AVRT (atrioventricular reentry tachycardia)
  • Supraventricular tachycardias with bundle branch block

Related Pearl: ECG patterns of various ventricular arrhythmias

Ventricular tachycardia

 

Polymorphic ventricular tachycardia associated with QTc prolongation- Torsades de pointes

 

Ventricular flutter

 

Ventricular fibrillation

questions.text: Which of the following is the first-line drug used to control seizures in a child presenting with febrile seizures?
questions.solution:
The first-line drug to control the seizures in febrile seizures is a benzodiazepine like midazolam or lorazepam.

Febrile seizures occur in children of the age of 6-60 months with a high-grade fever of 38°C (100.4 F) or higher without underlying CNS infections, metabolic abnormality, or prior afebrile seizures.

Risk factors:

Major:

  • Age  less than 1 year
  • Duration of fever  less than 24 hr
  • Fever range: 38-39°C (100.4-102.2°F)

Minor:

  • Family history of epilepsy
  • Daycare
  • Male gender
  • Complex febrile seizure
  • Family history of febrile seizures
  • Lower serum sodium at the time of presentation

Types of febrile seizures:

Simple febrile seizures Complex (atypical) febrile seizures
Occurs within 24 hours of the onset of fever Can occur at any time during a fever
Generalized seizures Focal seizures
Duration is <15 min Prolonged (>15 min)
No recurrence within 24 hrs of seizures Recurrent within 24 hours
Chances of going into epilepsy 1% Chances of going into epilepsy 6%

 Investigations:

  • Lumbar puncture should be performed in the first episode of seizures with fever, for all infants <6 months age (to exclude meningitis).
  • EEG and neuroimaging are advised for children with atypical febrile seizures.

Acute treatment of febrile seizures includes lorazepam and midazolam for seizures lasting more than 5 minutes. Rectal diazepam is prescribed to use at home as rescue medication if febrile seizures last more than 5 minutes. The use of antipyretics can decrease the discomfort of the child but does not reduce the risk of having a recurrent febrile seizure.

Prophylaxis:

  • Intermittent prophylaxis includes oral clobazam for 3 days during the fever episode, if the febrile seizures recur at the rate of ≥3 seizures in 6 months, or ≥4 in 1 year.
  • Continuous prophylaxis with sodium valproate and phenobarbitone can be used for failed intermittent prophylaxis and in recurrent atypical febrile seizures.

Note:

  • Intermittent oral nitrazepam, clobazam, and clonazepam have also been used. Such therapies help reduce, but do not eliminate, the risks of recurrence of febrile seizures.
  • Future epilepsy does not change with or without antiepileptic therapy.
  • Iron deficiency is associated with an increased risk of febrile seizures, and thus screening and treating it would be appropriate.

questions.text: A 3-day old male neonate who has not yet passed meconium developed abdominal distension. There is no history of fever. On rectal examination, forceful expulsion of stool was observed. A barium enema is performed and the findings are shown in the image below. Which of the following is the gold standard for the diagnosis of the above condition?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of a newborn presenting with failure to pass meconium, abdominal distension, forceful expulsion of stools on rectal examination, and barium enema showing dilated right colon with a transition zone in the mid-descending colon is suggestive of Hirschsprung's disease. The gold standard for the diagnosis of Hirschprung's disease is a rectal biopsy.

Hirschsprung disease or congenital aganglionic colon is characterized by the absence of ganglion cells in the myenteric (Auerbach) plexus and submucosal (Meissner) plexus of the distal intestinal segment. This is because of the premature arrest of normal migration of neural crest cells from the cecum to the rectum.

 

They are predominantly seen in boys and are associated with Down syndrome. Most cases present during the neonatal period with abdominal distension, bilious vomiting, and failure to pass meconium. Later they may also have poor feeding and severe constipation. Forceful expulsion of stools is observed on rectal examination as the stools accumulate in the distal colon.

A barium enema is obtained on all suspected cases. This demonstrates the location of the transition zone between the dilated ganglionic colon and the distal aganglionic rectal segment.  In older children, anorectal manometry shows a high internal sphincter pressure due to the absence of normal inhibitory reflex.

 Rectal biopsy is the gold standard investigation shows the following:

  • Absent ganglia
  • Hypertrophied nerve trunks
  • Positive immunostaining for acetylcholinesterase
  • Calretinin immunostain­ing (superior to acetylcholinesterase staining)

The definitive surgeries are the Swenson procedure, Duhamel procedure, and Soave's procedure

The most common cause of death in uncorrected Hirschprung's disease is enterocolitis.

questions.text: Which of the following is the safest hysterectomy surgery to minimise the risk of ureteric injury on the OT table?
questions.solution:
Vaginal hysterectomy is the safest surgical approach to minimize the risk of ureteric injury on the OT table.

This is because the vaginal approach allows surgeons to follow natural anatomical planes and typically requires less dissection and manipulation of the uterus.

In a retrospective review of study involving 3114 hysterectomies, the following rates of ureteric injury were noted :

Procedure Incidence of Ureteric injury
Abdominal hysterectomy (5/940) 0.53%
Vaginal hysterectomy (1/304) 0.33%
Robotic hysterectomy (7/1088) 0.64%
Laparoscopic hysterectomy (4/782) 0.51%

Procedures that are associated with highest risk for ureteric injury are (but they are not the most common cause of ureteric injuries):

  • Surgery for malignancy
  • Advanced pelvic reconstructive surgery
  • Laparoscopic hysterectomy

Urinary tract injury occurs almost exclusively in major gynecologic surgery that involves surgical dissection in proximity to the ureters or bladder. Vaginal route for hysterectomy tends to have lower rates of ureteric injuries than open or laparoscopic routes.

Patients with ureteric injuries have a complicated post-operative period. They can present with the following features:

  • Fever
  • Flank pain
  • Abdominal distension
  • Prolonged paralytic ileus - bowel sounds are absent
  • High drain outputs, in case abdominal drains are placed.

CT urogram and retrograde pyelography are the investigations of choice. They reveal urinary extravasation from the ureter. Ureteric injuries are prevented by careful division of tissue planes during pelvic or genitourinary surgeries. The condition is managed by prompt surgical repair by ureteroureterostomy or percutaneous ureterostomy.

questions.text: A post-menopausal woman presented with pain in her lower abdomen for the past 4 months. She was informed to have fibroids for a long time. The radiological investigation is shown below. What is the type of degeneration that occurred in this patient?
questions.solution:
The X-ray shows calcified fibroids and is due to the calcific degeneration of fibroids.

Calcific or calcareous degeneration most often involves subserous fibroid with small pedicle or myomas in post menopausal women.

In calcareous degeneration, phosphates and carbonates of lime are deposited in the periphery along the course of the vessels. The best examples of calcareous myomas are those in old patients with long-standing myomas. They are like ‘womb-stones’ in graveyards.

Another radiograph showing large calcified myoma:

Related Pearl: Secondary changes and complications in fibromyomas

  • Hyaline change, cystic degeneration and atrophy

  • Calcareous degeneration, osseous degeneration

  • Red degeneration

  • Sarcomatous change

  • Torsion, hemorrhage

  • Infection/ ulceration, particularly in the dependent part of a submucous polyp

  • Inversion of the uterus

  • Endometrial carcinoma associated with fibromyoma

  • Endometrial and myohyperplasia

  • Accompanying adenomyosis

  • Parasitic fibroid

questions.text: The mask given below works on which of the following principles?
questions.solution:
The given image shows a Venturi mask and it works using the Bernoulli principle in delivering a predetermined and fixed concentration of oxygen to the patient.

In the Venturi mask ,the size of the constriction present in the device determines the final concentration of oxygen for a given gas flow. This is achieved in spite of the patient's respiratory pattern by providing a higher gas flow than the peak inspiratory flow rate.

Patients with COPD require greater FiO2 than those provided by low-flow devices and are ideal candidates for the use of a Venturi mask.

In the Venturi mask system, oxygen inflow is connected to a specific color-coded entrainment device at the base of the mask that provides a set Fio2 at a set oxygen inflow rate. Various entrainment devices can provide a Fio2 of 0.24 to 0.5, with an oxygen inflow of 4 to 15 l/min and a delivered total flow of 35 to 45 l/min.

questions.text: If the division in the zygote occurs between 9-12 days after fertilization, which of the following twin is expected?
questions.solution:
If the division in the zygote occurs between 9-12 days after fertilization, monochorionic monoamniotic twins are expected.

Time of division Type of twin
<3 days  Dichorionic diamniotic (DCDA) 
4-8 days Monochorionic diamniotic (MCDA)
>8 days Monochorionic monoamniotic (MCMA)
>13 days  Conjoint twins

The following radiological signs help in the determination of the chorionicity and the amnionicity of a twin gestation.

Lambda sign: In dichorionic gestation, the twins are separated by amniotic membranes and an intervening chorion. So, a thicker twin peak sign or lambda (λ) sign is formed at the point at which the amnions meet the placenta. It is best seen in the first trimester.

T sign: It is the sonographic image seen in a monochorionic twin pregnancy. It refers to the lack of chorion extending between the layers of the intertwin membrane.

  • In monochorionic diamniotic gestation, the twins are separated only by the two amniotic membranes, with no intervening chorion. So, a thin T sign is formed at the point at which the amnions meet the placenta. It is best seen in the latter part of the first trimester or the beginning of the second trimester.
  • In monochorionic monoamniotic gestation, there is an absence of a dividing membrane.

Related Pearl: Twinning

questions.text: A 30-year-old man presents with distal leg weakness, reduced muscle stretch reflexes, with no complaints of tingling or numbness. On examination, there is atrophy of the muscles below the knee. The following clinical findings are seen and similar history is seen in elder brother. The most probable diagnosis is
questions.solution:
The given image shows lack of muscle, high arch of foot, and hammer-toes which, along with the other clinical features mentioned above, are suggestive of Charcot-Marie-Tooth disease.

Charcot–Marie–Tooth disease (CMT) is the most common type of hereditary neuropathy. CMT is a syndrome of many genetically distinct disorders.

CMT type 1

  • Most common form of hereditary neuropathy
  • Usually presents in the first to third decade of life with distal leg weakness, e.g., foot drop
  • No numbness or tingling
  • Reduced sensation to all modalities apparent on examination
  • Reduced muscle stretch reflexes
  • Atrophy of the muscles below the knee, leading to inverted champagne bottle legs 

Diabetic neuropathy, primary amyloidosis, neuropathy associated with Sjogren’s syndrome, and rheumatoid arthritis are acquired forms of neuropathies.

Related Pearl: Neuropathic Disorders

Hereditary neuropathic disorders 

  • Charcot-Marie-Tooth disease (Most common hereditary neuropathy)
  • Tangier disease
  • Friedreich’s ataxia
  • Familial Amyloid Polyneuropathy
  • Hereditary Neuropathy with Liability to Pressure Palsies (HNPP)
  • Hereditary Neuralgic Amyotrophy (HNA)
  • Hereditary Sensory and Autonomic Neuropathy (HSAN)
  • Fabry’s disease (angiokeratoma corporis diffusum)
  • Refsum’s disease

Causes of acquired neuropathies

  • Primary or AL amyloidosis
  • Diabetic neuropathy
  • Hypothyroidism
  • Sjögren’s syndrome
  • Rheumatoid arthritis (RA)
  • Scleroderma, Sarcoidosis
  • Infectious (VZV,CMV,EBV,Hepatitis, HIV, Diphtheria, Leprosy) 
  • Inflammatory bowel disease
  • Critical illness polyneuropathy (CIP)

questions.text: A female patient with post partum hemorrhage has been given ergometrine and oxytocin. The bleeding still continues. Which prostaglandin derivative can be given in this situation?
questions.solution:
Carboprost, 15-methyl PGF2α can be used in a setting where both ergometrine and oxytocin have not been able to control the bleeding. 

Oxytocin is used as the first-line agent in preventing postpartum hemorrhage. When oxytocin fails or is not available, ergot derivatives can be used for second-line treatment. 

Carboprost, 15-methyl PGF2α is the drug of choice for PPH and can be used for uterine atony in a dose of 0.25 mg IM. This dose can be repeated if necessary at 15-90 min intervals, up to a maximum of eight doses.

Misoprostol: 

  • (PGE1) is useful where injectable uterotonics are not available or are not recommended.
  •  Evidence from a meta-analysis doesn't clearly favor misoprostol over other uterotonics for treating postpartum hemorrhage (PPH) or enhancing oxytocin infusion.
  • The side effect of hyperthermia with misoprostol is causes discomfort, leading to unnecessary sepsis investigations and potentially unwarranted antibiotic therapy.

Postpartum hemorrhage:

It is defined as a loss of more than 500 ml of blood after completion of the third stage of labor (in vaginal delivery).

PPH is blood loss of more than 1000 mL from the genital tract following cesarean section.

Depending upon the amount of blood loss, PPH can be, minor (<1L) or major (>1L). Major is further subdivided into moderate (1L-2L) and severe (>2L).

Types of PPH:

Primary/early PPH: Hemorrhage occurring within 24 hours of childbirth. Causes include

  • Atony: Primi, grand multipara, over-distended uterus, hydramnios, precipitate labor, prolonged labor, uterine malformations, fibroid uterus
  • Trauma: Instrumental deliveries, episiotomy, precipitate labor, macrosomia
  • Retained tissues: retained placenta, blood clots
  • Bleeding disorders: Sepsis, Intrauterine death, HELLP syndrome.

Secondary/ late PPH: Hemorrhage occurring after 24 hours and up to 12 weeks postpartum. Causes include 

  • Placental polyp: Retained products undergo necrosis with fibrin deposition and eventually form a placental polyp, which on detachment from the myometrium causes brisk hemorrhage.
  • Abnormal involution of the placental site.
  • Retention of placental cotyledon or products of conception.
  • Uterine artery pseudoaneurysm.
  • Endometritis
  • Coagulopathy

Resuscitative measures include

  • Airway, breathing, circulation assessment
  • A high concentration of oxygen (10–15 l/min) via a facemask 
  • Blood transfusion if clinically required
  • Fluid resuscitation with warmed fluids up to 3.5 liters, starting with up to 2 liters of crystalloids such as normal saline and ringer's lactate. Colloids can be used when there is a need for packed RBCs transfusion, until blood is arranged.

questions.text: A patient is brought in to the casualty with maxillofacial trauma after an RTA. He is unconscious with a dropping SpO2. The ER doctor decides to intubate him. What is the preferred method of securing airway for this patient?
questions.solution:
Patients with severe maxillofacial trauma are very likely to experience severe airway compromise or obstruction. Hence to maintain airway competency, intubation is necessary and in the above case, the presence of facial trauma, tracheostomy is ideal.

Tracheostomy involves making an opening and placing a stoma in the anterior wall of the trachea. 

Functions: 

  1. Provides an alternative pathway for breathing by bypassing the obstruction.
  2. Improves alveolar ventilation by reducing dead space by 30-50% and reducing airway resistance
  3. Uses a cuff to protect the airways from secretions and blood
  4. Allows suction of secretions in the setting of the impaired cough reflex.
  5. Allows positive pressure respiration
  6. Allows administration of anesthesia

Indications: 

  1. Respiratory obstruction due to 
    1. Infections (laryngo-tracheo-bronchitis, epiglottitis, diphtheria)
    2. Trauma due to external injury, mandibular or maxillofacial fractures
    3. Neoplasms
    4. Foreign bodies or edema
    5. Bilateral abductor paralysis
    6. Congenital anomalies
  2. Retained secretions
    1. Inability to cough due to coma, spasm, or paralysis of respiratory muscles
    2. Aspiration of pharyngeal secretions
    3. Painful cough
  3. Respiratory insufficiency due to emphysema, chronic bronchitis

Other options:

Option A and B: Mask ventilation and LMA are not enough as the patient has severe airway compromise.

Option D:  Nasotracheal intubation is contraindicated in the presence of facial trauma because if there is an undiscovered fracture at the base of the skull, the tube could be forced through it and into the brain.

questions.text: An elderly male patient who is a known case of COPD, hypertension, and diabetes mellitus visits the OPD to review his medications. Which of the following criteria should be followed by the physician during the review?
questions.solution:
Beer's criteria is widely used for reducing the use of potentially inappropriate medications and polypharmacy in the geriatric population.

American Geriatric Society came up with Beer's criteria to review potentially inappropriate medications and avoid polypharmacy and deprescribe irrational medications due to the increased adverse effects of many drugs in the geriatric age group. This includes:

  • Explicit list of drugs that should be avoided in older adults
  • Drugs that should be avoided or be used at lower doses in patients with reduced kidney function
  • Specific drug-disease and drug-drug interactions that are known to be harmful in older adults

Long-acting benzodiazepines, proton pump inhibitors, antipsychotics, aspirin, dipyridamole, propoxyphene, and amitriptyline were among the most frequently prescribed inappropriate medications.

Medications like glimepiride, rivaroxaban, tramadol, and certain antipsychotic medications in patients with Parkinson's disease are recently added to the use-with-caution list.

Other options:

  • The Light's Criteria is used to differentiate between different causes of pleural effusions (transudative vs exudative).
  • The Jones Criteria is used for the diagnosis of acute rheumatic fever. 
  • The Duke's Criteria is used for the diagnosis of Infective Endocarditis (IE)

questions.text: A 55-year-old male patient presents with hematuria and a neovascular mass in bilateral  kidney on a CT scan, as shown below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The CT image showing renal lesions that has hypo-attenuating components consistent with macroscopic fat is highly suggestive of renal angiomyolipoma.

Angiomyolipomas are benign tumors that occur sporadically or in association with tuberous sclerosis. The mean age of presentation is 43 years and there is a female predilection. It can present as spontaneous retroperitoneal hemorrhage, especially with larger tumors. The patient can present with flank pain, palpable mass, hematuria, urinary tract infections, hypertension, or renal failure. 

Imaging in renal angiomyolipoma: Demonstration of macroscopic fat is the main part of making a diagnosis. USG may show hyperechoic lesions in the cortex with posterior acoustic shadowing. In patients with tuberous sclerosis, the entire kidney is affected and produces an echogenic appearance with loss of normal corticomedullary junction.

CT findings:

  • Cortical lesions that demonstrate macroscopic fat (less than -20 HU)
  • Absence of ossification or calcification
  • The presence of macroscopic fat is strongly suggestive of this condition, but not pathognomonic as RCC may rarely demonstrate macroscopic fat.
  • Approximately 5% may be fat-poor.

MRI: It is an excellent tool to demonstrate intramural fat components. Two sequences are used:

  • Fat-saturated techniques 
  • Phase-in and phase-out imaging that shows India ink artifacts at the junction between fat and non-fat components.

Digital subtraction angiography: They are hypervascular lesions showing a 'sunburst appearance' in the arterial phase and an 'onion peel appearance' in the venous phase.

They usually do not require any intervention. mTOR inhibitors like everolimus can be used to decrease the size of the lesion.

Other options:

Renal cell carcinoma (RCC): It is the most common malignant tumor of the kidney. It usually occurs in the age group 50-70 years and macroscopic hematuria is seen in about 60% of the cases. It is a differential for angiomyolipoma but it is important to note that macroscopic fat is almost always associated with ossification or calcification.

Renal oncocytoma: They are relatively benign in nature and usually present in the 6th to 7th decade. An important point regarding this tumor is its similarity with RCC and hence it is very difficult to differentiate between them preoperatively. A sharp central stellate scar may be seen in one-third of the cases. But RCC may also show this stellate scar appearance in some cases.

Renal cyst: It is a broader term that includes the cystic lesions of the kidney. They can be simple cysts that are benign. Complex or complicated cystic lesions needs evaluation and can be malignant. Bosniak classification of renal cysts is given above.

Image showing a simple renal cyst:

questions.text: A 7-month-old child was brought by her mother with complaints of diarrhoea and mucocutaneous lesions as shown in the image. The symptoms have been present since weaning was started. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A child with eczematous rash typically in the perioral and perineal region is characteristic of acrodermatitis enteropathica which is due to secondary zinc deficiency.

Acrodermatitis enteropathica:

  • autosomal recessive disorder seen in infants due to a defect in the intestinal zinc-specific transporter gene. 
  • classically presents while weaning from breast milk to formula, which has lower zinc bioavailability than breast milk.
  • symptoms are perioral and perineal rashes, periungual dermatitis- Beau’s lines on nails, chronic diarrhea, and alopecia.
  • present with symmetrical, eczematous plaques that become vesicular, bullous, pustular, or erosive with characteristic crusting at the edges.
  • perioral eruption usually spares the upper lip, giving it a U‐shaped or horseshoe‐shaped appearance.
  • Investigations would reveal low serum zinc.
  • Oral zinc therapy is the preferred management.(3 mg/kg/24 hour)

Option A: Wiskott Aldrich syndrome is the classical triad of thrombocytopenia, eczema and recurrent pyogenic infections. No history of bleeding rules out this option.

Option C: Epidermolysis bullosa presents as bullous lesions in pressure handling areas.

Option D: In atopic dermatitis usually the lesions will be itchy and distributed in extensor aspects (flexural in adults).

questions.text: A middle-aged man presents with progressive difficulty in swallowing for both solids and liquids for 8 months. Barium swallow done is shown below. Upper GI endoscopy and manometry are performed in this patient. Which of the following is incorrect regarding this condition?

choices.text: Loss of lower esophageal sphincter pressure causing reflux
incomplete  relaxation of the lower esophageal sphincter
It is is a primary motility disorder

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the barium swallow showing bird beak appearance is suggestive of Achalasia cardia.  The diagnostic criteria for achalasia with manometry are impaired lower esophageal sphincter (LES) relaxation and absent peristalsis with elevated LES pressure.

Achalasia is a primary esophageal motility disorder characterized by the absence of esophageal peristalsis and impaired relaxation of the lower esophageal sphincter (LES) in response to swallowing. There is incomplete(<75%) relaxation of the lower esophageal sphincter

Manometry is considered the most sensitive investigation to diagnose achalasia as it identifies early disease before esophageal dilatation and food retention.

Endoscopy is useful for ruling out pseudoachalasia.

Note: 24 hours pH monitoring is ideal and most accurate in patients with the features of gastroesophageal reflux disease.

Related Pearl: Achalasia Cardia

Achalasia is a rare disease caused by the loss of ganglion cells within the esophageal myenteric plexus.

Their absence leads to increased tone of the lower esophageal sphincter, impaired relaxation of the lower esophageal sphincter (LES), and absent peristalsis.

Achalasia is the only true motility disorder of the esophagus.

Primary achalasia is due to ganglion cell degeneration and is thought to be due to an autoimmune process attributable to latent infection with human herpes simplex virus 1 (HSV1) combined with genetic susceptibility.

Secondary achalasia may arise in Chaga's disease

Clinical features:

  • dysphagia (solid and liquid food)
  • regurgitation
  • chest pain
  • weight loss
  • bronchitis, pneumonia, or lung abscess from aspiration

Differential diagnosis: Diffuse esophageal spasm, Chagas’ disease, and pseudoachalasia

On barium swallow: Bird beak-appearance

Investigation of choice: Manometry (most sensitive)

Treatment: Pneumatic dilatation and Heller myotomy

Related Pearl: Barium swallow

Diffuse esophageal spasm: Corkscrew appearance

Feline esophagus: Transient transverse bands seen in the mid and lower esophagus on a double-contrast barium swallow. It is seen in active gastroesophageal reflux, hiatus hernia, and eosinophilic esophagitis.

Achalasia: Dilated esophagus with a retained column of barium and bird beak sign.

Zenker's diverticulum: Posterior outpouching of the hypopharynx through a weakness in the muscle layer called Killian dehiscence.

Esophageal carcinoma: Irregular narrowing, mucosal destruction, and shouldered margins.

Schatzki's ring: Thin submucosal circumferential ring in the lower esophagus at the squamocolumnar junction.

Esophageal web in a patient with Plummer Vinson syndrome. Esophageal webs are thin membranes of normal esophageal tissue consisting of mucosa and submucosa. Translucent part denotes esophageal web.

questions.text: A patient presented with pain and swelling of his left arm after a fall from height. An upper arm X-ray was done. Which nerve is most likely to be injured in this condition?
questions.solution:
In the above clinical scenario, the history and radiograph suggest a closed fracture of the shaft of the humerus. The radial nerve is commonly damaged in this condition. This is because the radial nerve follows a superficial path around the humerus and can be stretched or compressed when there is significant trauma to the upper arm. 

It manifests with wrist drop (inability to dorsiflex the wrist) and finger drop (inability to dorsiflex the digits). Numbness occurs on the dorsoradial aspect of the hand and the dorsal aspect of the radial 3 1/2 digits. 

Management of humerus shaft fractures: 

  • Conservative management using a hanging cast or U-slab for 2-3 weeks followed by functional bracing
  • Surgical fixation by compression plating, interlocking intramedullary nail, semi-flexible pins, or an external fixator is indicated in:
    • Open fractures
    • Pathological fractures
    • Unstable humeral and forearm fractures (floating elbow)
    • Radial nerve palsy

The below X-ray shows shaft of humerus fracture.

Other options:

  • The axillary nerve is most commonly injured in shoulder dislocations or fractures of the surgical neck of the humerus. 
  • The ulnar nerve is more commonly injured in conditions like elbow dislocations, fractures of the medial epicondyle of the humerus, or entrapment at the elbow (cubital tunnel syndrome). 
  • The median nerve is more frequently associated with injuries in the forearm or wrist, such as carpal tunnel syndrome, or with certain systemic conditions like pronator teres syndrome. 

Related Pearl: Fractures/dislocations and associated nerve injuries

Fracture/Dislocation Nerve injured
Fracture clavicle Brachial plexus
Anterior or inferior shoulder dislocation Axillary (circumflex humeral) nerve
Proximal humerus fracture Axillary nerve
Shaft of humerus fracture Radial nerve
Supracondylar fracture humerus  Anterior interosseous nerve > Median nerve > Radial nerve
Medial condyle of humerus  Ulnar nerve
Posterior dislocation elbow Ulnar nerve >Median nerve
Monteggia fracture Posterior interosseous nerve
Volkman’s ischemic contracture Anterior interosseous nerve
Hook of hamate fracture Deep branch of the ulnar nerve
Lunate dislocation  Median nerve
Wrist injury Median nerve
Posterior hip dislocation Sciatic nerve
Anterior dislocation of hip and shaft femur fracture Femoral nerve
Knee dislocation Common peroneal nerve
Proximal tibial fractures and ankle injury Posterior tibial nerve
Fracture neck of the fibula Lateral popliteal nerve (common peroneal nerve)

questions.text: Which of the following milestones in an infant is achieved at the earliest?
questions.solution:
The milestone which is achieved earliest in the above options is ulnar palmar grasp which is seen by 6 months of age. 

Developmental progression of the grasp:

  • At 6 months, the infant reaches and holds a larger object in a crude manner using the ulnar aspect of his hand-ulnar palmar grasp. 
  • At 8-9 months, the object is grasped by the radial side of the palm-radial palmar grasp.
  • At 9 months, the immature pincer grasp develops. The object is secured between the adducted thumb and the extended index finger.
  • At 12 months, the mature pincer grasp develops. The object is secured between the opposed thumb and the tip of the index finger.

Related Pearl: Fine motor milestones

 
Age Milestone
4 months Reaches out for objects with both hands (Bidextrous reach)
6 months
Reaches out for objects with one hand (Unidextrous reach) and transfers objects
9 months Immature pincer grasp
12 months Mature pincer grasp
15 months Imitates scribbling and builds a tower of 2 blocks
18 months Scribbles and builds a tower of 3 blocks
2 years Builds a tower of 6 blocks
3 years Builds a tower of 9 blocks and copies a circle
4 years Builds a bridge with blocks and copies a cross
5 years Copies a triangle and builds a gate with blocks

Related Pearl: Important developmental milestones at various ages

Developmental Milestones
At 1 year
  • Motor: Walks with support
  • Adaptive: Mature pincer grasp
  • Language: Speaks a few words
  • Social: Plays simple ball game
  • Domestic mimicry at 18 months
At 2 years
  • Motor: Walks up and downstairs, one step at a time
  • Adaptive: Makes a tower of 6 blocks 
  • Language: Simple sentences, a vocabulary of 50-100 words, uses pronouns at 2.5 yrs
  • Social: Asks for food and starts toilet training, listens to stories
At 3 years
  • Motor: Rides tricycle
  • Adaptive: Makes a tower of 9 blocks, handedness is established
  • Language: Knows full name, age, gender
  • Social: Plays simple games and engages in parallel play with other children
At 4 years
  • Motor: Hops
  • Adaptive: Draws square and constructs a bridge with blocks
  • Language: Tells stories
  • Social: Goes to the toilet alone
At 5 years
  • Motor: Skips
  • Adaptive: Draws a triangle
  • Language: Asks the meaning of words, names 4 colors
  • Social: Dresses and undresses

questions.text: Which of the following is contraindicated in patients with acute intermittent porphyria?
questions.solution:
Thiopentone cannot be administered in a patient with acute intermittent porphyria.

Thiopentone is a barbiturate induces aminolevulinic acid synthetase, which increases the formation of porphyrins. This will precipitate porphyria attacks, especially acute intermittent porphyria or variegate porphyria in susceptible individuals.

Other effects:

Thiopentone

  • is cerebroprotective as it reduces CSF volume by facilitating its absorption. 
  • also decreases cerebral blood flow, cerebral blood volume and helps in lowering intracranial pressure.
  • should be avoided in hypovolemic or shock patients because of the significant reduction in cardiac output (69%) and arterial blood pressure due to vasodilation and venous pooling.
  • produces dose-related central respiratory depression, producing a characteristic ventilatory pattern called 'double apnea'.

questions.text: A woman who underwent dilatation and curettage following a missed abortion now presents with amenorrhoea. Urine pregnancy test is negative. Hysterosalpingography shows the findings seen in the image below. What is your diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The history along with the moth-eaten appearance on hysterosalpingography suggests a diagnosis of Asherman syndrome.

In Asherman syndrome, oligomenorrhoea, amenorrhoea, dysmenorrhoea, abortion and infertility are seen with uterine synechiae.

The synechiae are caused by the following factors:

  • Vigorous curettage following postpartum haemorrhage or abortion
  • Tubercular endometritis
  • Uterine infections with or without intra-uterine device

Treatment involves hysteroscopic lysis of the adhesions

questions.text: A 60-year-old man with a history of COPD presents with sudden onset increased shortness of breath. His ABG analysis reveals pH - 7.24, pCO2 - 60 mm Hg, pO2- 52 mmHg, and HCO3 - 27 mmol/L. What is the most appropriate treatment for this patient?
questions.solution:
This given clinical scenario is suggestive of acute exacerbation of COPD with ABG showing respiratory acidosis. The next step for this patient would be to start non-invasive positive pressure ventilation (NIPPV).

Initial management of acute exacerbation of COPD includes:

  • Bronchodilators: Inhaled beta-agonists and muscarinic antagonists.
  • Antibiotics
  • Supplemental oxygen
  • Non-invasive positive pressure ventilation (NIPPV)

If initial NIPPV fails, then, invasive PPV may be provided. However, during the invasive PPV, the tidal volume is reduced to prevent damage to the alveolar structures. This decrease in minute ventilation causes progressive hypercapnia, which is however permitted to a certain extent for the benefit of the patient (commonly known as permissive hypercapnia).

The severity of COPD assessed by Global Initiative for Lung Disease (GOLD) is classified as:

GOLD Stage

Severity

Spirometry

I

Mild

FEV1/FVC <0.7 and FEV1 ≥80% predicted

II

Moderate

FEV1/FVC <0.7 and FEV1 ≥50% but <80% predicted

III

Severe

FEV1/FVC <0.7 and FEV1 ≥30% but <50% predicted

IV

Very severe

FEV1/FVC <0.7 and FEV1 <30% predicted

questions.text: An intern observed that a patient was unresponsive, and an ECG which was performed urgently showed an arrhythmia as below. DC shock was delivered but the arrhythmia persisted and the patient is still unresponsive. What is the next best step in the management of this patient?
questions.solution:
The patient is in cardiac arrest and the rhythm shown is ventricular fibrillation. Since one defibrillation is given and the patient is still unresponsive, CPR has to be given for 2 minutes after which the rhythm will be assessed again. 

The management of ventricular fibrillation and pulseless ventricular tachycardia is the same. Chest compressions are to be started following defibrillation.

Defibrillation involves delivering an electrical current between two pads placed on the chest so as to interrupt the disorganized cardiac activity and restore an organized cardiac rhythm. The energy that must be applied is

  • Monophasic defibrillator: 360 J
  • Biphasic defibrillator: 120-200 J

It is of utmost necessity to defibrillate at the earliest because the chances of survival decrease by 7-10% every minute without defibrillation.

 

Related Pearl: Adult Basic Life Support (BLS) Algorithm (Updated as per 2020 guidelines)

Related Pearl: High quality CPR for adults

  • Push hard: 5-6cm depth
  • Push fast: 100-120/min frequency
  • Allow for complete chest recoil
  • Minimize interruptions in compressions <10 seconds
  • Avoid excessive ventilation
  • Rotate compressor every 2 min or earlier if fatigued
  • If no advanced airway, 30:2 compression-ventilation ratio

Attempt to improve CPR quality if :

  • Quantitative waveform capnography - PETCO2 <10mmHg, 
  • Intra-arterial pressure - If relaxation phase (diastolic) pressure <20mmHg

questions.text: A 4-year-old child is brought to the emergency with a painless mass in his abdomen. Examination revealed a large, mobile abdomen mass that does not cross the midline .  What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The history of a large abdominal mass in a young child without pain is strongly suggestive of Wilms tumor (nephroblastoma).

Wilms tumor (nephroblastoma): It is the most common primary renal tumor of childhood (peaks 2-5 years of age).

Other options

  • Renal cell carcinoma is a malignant tumor of adults.
  • Angiomyolipoma may rarely be seen in children.
  • Neuroblastoma is the most common extracranial solid tumor of childhood arising from adrenal medulla; however, it presents as a painful, fixed abdominal mass, crossing the midline.

 Syndromic Associations of Wilms Tumor :

Syndrome Mutation Features
WAGR Syndrome

WT1 and PAX6 deletion on Chr11p

Genetic basis- 
Two-hit hypothesis

Wilms tumor

Aniridia

Genital anomalies

mental Retardation
Denys–Drash Syndrome

Dominant-negative missense mutation of WT1 protein

 

Genetic basis- 
Two-hit hypothesis

Gonadal dysgenesis (male pseudo-hermaphroditism)

Early-onset nephropathy

Gonadoblastoma
Beckwith– Wiedemann Syndrome

IGF-2 overexpression on WT2 region

Genetic basis- 
Genomic imprinting

Organomegaly

Macroglossia

Hemihypertrophy

Omphalocele

Adrenal cytomegaly

Hepatoblastoma, Pancreato-blastoma, Adrenocortical tumors, and Rhabdomyosarcoma

Note: Wilms tumor 1 (WT1) protein is a transcriptional activator of genes involved in normal renal and gonadal development. Therefore, genitourinary abnormalities are commonly associated with WT1 gene mutations.

questions.text: Four patients were brought to the casualty after sustaining trauma. Which of the following is the correct match of injuries and signs among the following?

choices.text: Extra dural hemorrhage (EDH)- Pin point pupil
Penetrating injury to eustachian tube- CSF otorrhea
Penetrating injury to eye- Battle sign

questions.solution:
Gaze paresis- Mid-brain lesion, is the correctly matched pair among the given options.

Traumatic injury to the brain affecting the mid-brain or brainstem dysfunction produces:

  • Gaze paresis - Inability of the eye to look across beyond the midline.
  • Dysconjugate gaze - Inability of the eyes to work together.
  • Roving eye movements.

Battle sign and CSF rhinorrhea are features of a middle cranial fossa fracture.

Middle cranial fossa fracture is associated with:

  • CSF otorrhea or rhinorrhea
  • Hemotympanum
  • Ossicular disruption
  • Battle sign: Bruising behind the ear
  • 7th and 8th cranial nerve palsies

A double target sign is seen in patients with CSF rhinorrhea. The nasal discharge in a patient with CSF rhinorrhea after head trauma is mixed with blood. When this discharge is collected on a filter paper, it shows a double target sign with a central red spot and a peripheral lighter halo as seen in the image below. 

The image below shows the 'battle' sign.

Anterior cranial fossa fracture is associated with:

  • Subconjunctival hematoma
  • CSF rhinorrhea
  • Periorbital hematoma or “Raccoon eyes”

Periorbital ecchymosis (raccoon eyes): Pooling of blood surrounding the eyes, associated with fractures of the anterior cranial fossa (given below). 

The pinpoint pupil is seen in patients with pontine hemorrhage and opioid overdose.

questions.text: A 37-week primigravida has mild labor pains for 20 hours and the cervix is persistently 1 cm dilated but non-effaced. What would be the appropriate management?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of either prolonged latent phase. The appropriate management is to sedate the patient and wait.

The first stage of labour consists of two phases :

  1. Latent phase: It is considered to begin at the time the woman first perceives regular uterine contractions and is characterized by gradual cervical change (up to 5 cm of cervical dilatation).
  2. Active phase: This follows the latent phase and is characterized by regular painful uterine contractions, cervical effacement, and rapid cervical dilatation from 5 cm to full dilatation.

A latent phase that exceeds 20 hours in primigravidae or 14 hours in multiparae is termed as a prolonged latent phase of labour. Bed rest is the preferred treatment unless there is any indication for expediting the delivery.

The presence of false labour pains for a long time may be confused with a prolonged latent phase. The differences between them include

Features True labour pains False labour pains
Cervical dilatation and effacement Present Absent
Pain Lower abdomen and back, radiating to thighs Lower abdomen only
Show Present Absent
Bag of water Formed Absent
Relief with enema No Yes

Augmentation with oxytocin is done only in those patients who even after therapeutic rest continue to be in a prolonged latent phase. There is no indication of the cesarean section unless cephalopelvic disproportion is present. Amniotomy is not useful and should be avoided in patients with prolonged latent phases due to the risk of infections.

Related Pearl: Abnormalities of first stage of labor

Labor pattern Criteria- Nullipara Criteria-Multipara Treatment
Prolonged latent phase >20 hrs >14hrs

Bed rest

Oxytocin or cesarean delivery 
Protraction of dilatation <1.2cm/hr 1.5cm/hr

Expectant management and support

Cesarean delivery for CPD
Protraction of descent <1cm/hr <2cm/hr
Secondary arrest of dilatation >2hr >2hr

Check for CPD:

If no CPD- administer oxytocin

If CPD present- cesarean delivery

 
Arrest of descent >1hr >1hr
 CPD- Cephalopelvic disproportion

Related Pearl: Partograph

Partograph types:

WHO Modified Partograph (2000)

  • No latent phase
  • Vaginal examination: This should be done no less than every 4 hours to assess cervical dilatation, descent of the fetal head, and moulding of skull bones. More frequent examination is only undertaken if indicated.
  • Charting starts at 4 cm of cervical dilation.
  • Colour of liquor mentioned as C-clear, B-blood stained, M-meconium stained.
  • Moulding mentioned:
    • bones are separated and sutures can be easily felt - (0)
    • bones touching (1+)
    • bones overlapping but can be reduced(2+)
    • bones severely overlapping and irreducible ( 3+).
  • Alert line reflects the average rate of cervical dilation of the slowest quintile of term primigravidas, if dilation slows or ceases, the partograph plot will cross the alert line.
  • Alert line: at 4 cm dilation and expected dilation of 1 cm/hour.
  • Action line is 2–4 hours after the alert line, which prompts interventions to accelerate labor or perform cesarean delivery.
  • Higher rates of perinatal mortality are associated with delays of 4 hours or more after the alert line.
  • Contractions measured for a span of 10 min (duration noted) and measured every 30 min (1 square = half hour).
  • Pulse: record every 30 minutes and mark with a dot (•).
  • Blood pressure: record every 4 hours and mark with arrows, unless the patient has a hypertensive disorder or pre-eclampsia, in which case record every 30 minutes.
  • Temperature: record every 4 hours.

WHO Composite Partograph: It is same as modified except for it has latent phase and charting done at 3 cm.

WHO Simplified Partograph: WHO further modified the partograph for use by skilled attendants in health centers. This simplified partograph is colour coded.

  • The area to the left of the alert line in the cervicograph is coloured green, representing normal progress.
  • The area to the right of the action line is coloured red, indicating dangerously slow progress in labour.
  • The area in between the alert and action line is coloured amber, indicating the need for greater vigilance.

questions.text: An 18-year-old female patient comes with the following findings. Which of the following is pathognomic of the primary stage of this disease?
questions.solution:
Comedones are pathognomic of the primary stage.

Acne is a polymorphic inflammatory disease of the pilosebaceous unit, frequently affecting the face, back, and chest. Comedonal lesions are the earliest lesions of acne. They represent the keratin plugs of the pilosebaceous duct. When the keratin plug is inside the follicle, it is called a closed comedone (Whitehead). When the keratin plug is exposed to the environment, it gets oxidized by the air and turns black which is known as an open comedone (blackhead).

Precipitating factors include:

  • Lifestyle and environmental factors, diet, BMI, smoking and alcohol use, menstrual cycle, stress, and sleep deprivation
  • Drugs like corticosteroids, anticonvulsants, etc

The severity of acne according to lesion type and extent:

Type of acne Description
1. Comedonal

- Non‐inflamed lesions
- Open comedones/blackheads
- Closed (whiteheads) comedones
2. Mild

- Non‐inflamed lesions
- Inflammatory lesions <5 mm
3. Moderate

- Non‐inflamed lesions
- Papulopustular lesions
4. Severe

- Deep-seated inflammatory lesions
- Nodules and deep pustules
- Small nodules are >5 mm; large nodules are >1 cm
- Painful lesions with exudative sinus tracts, disfiguring tissue destruction, and scarring

Acne conglabata:

- Multiple-grouped comedones
- Papules, tender inflammatory nodules of varying sizes, suppurative and coalesce to form sinus tract
- Extensive scarring

Assessment of acne includes:

  • Leed's photometric grading scale
  • Comprehensive acne severity system (CASS)

Management: 

  • Mild acne - 
    • Comedonal acne - topical retinoid
    • Papular and pustular acne - topical retinoid and topical antibiotics
  • Moderate papular or pustular acne and nodular acne - oral antibiotic + topical retinoid ± benzoyl peroxide
  • Severe nodular and conglobate acne - oral isotretinoin
  • Other therapies -  topical niacinamide, salicylic acid, chemical peels, lasers, and photodynamic therapy
  • Novel drugs - 
    • Drugs that target both retinoic acid receptors -beta and -gamma - 
      • Adapalene
      • Tazarotene 
      • Tretinoin
    • Topical androgen receptor inhibitor - 1% clascoterone cream

Related Pearl: Global Alliance Algorithm for Acne Treatment

Global Alliance Algorithm for Acne Treatment

Image: Global Alliance Algorithm for Improving Outcomes in acne

BPO - Benzoyl peroxide

questions.text: A patient is brought to the OPD with complaints of speaking nonsensical and made-up words. However, his speech is easy and fluent. His family claims his speech was fine until a few hours back. Which type of aphasia does the patient most likely have?
questions.solution:
The patient is most likely suffering from fluent aphasia/ Wernicke's aphasia. The speech is easy and fluent but there are difficulties related to the output of language like paraphasia (substitution of similar-sounding, non-words, or incorrect words) and neologisms (non-existent words).

It is a type of aphasia that is seen in the lesions of the posterior part of the superior temporal gyrus due to the involvement of the Wernicke's area. The speech is full of jargon and neologisms that make little sense.

Other options: 

Option B- Broca's or motor/non-fluent aphasia is seen in lesions of the inferior frontal gyrus which contains the motor speech area. Speech is non-fluent and interrupted, with a paucity of functional words.

Option C- Comprehension of written language and the ability to name objects are compromised in anomic aphasia. This aphasia is caused by damage to the angular gyrus that disrupts visual information processing and transmission to the Wernicke area.

Option D- Conduction aphasia is seen in lesions of the arcuate fasciculus, the bundle of nerve fibers connecting the Wernicke and Broca's areas. Repetition of words is impaired and paraphasias are observed, though not as much as in Wernicke aphasia.

Related Pearl: Aphasias and Related Conditions

  Comprehension Repetition of Spoken language Naming Fluency
Wernicke's Impaired Impaired Impaired Preserved
Broca's Preserved Impaired Impaired Decreased
Global Impaired Impaired Impaired Decreased
Conduction Preserved Impaired Impaired Preserved
Anterior (nonfluent) transcortical Preserved Preserved Impaired Impaired
Posterior (fluent) transcortical Impaired Preserved Impaired Preserved
Isolation Impaired Echolalia Impaired No purposeful speech
Anomic Preserved Preserved Impaired Preserved except for word finding pauses
Pure Word Deafness Impaired only for spoken language Impaired Preserved Preserved
Pure Alexia Impaired only for reading Preserved Preserved  Preserved

questions.text: What is the diagnosis if the axis is on the mark "?" from the diagram shown below?
questions.solution:
The image shows the cardiac axis greater than +100 degrees and thus it shows right axis deviation. 

The cardiac axis represents the mean QRS axis (direction of mean depolarization vector).

The normal adult QRS axis is directed downward and to the left, which is between -30 degrees and +100 degrees.

The position of lead aVF is at +90 degrees (shown in the image below). If the cardiac axis is also at +90 degrees, it would be in the same direction as lead aVF and hence aVF would show maximum R wave amplitude.

If the mean axis is:

  • More negative than –30 degrees- left axis deviation
  • More positive than +100 degrees- right axis deviation
  • Lies between -90 to +180 degrees- extreme axis deviation

The image below shows the position of lead aVF with respect to the normal cardiac axis and the axis deviations.

questions.text: While performing the USG assessment of a woman at 28 weeks of gestation, you note her amniotic fluid index to be 12.8. When does this parameter reach its maximum value in a normal pregnancy?
questions.solution:
The amniotic fluid index (AFI) is a measure of the amniotic volume which is maximum at 34 weeks of gestation.

The volume of amniotic fluid each week is variable. The volume gradually increases till 32-34 weeks of gestation. At 34 weeks, it is maximum and thereafter it starts declining till term. 

Amniotic fluid volume is a passive reflector of the fetal condition. Its volume is determined by the following:

Pathway  Volume in ml
Fetal urination +1000 
Fetal swallowing -750
Fetal lung fluid secretion +350
Intramembranous flow across fetal vessels on the placental surface -400

Early in pregnancy, amnionic fluid arises mainly from a transudate of plasma either from the fetal skin or across the uterine decidua and placenta. Fetal urine production becomes a major component in the second trimester.

Any alteration in fetal homeostasis, caused by fetal and maternal conditions, affects the amniotic fluid volume. Thus, AFI is measured as a part of the biophysical score.

questions.text: A newborn baby presents with irritability and cyanosis which subsides on crying. On examination, you are unable to pass a nasogastric tube and no mist formation is noted on the laryngeal mirror test. Which of the following is the best next step in management?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of choanal atresia, the best next step would be to provide an oropharyngeal airway.

Choanal atresia is the persistence of the bucconasal membrane, unilateral is more common and may remain undiagnosed until adult life, bilateral atresia will present as a respiratory obstruction in the newborn. The initial clinical evaluation consists of placing a large laryngeal mirror under each nostril and checking for fogging, this is known as the laryngeal mirror test.

Diagnosis can be made by:

  • Presence of mucoid discharge in the nose
  • Absence of air bubbles in the nasal discharge
  • Failure to pass a catheter from the nose to the pharynx
  • Putting methylene blue dye into the nose and checking its passage to the pharynx
  • Putting a radio-opaque dye into the nose and taking a lateral radiograph
  • CT in the axial plane 

Management: In bilateral atresia, emergency treatment is to provide an airway, which is done by McGovern's technique- (a feeding tube with a large hole that provides a good oral airway), this removes the need for tracheostomy. Definitive treatment is correcting the atresia either by transpalatal or transnasal approach, which is usually done at one and a half years of age.

Related Pearl: Choanal atresia

  • It is due to the persistence of bucconasal membrane which separates primitive oropharynx from the primitive nasopharynx
  • Unilateral > bilateral
  • 30% of cases are bony and 70% are mixed
  • Unilateral cases may be asymptomatic and present in adult life
  • Bilateral cases are life-threatening and present with respiratory distress
  • Associated with CHARGE syndrome
    • C- Coloboma of the eye
    • H- Heart defects
    • A- Atresia of choana
    • R- Retarded growth and development
    • G- Genital anomalies
    • E- Ear anomalies and hearing loss.
  • CT scan is the best investigation

Image: Membranous, bilateral choanal atresia in a newborn

 

 

  • McGoverns technique- A feeding nipple with a large hole provides a good oral airway
  • Definitive treatment consists of correction of atresia by a trans-nasal or trans-palatal approach.

questions.text: During the normal delivery of a primigravida with polyhydramnios, the intern prematurely removes the placenta, leading to profuse bleeding. Examination reveals an intact placenta and that the uterus is partly outside the introitus. The patient is in hemorrhagic shock, so initial resuscitative measures are taken. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical picture is suggestive of uterine inversion and it is the most likely cause of shock immediately after delivery.

Uterine inversion:

  • A rare cause of postpartum collapse, acute in onset, and occurs immediately after delivery.
  •  Profuse bleeding after a premature attempt to remove the placenta and the development of shock immediately after delivery with the uterus partially outside the introitus is suggestive of uterine inversion.

Causes:

  • Mismanagement of 3rd stage of labor - Delivering a yet to be separated placenta (Creede’s method): Most common
  • Spontaneous
  • Placenta accreta.

Features:

  • Shock immediately after delivery, degree of shock out of proportion to the amount of bleeding,
  • Shock is both neurogenic and hemorrhagic.
  • Per abdomen examination: Fundus of the uterus is felt to be absent. 

Management:

Vaginal operations

 Abdominal operations

 Hydrostatic  method

Kustner

Huntingtons

O sullivan

Spinelli

Haultain

Oguch

Amniotic fluid embolism causes shock but not immediately.

questions.text: A young male who had a road traffic accident is brought to the emergency department. His left leg is shortened, internally rotated, and adducted. On examination, femoral artery pulsation is not felt. A plain radiograph of his hip was taken which is shown below. What is your diagnosis?

choices.text: Fracture neck of femur with injury to femoral vessels
Anterior dislocation of hip with femoral artery injury

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of posterior hip dislocation. In this condition, the leg will be in flexion, adduction, and internal rotation. 

Posterior hip dislocation is the commonest type of hip dislocation accounting for about 80%  of the cases. It is commonly seen following dashboard injuries. The patient presents with flexion, adduction, and an internal rotation deformity.

Radiological findings include femoral head lying above and behind the acetabulum, femoral head appearing smaller than normal, lesser trochanter not visualized as the thigh is internally rotated and the femoral head and posterior acetabular wall fractures may also be seen

Sciatic nerve injury is seen in 10-20 % of cases with posterior hip dislocation. It is usually a neuropraxia type of injury and resolves spontaneously. The femoral artery pulsation is usually felt against the neck of the femur. Due to the posterior dislocation of the hip joint, the femoral vessels fall backwards and the pulsation of the femoral artery cannot be felt. This is called the vascular sign of Narath.

Anterior hip dislocation is less common than posterior hip dislocations and accounts for about 10-20% of all hip dislocations. This injury is usually sustained following a high-energy accident. The affected limb in this condition will be abducted, externally rotated, and slightly flexed.

Note: Although, vascular injuries are seen in posterior dislocations as well, they are most likely with anterior dislocation. This is because of the femoral artery lying anterior to the head

questions.text: A patient came to the hospital with complaints of lethargy, increased sleep, and weight gain. Investigations revealed low plasma TSH concentration, low T3, low T4.  However, on the ​administration of TRH, the TSH levels increased. Which of the following conditions is likely in this patient?

choices.text: Hyperthyroidism due to disease in the pituitary
Hypothyroidism due to disease in the pituitary
Hypothyroidism due to disease in the hypothalamus
Hyperthyroidism due to disease in the hypothalamus

questions.solution:
The given clinical features are suggestive of hypothyroidism and the TSH levels are low due to low levels of TRH. This is based on the fact that the administration of TRH increased the TSH levels. Hence, the patient has hypothyroidism due to disease in the hypothalamus.

Normally, the thyrotropin-releasing hormone (TRH) is released by the hypothalamus. It stimulates the pituitary gland to release the thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH), which in turn stimulates the thyroid gland to produce T3 and T4 hormones. 

Symptoms and signs in decreasing order of frequency are given below:

Symptoms

Signs
  • Tiredness, weakness
  • Dry skin
  • Cold intolerance
  • Hair loss
  • Difficulty concentrating and poor memory
  • Constipation
  • Weight gain with poor appetite
  • Dyspnea
  • Hoarse voice
  • Menorrhagia (later oligomenorrhea or amenorrhea)
  • Paresthesia
  • Impaired hearing
  • Dry coarse skin, cool peripheral extremities
  • Puffy face, hands, and feet (myxedema)
  • Diffuse alopecia
  • Bradycardia
  • Peripheral edema
  • Delayed tendon reflex relaxation
  • Carpal tunnel syndrome
  • Serous cavity effusions

Treatment is by levothyroxine replacement and their clinical effects are slow to appear. Patients may not experience full relief from symptoms until 3–6 months after normal TSH levels are restored.

If there is no residual function, the daily replacement dose of levothyroxine is usually 1.6 μg/kg body weight (typically 100–150 μg), ideally taken at least 30 minutes before breakfast.

TSH responses are gradual and should be determined 2 months following the initiation of treatment or change in dose. Once the full replacement is achieved and TSH levels are stable, TSH measurement is recommended at annual intervals.

questions.text: You see a middle-aged man presenting to the psychiatry OPD who reports aliens have been speaking to him and telling him to kill his relatives over the past 7 months. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The patient has had auditory hallucinations for the past 7 months, which makes the diagnosis of schizophrenia more likely of the given options.

Diagnostic criteria for schizophrenia (DSM-5):

1. The DSM-5 criteria to diagnose schizophrenia require a total duration of 6 months.

2. Within this 6-month period, there must be at least 1-month overt psychotic symptoms where 2 or more of the following have to be present. And at least one must be delusion, hallucination or disorganised speech.

  1. Delusion
  2. Hallucination
  3. Disorganized speech (or formal thought disorder)
  4. Disorganized behaviour
  5. Affective flattening or other negative symptoms

A mood disorder & substance abuse should be excluded first.

This person has come to seek medical care for hearing voices of aliens (not thoughts or beliefs)which is telling him to kill his relatives, causing impairment. These are consistent with schizophrenia.

Other options:

Option A: Mania: Mania is a key feature of bipolar disorder, characterized by an elevated mood, increased energy levels, and racing thoughts. Persistent auditory hallucinations commanding the individual to harm others is not typically seen in mania alone. Additionally, the duration of 7 months suggests a more chronic and enduring condition, which is not consistent with a typical manic episode.

Option B: Delusional disorder: Delusional disorder involves the presence of one or more persistent delusions without the significant impairment of other cognitive functions or the presence of hallucinations. 

Option D: Brief psychotic disorder: Brief psychotic disorder is characterized by the sudden onset of psychotic symptoms, such as hallucinations, delusions, disorganized speech, or behavior, that last for less than one month. 

Related Pearl: Psychotic disorders

Differential diagnosis of DSM-5 psychotic disorders

Psychotic disorder

 Criteria for diagnosis
Brief psychotic disorder

Sudden onset and a full return to function

Duration: > 1 day and < 1 month
Schizophreniform disorder

Same symptoms as schizophrenia and functional decline not required

Duration: > 1 month & < 6 months
Schizophrenia

Requires functional decline

At least 6 months (includes at least 1 month of active symptoms, can include prodromal and residual periods)
Schizoaffective disorder

With concurrent mood episode. Active-phase symptoms of schizophrenia with at least a 2 weeks of lifetime history of delusions or hallucinations in absence of prominent mood symptoms
Delusional disorder

One or more delusions for > 1 month

No other psychotic symptoms and normal functioning apart from the direct impact of delusions
Shared psychotic disorder (folie a deux)

Development of delusions in a person who is in a close relationship (ex: spouse, child) with someone who has a delusional disorder (the inducer)

questions.text: Which of the following autoantibody isotype is involved in the pathogenesis of Acute inflammatory Demyelinating Polyneuropathy (AIDP)?
questions.solution:
IgG isotype of autoantibody is involved in the pathogenesis of Acute inflammatory Demyelinating Polyneuropathy (AIDP), which is a type of Guillian Barre syndrome (GBS).

IgM isotype autoantibodies are known to play a role in some types of chronic immune neuropathies.

Antibodies seen in GBS:

Type Antibody
Acute inflammatory demyelinating polyneuropathy (AIDP) Anti GM1
Acute motor axonal neuropathy (AMAN) Anti GD1a
Acute motor sensory axonal neuropathy (AMSAN) Anti GD1a
Miller Fisher syndrome Anti GQ1b

questions.text: An infant was brought to the OPD with complaints of poor feeding and irritability. On examination, neck rigidity was present. Her sister has been on antitubercular therapy for 2 months. What are the CSF analysis findings expected in this child?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario, along with a neck stiffness and contact with patient of tuberculosis is suggestive of TB meningitis. The CSF picture is lymphocytosis, with low sugar and high protein

Tuberculous meningitis is the most severe form of tuberculosis.

Predisposing factors

  • Young age
  • Household contact
  • Recent measles
  • Protein-energy malnutrition

After the initial infection, the disease presents with vague symptoms accompanied by intermittent bacillemia. These feed the meninges forming Rich's foci. When the body's immunity is lowered during stress or coinfections, these ruptures cause widespread meningitis

Clinical Features

  • Prodromal phase: irregular fever, anorexia, irritability and occasional vomiting. These could last 1 to 4 weeks
  • The second stage has the nervous system involvement, with seizures, focal deficits and meningeal signs.
  • The third stage is one of coma and sequelae like Hydrocephalus (communicating or obstructive), decerebrate posturing, cranial nerve palsies, optic atrophy, extrapyramidal signs, and focal deficits.

Diagnosis:

  • CSP typically shows raised pressure, lymphocytic predominance, high protein, and low sugar
  • Imaging can show exudates and if present, features of the sequelae
  • The diagnosis is confirmed detection of tubercular bacilli in CSF. This can be by culture or cartridge-based tests like Gene Xpert

Treatment includes antitubercular treatment with two months of four drug-intensive therapy(HRZE) and 10 months of two-drug (maintenance) therapy  Sometimes, intravenous is dexamethasone is followed by oral administered for 8-12 weeks. This is to prevent sequelae of TB.. Patients with severe hydrocephalus may require shunts or ventriculostomy

questions.text: A man brings his father who became unconscious while working in a field in the hot sun at 42 degrees Celsius in May. On examination, there were no physical signs of dehydration. His serum electrolyte values were normal. The physician found that the body temperature was 106 F. Which of the following symptoms is least likely to be seen in this patient?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a patient is highly suggestive of heatstroke. The symptom least likely to be seen in this patient is sweating.

Heatstroke occurs due to the failure of the heat regulation center of the hypothalamus. The person fails to lose heat by cutaneous circulation and sweating. It is likely to develop when the body temperature rises to a range of 105°F to 108°F. The predisposing factors include high temperature, increased humidity, minor infections, old age, and physical activity

Heatstroke can be:

  • Exertion-induced heat stroke is seen in people with prolonged exposure to or physical exertion in high temperatures, usually without adequate training.
  • Sedentary heatstroke is a disease of elderly or infirm people whose cardiovascular systems are unable to adapt to the stress of a hot environment and release sufficient heat such that body temperature rises.

It is a medical emergency that leads to homeostatic imbalance. The symptoms include dizziness, abdominal distress, vomiting, delirium, and eventually leading to loss of consciousness. On examination, the skin is dry, hot, and flushed, with a complete absence of sweating (anhidrosis). Other signs seen in heat stroke are tachycardia, Kussmaul-type rapid deep breathing (tachypnea), hypotension, cardiac failure, dizziness, muscle cramping, confusion, and seizures. Heatstroke can cause damage to multiple organ systems, including the brain, kidneys, and liver, which can lead to life-threatening complications. It is essential to initiate rapid cooling and supportive care measures to prevent permanent injury or death. The cooling methods used to treat heatstroke include:

Although there is no single specific diagnostic test, clinical features of exposure to heat stress, CNS dysfunction, and core temperature >104.9o Fahrenheit (> 40.5 degrees Celsius) help establish the preliminary diagnosis. The body temperature must be measured rectally.

Treatment includes rapidly cooling the body with ice water till the rectal temperature falls below 102oF.

Autopsy findings include the presence of edema and reduction of Purkinje's cells in the cerebellum.

Related Pearl: Hyperthermic disorders

Hyperthermic disorders Mechanisms
Heat edema Cutaneous vasodilation and pooling of interstitial fluid leads to swelling of hands, feet, and ankles
Heat syncope Vasodilation and volume depletion(from sweating) following exercise or prolonged standing with consequent systemic and cerebral hypotension
Heat cramps Deficiency of sodium, potassium, and water at an intracellular level, leading to intermittent, painful, and involuntary spasmodic contractions of skeletal muscles
Heat exhaustion

Results from prolonged strenuous activity. There is water or salt depletion, but thermoregulatory mechanisms are maintained. Temperature < 40.5° C
Heatstroke

Thermoregulatory mechanisms are lost

Temperature > 40.5° C

questions.text: A mother complains that her child is reluctant when it comes to taking feeds appropriately. Her 15-month-old boy has a length-for-age ≤ –2 SD below the median. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This child with a length-for-age ≤ –2 SD below the median is having moderate stunting.

The anthropometric measures used are weight for age, height for age, weight for height, BMI, and mid-upper arm circumference.

  • Low weight for height, or wasting, indicates acute malnutrition. It is also called as wasting as a result of a recent food deficit or an acute illness such as diarrhea.
  • High weight-for-height indicates overweight.
  • Low height-for-age, or stunting, indicates chronic malnutrition. This is the best indicator of long-term nutritional status in the pediatric population. 
  • Low weight for age, or underweight indicates acute or chronic malnutrition. It does not differentiate between wasting and stunting. Hence, it has limited clinical significance.

Mid-upper arm circumference (MUAC) is an age-independent parameter used for screening wasting in children. Classification of nutritional status depending on the anthropometry (height/length for age) is given in the pearl below.

Related Pearl: World Health Organization (WHO) classification of nutritional status of infants and children

Weight-for-height/length >3 SD

SD - Standard deviation (from the median)

questions.text: A 30-year-old male is admitted to the hospital with complains of fever and cough since 4 days. He is oriented to time, place, and person. His respiratory rate is 35/min, BP is 130/90 and serum urea is found to be within normal limits. What is the CURB-65 score in this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient with a most likely diagnosis of pneumonia has a CURB-65 score of 1 (RR>30/min). The patient can be best managed by a respiratory fluoroquinolone - moxifloxacin in the inpatient Non-ICU category.

The CURB-65 criteria are used to assess the severity of pneumonia. The CURB-65 criteria include five variables (1 point for each variable):

  • Confusion 
  • Blood Urea Nitrogen (BUN) >7 mmol/L
  • Respiratory rate ≥30/min 
  • Blood pressure, systolic ≤90 mmHg or diastolic ≤60 mmHg 
  • Age ≥65 years.

Management:

  • 0 point: Treat as an outpatient
  • 1 to 2 points: Admitted to the hospital- Non-ICU
  • ≥3 points: ICU admission

questions.text: A 20 year old man presents with pain in the thigh. Pain is worse at night and is relieved by aspirin. X ray demonstrates  a bone lesion. What is the lesion?
questions.solution:
The image shows presence of metadiaphyseal cortical osteoid osteoma involving the upper end of the femur with radiolucent nidus surrounded by cortical sclerosis.

Nidus of osteoid osteoma is present in the cortex and hence CT scan will be the best investigation to diagnose osteoid osteoma.

  • White arrow - Cortical sclerosis
