questions.text: Epidural anesthesia involves local anesthetic administration between
questions.solution:
Epidural anesthesia involves local anesthetic administration between the dura and ligamentum flavum.

Subdural injection (seen in a failed spinal anesthesia) is between dura and arachnoid.

Spinal anesthesia (subarachnoid block, intrathecal block) involves local anesthetic administration between the pia and arachnoid mater.

In spinal anesthesia, the local anesthetic is injected into CSF, which bathes the nerve root. Hence, a relatively small dose and volume of local anesthetic is sufficient to achieve dense sensory and motor blockade.

questions.text: All of the following are true about audit in obstetrics except:

choices.text: Change in hospital administration and practices
Should be done before analyzing outcomes

questions.solution:
A clinical audit is done to ascertain if healthcare is being provided in line with set standards and lets care providers and patients know where their service is doing well, and where there could be improvements. As it is done to analyze the current level of care against standard practices, it is usually studied after analyzing data and selecting a topic that requires quality improvement and not before analyzing outcomes.
 
In audits or quality improvement initiatives, collecting data related to patient care and outcomes (like fetal death) can help improve treatment practices by making changes to hospital administration and current practice.

questions.text: A 73 old male smoker with a past history of coronary artery disease presents with blackening of the toes. An image of the foot is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of an elderly smoker with past history of coronary artery disease and gangrene of the first three toes is likely to have atherosclerosis. 

Atherosclerosis is a chronic inflammatory disease in which there is a build-up of plaques inside arteries.  It is common after 50 years.These plaques are principally composed of lipids that induce an inflammatory reaction causing turbulent flow leading to atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease(ASCVD). This results in atheroma formation in arteries throughout the body hampering the blood flow and leading to ischemia. 

Risk factors include smoking, hypertension, diabetes, and elevated cholesterol. The infrarenal part of the abdominal aorta, coronary arteries, iliofemoral vessels, carotid bifurcation, and popliteal arteries are the common arteries involved. The presence of atherosclerotic disease in one part of the body suggests there could be blockade in other parts as well. 

Patients with chronic limb ischemia present with rest pain and tissue loss such as gangrene and ulceration. An ischemic ulcer is painful, pale, and cyanotic in appearance with absent pulsations. It may be associated with transient ischemic attacks, chest pain, eye problems, mesenteric ischemia, and altered renal function.

Doppler or angiogram can be done to identify the block. It is important to evaluate these patients for intercurrent cardiac disorders.

Management involves cessation of smoking and modification of other risk factors such as hypertension, diabetes, and hypercholesterolemia. High-intensity statins should be given irrespective of cholesterol levels in ASCVD. Other drugs that can be used include pentoxifylline, aspirin, clopidogrel, and cilostazol. Surgical options include thrombectomy, endarterectomy, bypass grafting, and amputations if the limb is gangrenous. 

Complications of atherosclerosis include

  • Narrowing of the arteries: Coronary, cerebral, renal, mesenteric, iliofemoral. > 70% narrowing (severe) causes reduced blood flow.
  • lschaemia, ulcerations, gangrene 
  • Embolism: From atheromatous plaques
  • Aneurysm formation: Mainly abdominal aorta and also in peripheral arteries

Option A: Buerger’s disease is a progressive nonatherosclerotic segmental inflammatory disease that most often affects small- and medium-sized arteries, veins, and nerves of the upper and lower extremities.

  • Typically presents in young male smokers, with symptoms beginning prior to age 40.
  • Patients initially present with the foot, leg, arm, or hand.
  • Claudication may progress to rest pain to calf claudication and eventually ischemic rest pain and ulcerations on the toes, feet, or fingers and even gangrene.

If the patient continues to smoke, the disease progresses into the collaterals, blocking them eventually, leading to severe ischemia which is called decompensatory peripheral vascular disease/ critical limb ischemia which presents as rest pain, ulceration, and gangrene.

Option C: Raynaud's disease usually occurs in females and affects bilateral upper limbs. Patients present with pallor/blanching (syncope), dusky cyanosis (asphyxia), and rubor/painful red de-engorgement (recovery). Peripheral pulses are normal.

Option D: Giant cell arteritis is characterized by giant cell infiltration of the arterial wall (giant cell arteritis) involving superficial temporal, facial, retinal, upper limb, coronary and vertebral arteries. Patients present with severe headaches, visual abnormalities, jaw claudication, and a tender superficial temporal artery.

Related Pearl: Ankle–brachial Pressure Index (ABPI)

The ankle-brachial Pressure Index (ABPI) is the ratio of systolic pressure at the ankle to that in the arm.

The numerator is the highest pressure in the dorsalis pedis, posterior tibial, or peroneal artery and the denominator is the highest brachial systolic pressure.

ABPI Reading Interpretation
>0.91 < 1.3 Normal
<0.9 Diagnostic of occlusive arterial disease in patients with symptoms of claudication or other signs of ischemia
0.5 to 0.9 Arterial obstruction often associated with claudication
<0.3 Critical limb ischemia (multilevel obstruction i.e any combination of iliac, femoral or tibial vessel disease and may be associated with non-healing ulcerations, ischemic rest pain, or pedal gangrene.
>1.4 Signifies poor compressibility of the arteries. Mostly due to calcification because of increased age, diabetes etc.

Note: A fall in the resting ABPI of more than 20% after exercise is indicative of arterial disease.

questions.text: A patient received a tubal block and is scheduled for laparoscopy. Identify the instrument used in this procedure.
questions.solution:
Veress needle is used to produce pneumoperitoneum in laparoscopic surgery.

The closed method using the Veress needle has a small but significant potential for intestinal or vascular injury on the introduction of the needle or trocar. Proper placement of the needle can be determined by the inability to re-aspirate injected saline. The normal insufflation rate is 4-6 litres/min.

Insufflation of the abdomen is accomplished with a Veress needle held at its serrated collar with the thumb and forefinger.
Because the linea alba is fused to the umbilicus, the abdominal wall is grasped with fingers or penetrating towel clip to elevate the abdominal wall away from the underlying structures. (As shown below)

Other options:

Option A: The image given below is that of a Hasson trocar which is used in the open method of creating pneumoperitoneum.To achieve this, a 1 cm vertical or transverse incision is made at the level of the umbilicus, stay sutures are applied, and the fascia is dissected. Free penetration into the abdominal cavity is confirmed by the gentle introduction of a finger. A Hasson trocar, shown below, is inserted and anchored, and pneumoperitoneum is created. This is the Hasson or modified Hasson approach. This avoids the morbidity related to a blind puncture. 

Option C: Leech Wilkinson's Cannula is dipicted below.It can be identified by the spiral cone at the tip and is used for hysterosalpingography.Hysterosalpingography (HSG) is a technique used for visualization of the uterine cavity and fallopian tubes by the injection of a radiopaque dye, and visualization of the dye by fluoroscopy as it passes through the uterine cavity and fallopian tubes.

Option D: Whitacre Needle dipicted below and it is a Dura Splitting Needle. Dura-splitting needles include Sprotte, Whitacre, and Greene. They have a pencil-point, rounded and conical tip which splits the layers of dura. Thus, the loss of CSF is reduced and PDPH is lesser with these needles

questions.text: Which of the following radioactive isotopes is used for teletherapy?
questions.solution:
Cobalt-60 emits high-energy gamma rays and is commonly used in radiation therapy machines called cobalt units or teletherapy units. These units deliver radiation from outside the body, targeting the tumor.

Other options:

A) Iodine-125: This radioactive isotope is commonly used in brachytherapy for treating prostate cancer. It emits low-energy gamma rays that can effectively target and treat the cancerous tissue.

C) I-131 is a beta-emitter that is taken up by thyroid tissue as well as differentiated thyroid cancers and is used for systemic radiotherapy.

D) Iridium-192: This is a commonly used radioactive isotope in brachytherapy. It emits high-energy gamma rays and is used for treating various types of cancer, such as cervical, prostate, and breast cancer. Iridium-192 is often used in temporary brachytherapy, where the radioactive source is temporarily placed in the body and then removed after a specific period of treatment.

In summary, while Iodine-125 and Iridium-192 are commonly used in brachytherapy, Cobalt-60 is primarily used in external beam radiation therapy. Iodine-131 is used in other medical applications, such as thyroid cancer treatment and diagnostic imaging.

questions.text: A 21 year old woman is brought in a drowsy state from a PHC with complaints of fever, severe lower abdominal pain, and purulent vaginal discharge. Her friend revealed that she had had an unsafe abortion a week ago. On examination, her abdomen was distended, BP was 80/60 mmHg, PR was 140 bpm and RR was 36 /min. Which of the following is not a causative agent of her present condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of toxic shock syndrome (TSS) following septic abortion. Escherichia coli can be detected in septic abortion but it is not a causative agent for TSS.

Organisms causing toxic shock syndrome in septic abortion are:

  • Streptococcus pyogenes
  • Clostridium perfringens
  • Clostridium sordellii

Clinical features of septic abortion include:

  • Fever with chills and rigors
  • Abdominal or chest pain
  • Diarrhoea and vomiting
  • Renal angle tenderness
  • Offensive purulent vaginal discharge.

Clinical grading of septic abortion:

  • Grade I - infection localized in the uterus
  • Grade II - infection spreads to parametrium, tubes, ovaries, or pelvic peritoneum
  • Grade III - generalized peritonitis, endotoxic shock, jaundice, or acute renal failure

Empirical antibiotic therapy in septic abortion is started for the broadest microbial coverage. Piperacillin-tazobactam or carbapenem and clindamycin are given intravenously. Antibiotics can be changed once culture sensitivity reports are available.

questions.text: Which of the following procedures is done with the instrument shown below?
questions.solution:
Pipelle aspirator (a) and Vabra (b) aspirator are shown in the image above which are used to obtain endometrial sampling.

Endometrial sampling using Pipelle aspirator - aspiration of the uterine cavity and sending the sample for histopathological examination. It is used as a screening test in menopausal women on HRT or tamoxifen.

Postmenopausal bleeding is defined as bleeding from the genital tract, more than 12 months after the last menstrual period in a woman not on hormone replacement. All postmenopausal women with unexpected uterine bleeding should be evaluated for endometrial malignancy since age is a significant risk factor for this.

Transvaginal ultrasound(TVS) is the first-line investigation. Endometrial sampling is indicated if:

  • The endometrial thickness is >4 mm
  • The endometrium shows diffuse or focal increased echogenicity (heterogeneity)
  • The endometrium is not adequately visualized on transvaginal sonography
  • The woman has persistent bleeding, as it can be a sign of endometrial cancer even when the endometrial thickness is less than 4mm.

The image below gives a summary of the evaluation of postmenopausal bleeding, as per the FOGSI guidelines.

Leech-Wilkinson cannula is used to inject dye in hysterosalpingography. The image below is that of a Leech-Wilkinson cannula.  

 
 

The instrument shown below is a Sim's uterine curette, used for endometrial curettage.

questions.text: A 7-year-old boy weighing 30 Kgs has been posted for surgical resection of a tumor. What is the daily maintenance fluid required for this child while he’s NPO?
questions.solution:
The daily maintenance fluid required for a child weighing 30 Kg is 1700 ml. 

Bodyweight method for calculating the daily maintenance fluid volume (also known as Holliday-Segar method) is used.

Bodyweight Fluid required per day
0–10 Kg 100 mL/Kg
11–20 Kg 1000 mL + 50 mL/Kg for each Kg >10 Kg
>20 Kg 1500 mL + 20 mL/Kg for each Kg >20 kg

Calculation:

In the question, the weight of the child is given as 30 Kgs.

So, the formula for >20 Kg is used.

1500 mL + (20 mL x weight more than 20 Kgs)

Since the child weight is 30 Kgs, he/she is 10 Kgs more.

Therefore, fluid required is

= 1500 mL + (20 mL x 10)

= 1500 mL + 200 mL

= 1700 mL.

questions.text: Identify the type of study from the following design:
questions.solution:
The above study design is typical of a Case control study.

  • A case control study uses individuals as the unit.
  • The study proceeds from effect to cause and is done after the exposure and outcome have occurred.
  • This is the first approach to test causal hypothesis and uses controls to support or refute an inference.
  • A nested case control study is a case control study nested in a cohort study and it is a type of cohort study which moves in the forward direction.

questions.text: A female patient is diagnosed with recurrent genital infections. In which of the conditions does her male partner need to be treated?
questions.solution:
The male partner should be treated with a single dose of oral metronidazole in cases of recurrent Trichomonas infection.

Trichomoniasis is a sexually transmitted infection caused by the protozoan parasite Trichomonas vaginalis. It can cause symptoms such as vaginal discharge, itching, and irritation in females, and urethritis or prostatitis in males.

Since trichomoniasis is transmitted through sexual contact, both partners should be treated simultaneously to prevent reinfection.

The treatment options in case of Trochomoniasis include:

  • An oral dose of metronidazole 500 mg twice daily for 7 days or single oral dose of metronidazole 2 g  
  • Vinegar douche to lower the vaginal PH
  • Trichofuran suppositories
  • Betadine gel

Other Options:

  • Bacterial vaginosis is an imbalance of bacteria in the vagina and is not typically considered a sexually transmitted infection. Treatment of male partners is not routinely recommended. 
  • Candida albicans is the fungus responsible for most cases of vaginal yeast infections (vulvovaginal candidiasis). It is not considered a sexually transmitted infection, and treatment of male partners is generally not necessary unless they have symptoms of a yeast infection.
  • Herpes is a viral infection caused by the herpes simplex virus (HSV). While it can be sexually transmitted, the treatment of male partners may not be routinely necessary unless they are also infected or experiencing symptoms of genital herpes.

questions.text: Which of the following can not be used for emergency contraception?

choices.text: LNG 0.75 mg single dose in 72 hours

questions.solution:
LNG 0.75 mg single dose in 72 hours would not be enough for emergency contraception. Levonorgestrel (LNG) 1.5 mg, i.e. 2 tablets of LNG 0.75 mg, can be used as a single-dose emergency contraceptive. This should be taken within 72 hours of unprotected intercourse. Alternatively, one tablet of LNG 0.75 mg can be followed by another tablet 12 hours later. The tablets can be offered for up to 120 hours but the efficacy decreases with the increase in the interval between coitus and drug intake.

Advantages of LNG:

  • It does not contain estrogen and therefore precludes the associated side effects.
  • It can be used in hypertensive, cardiac, and diabetic patients.
  • It is suitable for lactating women.
  • It can be given up to 120 hours after unprotected intercourse.
  • It can be given as a single-dose therapy. 

Other options:

  • Ulipristal acetate 30 mg single dose is a synthetic progesterone hormone receptor modulator. It can be taken up to 5 days after unprotected sexual intercourse. Side effects include headache, nausea, and mood changes.
  • Centchroman is effective only if taken within 24 hours of unprotected sexual intercourse. 60 mg tablet taken twice in 24 hours can be effective in preventing implantation in 99% of women.

questions.text: A woman requests for medical termination of pregnancy (MTP). The doctor decides to perform a suction evacuation. Till when can this be performed?
questions.solution:
Suction and Evacuation (S&E) is best carried out between 7-12 weeks.

The various methods of termination of pregnancy are: 

Timing Medical methods Surgical methods

1st trimester

(up to 12 weeks)
  • Mifepristone
  • Mifepristone and misoprostol
  • Methotrexate and misoprostol
  • Tamoxifen and misoprostol
 		  
  • Menstrual regulation
  • Vacuum aspiration (MVA/EVA)
  • Suction evacuation and/or curettage
  • Dilatation and evacuation -
  • Rapid method
  • Slow method 

2nd trimester

(13 - 20 weeks)
  • Misoprostol
  • Mifepristone and misoprostol
  • Dinoprostone
  • Carboprost
  • Dilatation and evacuation
  • Intrauterine instillation of hyperosmotic solutions
  • Oxytocin infusion
  • Hysterotomy

questions.text: An elderly female patient presented with diarrhea occurring approximately 20 minutes after meals. She underwent a Billroth I gastrectomy operation.  What is the most appropriate initial management for this patient?

choices.text: Prescribe proton pump inhibitors in combination with amoxicillin.
Consider reversing the surgical procedure from Billroth II to Billroth I
Advise the patient to consume small, frequent meals and increase protein content in their diet.

questions.solution:
This patient most likely has dumping syndrome, and the initial management for this patient is to recommend small frequent meals and increased protein content in the diet to manage symptoms and slow down gastric emptying.

Dumping syndrome is a common complication after gastrectomy, particularly after procedures like Billroth I, where the stomach's capacity is reduced. It occurs due to the rapid emptying of the stomach contents into the small intestine, leading to symptoms like diarrhea, nausea, sweating, and palpitations, typically occurring shortly after meals.

The initial management of dumping syndrome involves dietary modifications. Recommending small, frequent meals can help slow down the rate at which food is emptied from the stomach and prevent the sudden surge in glucose absorption that triggers the symptoms. Increasing the protein content of meals can also help stabilize blood sugar levels and reduce the severity of symptoms.

Other Options:

Option A: Proton pump inhibitors (PPIs) and amoxicillin are not the primary treatments for dumping syndrome. PPIs are used to reduce stomach acid production, while amoxicillin is an antibiotic. Neither directly addresses the underlying issue of rapid gastric emptying and glucose absorption seen in dumping syndrome.

Option B: Insulin and glucose are not typically used as initial management for dumping syndrome. Dumping syndrome involves rapid glucose absorption, and managing it through dietary adjustments is usually the first step.

Option C: Reversing the surgical procedure to Billroth 1 or Roux-en-Y is a more drastic option that might be considered if dietary modifications do not effectively manage the symptoms of dumping syndrome.

questions.text: A 20-year-old man was brought to the emergency department after a RTA. On presentation, his pulse is 110/minute, RR is  18/minute and BP is 80/60 mmhg.  What is the next step in management?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a patient being hemodynamically unstable after a RTA indicates a probable ongoing hemorrhage and the next step in the management is to perform an eFAST.

Cardiogenic shock, hemorrhagic shock, or pneumothorax are the most likely causes of hypotension in a trauma patient. Ultrasound evaluation using eFAST to look for pericardium, pleural cavities, and abdomen in combination with plain radiographs of the chest and pelvis will usually identify the source of the bleed. 

In patients with hypotension due to blunt trauma, the pelvis should be wrapped in a sheet for stabilization until radiography can be done. 

eFAST stands for extended FAST and incorporates left and right thoracic views to assess for pneumothorax and haemothorax.

Limitations of eFAST are:

  1. Operator-dependent
  2. Bowel gas and subcutaneous air distort images.
  3. Can miss diaphragm, bowel, and pancreatic injuries
  4. Unreliable for assessment of the retroperitoneum
  5. Cannot reliably exclude injury in penetrating trauma
  6. May need repeating or supplementing with other investigations

FAST stands for Focussed Assessment with Sonography for Trauma. It is a rapid, non-invasive bedside test for detecting free fluid using sonography used to assess patients for potential thoracoabdominal injuries. 

Technique:

  • The patient is placed in a supine position and the following regions are scanned:
    • Subxiphoid transverse view: assess for pericardial effusion and left lobe liver injuries
    • Longitudinal view of the right upper quadrant: assess for right liver injuries, right kidney injury, and Morison pouch
    • Longitudinal view of the left upper quadrant: assess for splenic injury and left kidney injury
    • Transverse and longitudinal views of the suprapubic region: assess the bladder and pouch of Douglas

questions.text: The most common cause of post-menopausal bleeding all over the world is
questions.solution:
The most common cause of post-menopausal bleeding globally is senile endometrial atrophy, that is atrophy of the vaginal mucosa or endometrium.

Hypoestrogenism in a menopausal woman causes atrophy of the endometrium and vagina. In the uterus, the atrophic endometrial surfaces contain little or no fluid to prevent intracavitary friction. This results in microerosions of the surface epithelium and a subsequent chronic inflammatory reaction, which is prone to light bleeding or spotting.

Other Options :

  • Cervical cancer : Cervical cancer is the most common cause of post menopausal bleeding in India, and not over the world.
  • Endometrial cancer : Endometrial cancer is the most common cause of postmenopausal bleeding in developed countries, and not over the world.
  • Hormone replacement therapy : Hormone replacement therapy is the second most common cause of post-menopausal bleeding all over the world.

Note : Endometrial cancer accounts for 10 % of cases of post-menopausal bleeding. Still, all postmenopausal women with unexpected uterine bleeding should be evaluated for endometrial carcinoma, since this potentially lethal disease.

The confusion kill : Remember, no cancer is as prevalent as the hypoestrogenism in a postmenopausal woman and this is why senile endometrial atrophy is the most common cause of bleeding in them, and not any cancer.

questions.text: A young boy presented with a bluish-red cystic swelling on the left side of the floor of the mouth as shown below. On examination, it showed fluctuation and transillumination. It was initially 1.5 cm, and progressed to 5 cm in the last few months. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given scenario and the image of a cystic swelling on the floor of the mouth are suggestive of a ranula.

Ranula is a transilluminant mucocele. It is also known as "frog's belly", as it resembles the vocal sacs of a frog.

It is of two types:

  • Oral ranula - It is a benign cystic lesion formed by extravasation of mucus, involving the sublingual gland. Clinically present as cystic swelling in the floor of the mouth. On examination fluctuation test and transillumination test is positive. It is conservatively managed by marsupialization. Definitive management is the excision of the cyst. Some may resolve spontaneously.
  • Cervical or plunging ranula- is a rare type of retention cyst arising from the sublingual gland. The mucous passes through the mylohyoid muscle diaphragm to enter the neck. Clinically present as intraoral and cervical swelling. Diagnosis is made by USG or MRI. Management includes excision of the sublingual gland + aspiration of saliva out of the sac.

Other options:

Options A: Ectopic thyroid tissue is a developmental defect of the thyroid gland and is frequently found along the course of the thyroglossal duct. Lingual thyroid is the most common presentation of ectopic thyroid (shown below).

Option B: Cystic hygroma is usually seen in neonates and early childhood. They are cystic swellings filled with lymph fluid and are characteristically brilliantly translucent. They occur in the neck and can involve the parotid, submandibular, tongue, etc. The swelling is soft and partially compressible. Definitive treatment is the excision of the swelling. 

Option C: Ludwig's angina is a brawny swelling of the submandibular region that is caused by streptococcal infection. The infection tracks down to the mylohyoid muscle causing inflammation that displaces the tongue leading to dysphagia and painful airway obstruction. Management is by antibiotic therapy and decompression of the floor of the mouth by incising mylohyoid muscle.

questions.text: A 34-year-old G3P2L2 woman with a past history of Caesarean section and a Dilatation and curettage , presents to the ER with hypotension, tachycardia, and severe abdominal pain. On examination, fetal parts are palpable in the abdomen and Fetal heart rate is weak. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The diagnosis of the given clinical scenario is uterine rupture.

Previous cesarean section and Dilatation and curettage are both potential risk factors for scar dehiscence and uterine rupture. Hypotension, tachycardia, dizziness, confusion, abdominal pain, scar site tenderness are all the signs of uterine rupture. Rarely, Hemoperitoneum can irritate the diaphragm and cause chest and shoulder tip pain. 

CTG in uterine rupture will show non-reassuring variable fetal heart rate which might progress to late decelerations and bradycardia. 

Differential diagnoses for uterine rupture:

  • Pre-eclampsia 
  • Eclampsia
  • Pulmonary embolism - amniotic fluid embolism / venous embolism
  • Abruptio placenta
  • Anaphylaxis to anesthesia
  • Peripartum cardiomyopathy 

Management of uterine rupture:

  • confirm the fetal station and arrest of labor
  • Stabilize the patient's vitals
  • Immediate cesarean section should be performed, immediately/ as early as possible to avoid neurological or hypoxic sequelae in newborns.
  • Depending on the extent of rupture and vitals on the table decision of uterine suturing or hysterectomy or sub-total hysterectomy may be taken.

questions.text: This instrument is not used in which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
The instrument given in the above image is a proctoscope and proctoscopy is contraindicated in acute anal fissures.

Due to pain, digital rectal examination and anoscopy are not performed immediately in acute anal fissures. Acute anal fissures are examined under anaesthesia in operating room when needed. 

Anal fissure:

Clinical features

  • Severe pain associated with defecation resolves spontaneously and reappears during the next evacuation
  • It may even be associated with the passage of fresh blood noticed on tissue after wiping
  • Most of the fissures are located in the posterior midline, with the rest being located in the anterior midline. Fissures located laterally can be possible due to other diseases like HIV, TB, syphilis, Crohn's disease, or carcinoma.

Treatment of Anal fissure

  • The focus is to normalise bowel habits. Bowel softeners, dietary fibres, and adequate water should be recommended
  • Medical therapy involves the topical application of glyceryl trinitrate. It releases nitric oxide and relaxes the internal anal sphincter. This reduces spasms and pain and improves vasculature to promote healing
  • Surgical therapy is recommended for chronic fissures that have failed medical therapy. Lateral internal sphincterotomy is the procedure of choice. The aim of this procedure is to decrease the spasms of the internal sphincter by dividing a portion of the muscle.

questions.text: A pre-menopausal woman is diagnosed with lymph node-positive, early invasive breast cancer. IHC reveals ER +, PR +, and HER-2-neu 1+. Which of the following drug will you provide for this patient?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario suggests early invasive breast cancer in a pre-menopausal woman, which is lymph node-positive, hormone receptor-positive (ER/PR +), and Her-2/neu negative (Her-2/neu IHC score of 1+ is considered negative). Hence Tamoxifen is the drug of choice. 

Treatment of early-stage breast cancer (T1-2 N0-1 M0) includes:

Breast conservation surgery (BCS) + ALND or SLNB + Radiotherapy
  • BCS is followed by radiotherapy
  • Mastectomy is done if BCS is contraindicated.
  • Clinical N0 status-sentinel lymph node biopsy (SLNB) at the time of surgery.
  • Clinical N1 status-ultrasound-guided fine-needle aspiration (FNA): axillary lymph node dissection (ALND) if positive and sentinel lymph node biopsy (SLNB) if negative.
Endocrine therapy: for hormone receptor (ER/PR) positive 
  • For Premenopausal women-tamoxifen (selective estrogen receptor modulator, SERM)
  • For post-menopausal women (usually >50 years)-anastrozole (Aromatase inhibitor)
  • Tamoxifen has an agonistic action on the endometrium, leading to an increased risk of endometrial cancers Hence, it is not used in post-menopausal women.

Anti-Her-2 therapy: for Her-2/neu positive breast cancer
  • Trastuzumab is given
  • Her-2/neu IHC interpretation:
  •   0 or 1+ = Negative
  •   2+ = Equivocal cases ->        confirmed with Fluorescence    in situ hybridization (FISH)      analysis
  •   3+ = Positive
Chemotherapy

Indicated for:

  • Lymph nodes positive
  • Lymph nodes negative but tumor size of >1 cm
  • Lymph nodes negative and tumor size of >0.5 cm with
    • Blood vessel/Lymph vessel invasion
    • ER/PR –ve
    • Her-2/neu overexpression
    • High grade
  • Triple-negative breast carcinoma
  • High recurrence score after Oncotype Dx

The table below shows the summary of the adjuvant treatment approach:

  Tumor hormone receptor status (ER, PR)
Tumor HER status Positive Negative
Positive Endocrine therapy + chemotherapy + trastuzumab Chemotherapy + trastuzumab
Negative Endocrine therapy ± chemotherapy Chemotherapy

questions.text: A 40-year-old patient with a history of tuberculosis presents with dyspnea on exertion. On examination, it is noted that the JVP rises during inspiration. A chest radiograph of the patient is given below. Which of the following is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a patient with a history of tuberculosis now presenting with positive Kussmaul's sign, and pericardial calcification seen on chest radiograph suggest a diagnosis of constrictive pericarditis. 

Constrictive pericarditis is a chronic type of pericarditis that results when there is healing of acute fibrinous pericarditis or absorption of chronic pericardial effusion. While the most common cause in developing countries is tuberculosis, in developed countries, it occurs following viral pericarditis, cardiac surgery, mediastinal irradiation, or as a manifestation of rheumatoid arthritis and SLE. The main abnormality which occurs in constrictive pericarditis is the inability of the ventricles to fill because of the rigid and thickened pericardium. Unlike tamponade, this restriction is not uniform through the diastole. Ventricular filling is normal early in the diastole but stops suddenly when the elastic limit of the pericardium is reached. Y-descent on the JVP curve is prominent in constrictive pericarditis because it represents the rapid early filling of the ventricles. A sudden stop in ventricular filling and subsequent rising pressure is seen as a square root sign in the JVP curve.

The patient presents with exertional dyspnea and orthopnea. There may be a paradoxical rise in venous pressure during inspiration (Kussmaul's sign). Apart from constrictive pericarditis, Kussmaul's sign can be positive in tricuspid stenosis, restrictive cardiomyopathy, right heart failure, and pulmonary embolism. The ECG often shows low-voltage QRS complexes and diffuse flattening of T-waves. A chest radiograph may show pericardial calcification, especially in tuberculous pericarditis.

questions.text: What is the best management approach for gastroschisis in a neonate?
questions.solution:
A neonate with gastroschisis would need an immediate primary closure. Primary closure under general anesthesia or gradual reduction using a preformed silo may be performed. Parenteral nutrition is often needed for several weeks to support intestinal recovery.  

Gastroschisis is an abdominal wall defect located on one side of the umbilicus (right side commonly) allowing protrusion of the intestines, stomach, bladder, and sometimes ovaries or undescended testes. The loops of the bowel are not covered by amnion as they herniate through the abdominal wall directly into the amniotic cavity. The affected bowel loops can be damaged by exposure to amniotic fluid.

Risk factors include teenage pregnancy, recreational drug use, smoking, and genitourinary infection during pregnancy. After birth, careful management is required to prevent twisting or kinking of the blood supply to the intestines. The abdomen is wrapped with transparent plastic wrap, a nasogastric tube is inserted, and fluid resuscitation is initiated.

Management: Immediate surgical intervention is required after birth to prevent complications such as infection, dehydration, and damage to the exposed abdominal organs. Surgical repair typically involves gently placing the protruding abdominal contents back into the abdominal cavity and closing the abdominal wall defect surgically. This approach helps protect the exposed organs, prevent complications, and facilitate normal abdominal wall development.

Related Pearl: Difference between gastroschisis and omphalocele

Characteristic Gastroschisis Omphalocele
Defect size (diameter) 2-3 cm 2-15 cm
Sac Never Always, may be ruptured
Gestational age Prematurity Term
Umbilical cord Adjacent to the defect (defect is seen usually on its right side)  Attached to sac
Herniated viscera Small bowel, stomach, colon Small bowel, stomach, colon, liver
Malrotation Yes Yes
Bowel character Inflammatory, edematous Normal
Enternal nutrition Delayed Normal
Associated abnormalities Uncommon (10% atresia) Common (50%)

questions.text: Which of the following is the gold standard treatment for the condition shown in the image?
questions.solution:
The gold standard for the treatment of varicose veins is endothermal ablation. The given image shows tortuous dilated veins suggestive of varicose veins.

The management of varicose veins is as follows:

Incompetence Management
Great saphenous vein (GSV) and saphenofemoral (SFJ) 
  • Endothermal ablation (gold standard treatment for varicose veins). It includes:
  • Endovenous laser ablation (EVLA)
  • Radiofrequency ablation (RFA)
  • Trendelenburg procedure (Flush Ligation of Saphenofemoral Junction (SFJ) after ligation of 6 tributaries) ± stripping (retrogradely up to the knee, to prevent saphenous nerve injury.)     
Short saphenous vein (SSJ) and saphenopopliteal (SPJ)
  • Flush ligation of SPJ 
  • Endothermal ablation
  • Endovenous laser ablation (EVLA)
  • Radiofrequency ablation (RFA)
Perforator 
  • Dodd and Crockett surgery - Multiple subfascial ligations
  • Subfascial endoscopic perforator surgery (SEPS) - smaller incision, so cosmetically better
  • Endothermal ablation:
  • Endovenous laser ablation (EVLA)
  • Radiofrequency ablation (RFA)

New treatment modalities:

  • Foam sclerotherapy - The Tessari method is a widely used method to prepare foam for sclerotherapy. Sclerosant: air ratio taken is 1:3 or 1:4
  • Endovenous glue therapy - endoluminal application of cyanoacrylate adhesive 
  • Transilluminated powered phlebectomy

 

Option B: Injection sclerotherapy: In this technique, a detergent is injected directly into the veins.

  • Most commonly used sclerosant is Sodium tetradecyl sulfate.
  • The detergent causes endothelial damage leading to thrombosis, fibrosis, and obliteration (sclerosis) of veins.
  • Injection sclerotherapy alone can be successful in varicose veins <3 mm in diameter and in telangiectatic vessels.
  • Complications from sclerotherapy include allergic reaction, local hyperpigmentation, air embolism, stroke and pain at the site of injection.

Option C: Phlebectomy -Small stab incisions are made to revert the reflux by occluding the refluxing tributaries of the veins.

Option D: Saphenous vein ligation and stripping is the preferred therapy for patients with GSVs of very large diameter (>2 cm).

Related Pearl: Classification of Chronic Lower Extremity Venous Disease

Telangiectases are less than 1 mm, reticular veins are between 1 and 3 mm, and varicose veins are greater than 3 mm measured in the upright position.

questions.solution:
The incorrect combination of seizure and its medication is typical absence seizures: topiramate. The treatment of typical absence seizures is ethosuximide

questions.text: Which of the following is the recommended treatment for the condition shown in the image?
questions.solution:
The given X-ray image shows a lower/distal ureteric stone. Ureteroscopic removal is generally preferred for stones <6mm and specifically those present in the distal ureter. Ureteric calculi are directly visualized through semi-rigid ureteroscopes. Stones are then fragmented and extracted using a dormia basket. Complications are related to injury to the ureteric mucosa such as ureteric perforation and extravasation, avulsion of the ureter, and ureteric stricture.

Ureteroscopic stone removal using a dormia basket is depicted in the image below.  

Option A: Percutaneous nephrolithotomy (PCNL) - Endoscopic instruments are passed into the kidney by percutaneous technique and stones are fragmented and removed. It is mainly used in treating large stones in the renal pelvis and calyces and stones in the proximal ureter.

Indications of PCNL:

  • Obstructions caused by anatomical abnormalities like pelviureteric junction obstruction, calyceal diverticula or ureteric obstruction
  • Staghorn calculi
  • Stones >2.5 cm in size
  • Stone composition - struvite, calcium oxalate monohydrate , and cystine stones
  • Multiple stones
  • Obese patients in whom ESWL is contraindicated
  • Lower calyceal stones 
  • Stones not responding to EWSL

 Other options:

Option C: Extracorporeal shockwave lithotripsy (ESWL) is a non-invasive method that generates shockwaves outside the body, which are focused on stones. It is the commonest method of treating renal calculi nowadays. 

Stones up to approximately 1.5 cm in size are suitable for this form of treatment. Cystine stones which are often multiple, and very hard are relatively resistant to ESWL due to their hardness. Contraindications for ESWL include obese patients, pregnant patients, and patients taking oral anticoagulants.

Option D: Wait and watch is done for small stones <5mm as they are more likely to pass spontaneously.

Related Pearl: Management of renal and ureteric calculi

ESWL: Extracorporeal Shock Wave Lithotripsy

PCNL: Percutaneous nephrolithotomy

URS: Ureteroscopic retrieval of stones

Related Pearl: Microscopic Appearance of Various Stones

  • Cystine stones: Hexagonal
  • Uric acid stones: Varying shapes (rhomboids or parallelograms)
  • Calcium oxalate
    • Monohydrate: Dumbbell shaped
    • Dihydrate: Octahedral or envelope shaped
  • Struvite stones: Rectangular or coffin lid

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman presents to the OPD with palpitation and weight loss. On examination, both of her legs had the following lesion given below. On applying pressure, the indentation does not persist on release. ECG shows sinus tachycardia. What is the probable etiological cause for the oedema?
questions.solution:
A bilateral presentation of non-pitting oedema in the lower limbs along with features of palpitation and weight loss in the given scenario point towards a diagnosis of pretibial myxedema. And most probably it is due to the underlying thyroid disease.

Pretibial myxedema/Thyroid dermopathy  (localized edematous and thickened pretibial plaque formation) in seen secondary to Grave's disease.

Other options:

Option C: While chronic lymphangitis and acute lymphatic filariasis can also cause non-pitting oedema, they usually have a unilateral/localized presentation and the given clinical history is not relevant to this condition.

Option B and D: Nephrotic syndrome and heart failure cause bilateral pitting oedema. Also, the clinical scenario given above does not fit either of them. 

Causes of generalized oedema include:

  • Heart failure
  • Chronic renal failure
  • Nephrotic syndrome
  • Liver cirrhosis

Causes of localized oedema:

  • Thrombophlebitis
  • Chronic lymphangitis
  • Resection of regional lymph nodes
  • Filariasis

questions.text: Identify the given logo below?
questions.solution:
The given logo is of the Bureau of Indian Standards.

BIS is the National Standard Body of India established under the BIS Act 2016 for the harmonious development of the activities of standardization, marking and quality certification of goods.

BIS has been providing traceability and tangibility benefits to the national economy in a number of ways – providing safe reliable quality goods; minimizing health hazards to consumers; promoting export and import substitutes; controlling over proliferation of varieties etc. through standardization, certification and testing.

Other options:

Option C: The Food Corporation of India implements the objectives of the National Food Policy:

  • Effective price support operations for safeguarding the interests of poor farmers
  • Distribution of foodgrains throughout the country for Public Distribution System (PDS)
  • Maintaining a satisfactory level of operational and buffer stocks of foodgrains to ensure National Food Security
  • Regulate market price to provide foodgrains to consumers at a reliable price

 

Option A: AGMARK is a certification mark employed on agricultural products in India, assuring that they conform to a set of standards approved by the Directorate of Marketing and Inspection, an agency of the Government of India.

Option D: Goods and Services Tax (GST) is an indirect tax (or consumption tax) used in India on the supply of goods and services. It is a comprehensive, multistage, destination-based tax.

questions.text: What is the other name for an outlet forceps?
questions.solution:
Wrigley's forceps is an outlet forceps. It is used to provide traction force and can also be used in cesarean sections.

It is shown in the image below.

Related Pearl: Obstetrics forceps

Commonly used forceps: 

1) Simpson forceps

  • The most commonly used types of forceps in outlet delivery.
  • Has elongated cephalic curve.
  • These are used when there is substantial molding of the fetal head.

2) Elliot forceps

  • Has an adjustable pin for regulating the lateral pressure on the handles.
  • They are used most often when there is minimal molding.
  • More suitable for outlet delivery.

3) Kielland forceps

  • Has small pelvic curve and a sliding lock.
  • Suitable for head with little molding.
  • The most common forceps used for rotational delivery.
  • Helps correct asynclitism.

4) Piper forceps

  • Distinct perineal curve.
  • Allows for application to the after-coming head in breech delivery.

5) Tucker-McLane forceps

  • Suitable for fetal head with little molding.
  • Used in rotational delivery.

6) Barton forceps and traction handle

  • Used in rotational delivery.
  • Most importantly used for delivery of occipitotransverse positions in a platypelloid pelvis.
  • It is an obsolete procedure.
